name: Hockey, Joe, MP
text:
—In summarising the remarks I made on the A New Tax System (Taxation Laws Amendment) Bill (No. 1) 1999  last night, I would just add some further comments in response to the words of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and also those of the member for Rankin. They both express concern that the new withholding arrangements, and especially the abolition of the prescribed payments system, will encourage the growth of so-called dependent contractors who only work for one organisation. I am advised that the pay-as-you-go withholding provisions are not specifically designed to deal with those contractors. The main issues involved with those contractors are primary liability issues, whereas this bill is about collection issues.
Secondly, withholding will not generally apply to payments to contractors. The reason for this is that contractors generally will be charging GST on their services. The government considers that it would be too great a burden for business if both GST and withholding generally were applied to these transactions. It is no surprise that the Labor Party should be pushing that line. The third point, however, is that businesses generally will be required to withhold at the top marginal tax rate from payments to contractors who fail to quote their Australian business number in an invoice. So this measure is designed to prevent tax evasion where payments are made in cash.
Labour hire workers will not be treated like other contractors. A labour hire firm will have to withhold payments to workers for work performed for the client of the labour hire firm. The payment to the worker will not attract GST. As the honourable member noted, these arrangements will address any competitive advantage that labour hire workers have over traditional employees. Finally, we will be rejecting the Labor Party's amendment to this bill.
Mr Emerson interjecting—
—It comes as no surprise, I am sure, to members of the opposition because we read in today's paper that only yesterday the Leader of the Opposition was boasting to his party room about how good it is to be performing in sideshow alley for the Labor Party—how good it is for the Labor Party to be operating outside the mainstream debate in Australian politics. That is intriguing logic. It is great to be here in the fun park, but it is even better to operate a big stall in sideshow alley rather than to be in the main performance arena where the coalition and the Democrats are getting on with the job. That is intriguing leadership and intriguing commonsense.

You can only wonder what sort of logic is going through the office of the Leader of the Opposition. I would have speculated that when Michael Costello joined that office he would have added a new dimension to the thinking in the office. Obviously, one or other of two events is occurring. He has no influ 
 ence as the Leader of the Opposition's chief of staff or, alternately, his political antennae are not online at the moment. I will give him the benefit of the doubt. But the Leader of the Opposition is well experienced in this place, so I am surprised that he should say, `It is great to be operating out in the sidecar and let's leave the driving of the motorbike to the coalition and the Democrats.'
Mr Emerson interjecting—
—The member for Rankin knows better than he does.
—Here we have another example of Labor Party guff when they talk about delaying this bill until Ralph comes into play. The recommendations of the Ralph committee are being considered and are going through due process within the coalition and the government—which is appropriate—but why is it that, even at the time of death's doorknock, the Labor Party continue to push hard on ANTS? Why is it that they continue to oppose to the very end every single initiative of the government in relation to ANTS after the substantive bills have been passed by the Senate and the House of Representatives? It is because they are trying to get some relevancy back into their politics. It is a shameful exercise in political expediency and they will be judged very harshly for it.
We say that this bill has no relevance to the business taxation review occurring at the moment. We are focusing on getting on with the job of implementing ANTS and we will take the next step as and when appropriate in relation to business taxation. But, yet again, even in this House—and I heard the Deputy Leader of the Opposition's words on this—the opposition want to be dealt into Ralph and business taxation, in the same way that they wanted to be dealt into the Telstra privatisation debate, the workplace relations and reform program, the new taxation system that went through the parliament and the statement of reconciliation made by this House quite recently.
Why is it that on every single issue the Labor Party is choosing to take an alternate track and is finding that that alternate track leads to a dead-end? I will tell you why: because there is no strategic thinking. The 
 Labor Party has been intellectually lazy since the 1996 election and any dissenting opinion in the Labor Party is expressed but not dealt with by the Leader of the Opposition. If you are going to pretend to be an alternate government, you have to have the intellectual debates about policy and not simply choose the expedient political path which the Labor Party continues to choose at every single hard option.
Mr Emerson interjecting—
—It says a lot about the Labor Party at the moment. I can only speculate that the Labor Party have not yet gone through their cathartic experience in relation to policy development that each opposition should go through, and it is a reflection on people of good intellect. And I will say here, in due deference to the members in the house, that the member for Rankin and the member for Wills do possess good intellects. They do their research and the hard work, and they do bend the elbow in policy debates, but why is it that the Labor Party policies of the 1950s have overtaken the Labor Party policies of the 21st century? Why is it? It is a form of recidivism. They have gone back to gaol. They have not yet come out of the 1950s, and this bill is an example of the sort of guffaw that the Labor Party continues to put before the House—yet again, a senseless motion about an alternative system and an irrelevant point about the relationship to business taxation review. The government rejects it and is getting on with the job at hand. We are about delivering good policy and we will continue to oppose the Labor Party's games. (Time expired)
Mr Emerson interjecting—
—The member for Rankin has been persistently reminded by the chair of the obligations he has under the standing orders. His continual interjections therefore reflect on the chair and not on the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Crean's  amendment) stand part of the question.
The House divided.				[9.55 a.m.]
(Mr Speaker—Mr Neil Andrew)
		Ayes . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 74
		Noes . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 60
                                          ——
			Majority . . . . . . . . . . . . 14
                                          ——
Voting details are recorded in the Votes and Proceedings.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
debate_title: <title>A NEW TAX SYSTEM (TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT) BILL (No. 1) 1999</title>

name: Thomson, Kelvin, MP
text:
—These appropriation bills seek to appropriate moneys from the consolidated revenue fund for initiatives flowing from the deal that the government made with the Democrats to secure passage of the GST. The measures are, firstly, for the book industry assistance plan and, secondly, for additional funding for the Supported Accommodation Assistance Plan. Those measures are contained in Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 1) 1999 . We have a number of environment initiatives contained in Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 2) 1999 , and I will deal with each of these in turn.
Appropriation bill No. 1 provides $60 million for each of the four years from 2000-01 through to 2003-04. The main aims of the plan are to provide financial assistance to those producing books in Australia, Australian creators of books and retailers of textbooks in Australia. We need to point out to the House right up-front that this is needed only because of the GST and the impact that it will have on those who are involved in producing, creating and retailing books in Australia. We do this and we question the adequacy of this measure.
We think it is an inadequate response to what in the first place was a most unsatisfactory decision to impose a GST on books. We believe that it has the potential to create an administrative nightmare for every bookshop in Australia and that it is only going to compound the problem. Indeed, bookshops will have the administrative problems that every small business will have with the GST, but now they will have a whole new complex rebate to administer which has not been 
 properly worked through, and this does represent a potential nightmare for bookshops. This measure represents, in our view, small and inadequate compensation for the industry in general for a tax that will be a direct attack on what Australia needs to be—that is, the knowledge nation. So this represents perhaps one step forward but certainly two steps back for the knowledge nation.
The government knows that the GST is bad for the book industry, for consumers of books, for bookshops and for education and knowledge in this country. It had to be embarrassed and shamed into a promise that it would do something in this regard, and we now see it in the form of this legislation which represents just a few crumbs off the table to the book industry when what we really needed to be saying was, `We are not going to be imposing a GST on knowledge.'
It is a totally inadequate measure in our view, unnecessary but for the government's determination to impose a GST on books and, indeed, but for the Democrats' capitulation on this issue. One of the core promises, I guess, of the Democrats when they went to the last election was that they would not allow in any shape or form a GST to be imposed on books, but after the election we saw the Democrats caving in, capitulating to the government on this issue. Now they walk around saying, `We've done wonderful things for the book industry,' when in fact the contrary is true. They had it in their power to prevent a GST being imposed on books in this country but they did not do it.
So what we have here is a piece of legislation which effectively says to the book industry, `We've struck you a dreadful blow and you're bleeding, but here is a bandaid.' Certainly, the bandaid is better than nothing, and we will not be opposing it, but it is our view that it is a small and inadequate response. Those book publishers who have indicated that they welcome the measure say that it goes some way to compensate for the GST, but that is the best you can say for it: that it does go some way to compensate.
Australians ought to be aware that this plan is not good news. Despite its meagre compensation, come 1 July 2000 people involved in 
 this area—authors, bookshops, students, parents, Australians purchasing books—will be worse off. It would have been better, if we had to proceed down the GST path, to exempt books as the Democrats had pledged, rather than to introduce these complicated arrangements. I further point out to the House that it is quite hypocritical for some opposite to be talking about literacy—we hear from the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs from time to time on this front—when this tax will make books, and therefore knowledge and learning, more expensive.
The second provision in this legislation is that which provides an additional $15 million for the Supported Accommodation Assistance Program for each of the four years through to 2003-04. The processes for distributing this money to the states are not clear. This is something that we would like some information about. Indeed, in the lead-up to the renegotiation of the agreement of the Supported Accommodation Assistance Program, we would like to hear more from the government about how this is intended to be distributed to the states.
I should point out that we believe the government has failed to take real action to address homelessness issues. The government's negotiations with the Democrats have led to this $15 million per year being provided for youth homelessness. We think this is trying to solve a major national crisis with, once again, as with the books area, crumbs from the table. The government failed in its budget to address Supported Accommodation Assistance Program funding at all, and the $45 million over six years amounts to a meagre $7.5 million a year and it has been instituted merely to ensure that the staff employed in the Supported Accommodation Assistance Program agencies have and enjoy award conditions. Not one dollar of that amount will actually go towards expanding the Supported Accommodation Assistance Program services to the needy.
Last year, the government sponsored a review by the Australian Housing and Urban Research Institute which recommended, at a minimum, a 25 per cent funding increase to SAAP in order just to service current unmet 
 demands. The national evaluation of the program, released by the Department of Family and Community Services some three weeks ago, concurred with that analysis and requested that recurrent funding for the first year of the new agreement reach a total of $285 million.
Against that background, the extra $15 million which was reannounced by the government as part of this deal with the Democrats is candidly nowhere near the 25 per cent increase recommended by the government's own review and by the government's own Department of Family and Community Services. The demand for services for the homeless is ever growing. Figures released in budget week showed that the number of people accessing these services had risen from 101,000 in 1996-97 to 160,000—something like a 66 per cent increase—for the financial year 1997-98. This is a matter of considerable concern. The government was saying that it was a good thing that it was providing more services, but we would say it is illogical for the government to be treating as a sign of success evidence that there are more and more homeless people in our society. We are concerned that what is proposed here simply will not address these problems in a serious way.
Appropriation bill No. 2 provides for the environmental initiatives agreed with the Democrats, and I will go through them now. Those initiatives are: support conversions to compressed natural gas or liquid petroleum gas for commercial vehicles and buses that have a gross vehicle mass equal to or greater than 3.5 tonnes—that also applies to trains and ferries—support a product stewardship system for the reuse and recycling of waste oil; support the utilisation of photovoltaic systems on residential buildings and community reuse buildings; support the development and commercialisation of renewable energy; support the use of renewable energy from remote power generation; support the development and implementation of in-service emissions-testing capabilities for diesel patrol vehicles, where the diesel emissions testing is in connection with the making and/or implementation of a diesel national environment 
 protection measure; and provide for a Greenhouse Gas Abatement Program. As you can see, as far as they go, they are welcome, and we will certainly not be opposing them.
It is appropriate at this time to re-emphasise the environmental consequences of the goods and services tax, of which this legislation is a consequence, and the reduction in economic incentives to use alternative environmentally friendly fuels and technologies. The overwhelming body of evidence presented to the Senate committee inquiry into the impacts of the GST on the environment reinforced the view that the government's package was ill-considered and fundamentally flawed. Indeed, the Senate committee's report highlighted negative impacts on a great number of areas which it examined in some detail, including impact on the urban environment, impact on public transport services, impact on emerging technologies and impact on exports. All the evidence that the Senate committee considered tended to point to disastrous and long-term damage to the environment which would occur through an increase in diesel fuel pollutants and greenhouse gases and a reduction in economic incentives to use alternative environmentally friendly fuels and technologies.
The diesel fuel excise cut will result in economic incentive to use diesel fuel transport, a switch from petrol to diesel fuel vehicles, a switch from more fuel efficient rail transport to less efficient and high polluting road transport, and a reduction in incentives to switch from diesel to gaseous fuels and to new technologies such as solar. We want to continue to express the concern that the greatest environmental effects as a result of this measure will be in urban areas and that increased diesel fuel consumption will lead to an increase in highly dangerous particulates in our urban environments. We note that the Australian Medical Association has warned of increased risk of lung cancer and a variety of respiratory disorders.
The direct effect of the cut in the diesel fuel excise will be to make it difficult for the government to even meet those watered-down Kyoto greenhouse targets. One of the clear losers will be the emerging alternative energy 
 sector. The impact on emerging technologies could cost many jobs. Australia is currently a world leader in the development of new technology and the renewable energy sector, including solar. It is clear that the government's taxation package will be highly detrimental to this critical and developing industry. It will undermine the industry's huge export potential. The measures in this bill simply do not adequately address that issue.
Evidence to the Senate committee expressed deep concern that removal of the diesel fuel rebate would also impact on what I have to describe as the already fragile economics of the Alice Springs to Darwin and Melbourne to Darwin railway proposals. The evidence on the environment, as with the evidence on books, is that the GST will impact very adversely and that the government's compensation measures will not be adequate.
It is worth pointing out that the Democrats went to the Australian people with a non-negotiable set of changes to the government's GST proposals. When we look at what they have achieved in this bill, they have in fact achieved none of the changes at all. First, in relation to the diesel fuel rebate, they said that it would be only payable to trucks over 20 tonnes except for those carrying farm produce. In the end, they gave it to all trucks over 4.5 tonnes. Second, they said that they would not allow trips within cities to qualify for the grant. But, when you see what we have ended up with, there is no apportionment at all for diesel used in the city. So as long as a journey crosses a city boundary, wherever it is, then all of the journey qualifies for a grant, even if the overwhelming proportion of the journey is within a capital city. So journeys commencing outside a metropolitan area but ending up in a metropolitan area and journeys commencing in a metropolitan area but ending up outside the metropolitan area will all qualify for a grant for the complete journey.
What we will now see is the redesign of intra-city transport routes to ensure that they briefly leave the metropolitan area in order to qualify for the rebate. Worse still, since there will be no way to ensure the integrity of the scheme, there will be claims based on ficti 
 tious routes which involve a brief time outside the city. This is not going to discourage fossil fuel use; it is going to encourage fossil fuel use. No wonder the Democrats' expert environmental consultant, Dr Clive Hamilton, resigned in despair when he understood where the deal was going. We can see from this bill before the House that the Democrats have been absolutely naive in their negotiations with the government and have been played on a break. They have in fact achieved a system where a lot of the diesel used in cities will qualify for the grant system.
That is a most unsatisfactory situation, as is the situation where we do not have an indication of the boundaries for the metropolitan areas. We have the prospect of a plethora of anomalies and unfair outcomes depending on whether, in the Melbourne context for example, you describe Whittlesea or Werribee or Craigieburn or Kilmore or Seymour or somewhere else as being part of the urban area or part of the rural areas. We regard this as a very unsatisfactory situation. We certainly do not think that what the government has put forward with the support of the Democrats in this appropriation bill No. 2 will address those problems.
Having said that, as I indicated before, we are not proposing to oppose them. We note that there is some $60 million of expenditure for each of the four years in relation to the book industry assistance plan, and some $15 million of expenditure for each of the four years concerning supported accommodation assistance. We also note that the environmental measures are said to involve $214 million of expenditure in the first year, $222 million in the second year, $227 million in the third year and $233 million in the fourth year. On that basis, we will be supporting these measures, but we certainly put the government on notice that we do not think that the measures are adequate to address the adverse effects that its GST package will cause in the area of books, in the area of housing and accommodation and in the area of environment protection. We will be monitoring very closely the impact of this legislation, as well as the impact of the government's GST 
 proposals more broadly, as we proceed towards implementation.

name: Cadman, Alan, MP
text:
—The Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 1) 1999  and the Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 2) 1999  are bills contingent on the introduction of a goods and services tax, a change in the taxation system in Australia. The information contained in the bills is marginal but it is important to the people involved and it has been important to the settling in of the goods and services tax—the new taxation system. These bills are part of the total package and, in part, seek to compensate in some areas where compensation is needed.
The previous speaker spent a lot of his time on the diesel fuel rebate scheme, which is a part of the goods and services tax, but did not really deal with some of the issues in the bill. Rather, he complained about how that diesel fuel rebate system would operate. He also complained about the fact that a goods and services tax might apply to books. The goods and services tax is going to apply to a wide range of things. Applying a tax to consumers as they purchase things will allow the government to provide substantial personal income tax cuts, providing choice and opportunities for people that they have not had before. It is a change in the tax system. I remind the House that this government is running a balanced budget. This government does not need additional taxation. Unlike Labor Party governments, this government has been able to bring its house into order, balance its books and therefore be in a position not to make a claim for additional taxation from Australian taxpayers.
The process that we are going through is one of change. It is one that, in the broad, will provide tax concessions and relief for individuals, particularly for individuals with families. It will provide taxation relief for business processes and the export of Australian goods. It simplifies the taxation system and it gets rid of some unconscionable and stupid taxes. Those are goals worth striving for, and they are goals that this government has achieved. These appropriation bills that we are dealing with today are contingent on 
 the introduction of the goods and services tax and, on the margin, are complementary to it.
What do these bills seek to do? The Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 1) details the way in which two items of expenditure are dealt with. It provides that there should be ongoing assistance not only to the book industry but to readers of books, sellers of books and producers and writers of books. Through this legislation $60 million a year over the next four years—not an insignificant amount of money—will be provided to people involved in the book industry. That $60 million is going to go a long way to supporting the Australian book industry. It is a substantial amount of money. Anybody who is dismissive about $60 million has a pretty peculiar idea of what it is like to earn a living and pay the bills every week. I think it is a very superior attitude, one that is often demonstrated by the Australian Labor Party.
The book industry assistance plan has three main objectives: to provide financial assistance to those producing books; to provide financial assistance to those who are creators of books; and to provide financial assistance to retail sellers of text books in Australia in connection with reducing the retail price of text books for use in studies at Australian education institutions. They are pretty laudable objectives. They are narrow, well assessed and supportive of Australian students and children as well as the creative talent of Australia.
An additional objective relating to this plan is the provision of financial assistance to libraries of Australian primary schools. This is a great program. What could be better than money coming from the federal government to assist primary school libraries? I do not know how many libraries the members opposite go into; I do not know whether they go into libraries. I visit primary schools pretty frequently and I know that the member for Fisher does too. It is very much part of a proper representational role that effective members of the House of Representatives have. We go into these primary schools and look at the school libraries and often we say, `If only there were a little additional money to supplement this splendid collection of 
 books.' There is often no help from the state governments. The money raised by parents is spent on stocking the library. We are doing something about this situation in this legislation.
Another objective of this plan is the collection, compilation and dissemination of statistical information about book production and book sales in Australia. Yes, the industry claims that it has not been able to mount a case for better use of Australian book production because it is not certain of the nature and structure of the industry. This is money well spent. Further, this plan will enable the promotion of the intrinsic value of books and reading.
—Hear, hear!
—Well, it is hardly a `Life. Be In It' program, it is not a `get active and get attractive' sort of program, but it is one that I believe goes to the very core of personal satisfaction and growth. The idea is that the people of Australia should be encouraged—at the same time as having access to some marvellous innovations with the World Wide Web and email, electronic commerce and those sorts of things—to go directly to the creator of interesting ideas and thoughts and read books. I cannot see anything but good sense in it.
The promotion of literacy is an additional objective of the plan. The Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, David Kemp, has done more than any person in Australian history to promote literacy amongst Australian kids. That is a most laudable plan. If you are going to control a population, then take away their capacity to read and write and they will become reliant on broad media presentations churned out by a limited number of media moguls. David Kemp's pursuit of literacy for all has to be encouraged. This literacy promotion plan that the House is dealing with today is a good measure.
The promotion of books of Australian authors, the training of book producers, the support for innovation and infrastructure development in book production and the support of other ancillary or incidental objectives are part of this plan. Sixty million dollars a year will be allocated to this plan. It 
 is a well placed, well thought out four-year plan in support of the Australian book industry. Whilst the Labor Party say they are not opposing this, they are nevertheless complaining about it.
The second measure dealt with in  Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 1) 1999  is the Supported Accommodation Assistance Program. This covers a wide range of programs. I would like to inform the House that over the next four or five years the Commonwealth intends to raise funding from $140.1 million in the current year to $163.3 million in the year 2003-04. In addition to that, about $40 million goes on an annual basis to the states as part of the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement on crisis accommodation. That program must be considered in addition to SAAP that we are currently looking at today.
The additional funding for this program in this appropriation is $15 million a year for four years. This complements the work that has already been done in this area. If any government has done something to help our young people it must be this government. It has introduced the Tough on Drugs and Youth Off the Streets programs. Father Chris Riley and the Salvation Army have been in there doing this work. I know that members of the opposition will complain that not enough is being done. There is never enough being done in these areas. But this government has made honest and sincere attempts to do something and is out there doing this.
We have complementary programs. We see kids as not being in isolation from their families or their society. Kids need support in getting jobs. We have excellent programs to assist kids—whether they started in job clubs and went to the now defined Work for the Dole and Green Corps—which are producing great results. There are literacy programs to make sure that the huge number of young people who are not acquiring jobs because of their lack of literacy skills due to  the changes in literacy standards in the schools get assistance. There is assistance to families through taxation relief to make the people in the households more adequately prepared to look after their kids. Then there are programs to 
 assist young people who fall out with their families and cannot any longer live in the circumstances they wish to or their parents may wish them to.
I will give the House a couple of examples of these programs. Hills Accommodation for Youth, which is run in the Hills district where I live, has been starved of funds until recent years. Gradually through families contributing and appeals a stockpile of three homes has been built up to give support to homeless kids. The first focus of this program is: can we get the kids back into their own homes and do they really have to move out of home? There is negotiation and counselling between parents and children to try to establish a stable and ongoing relationship so that the young people do not find it necessary to move out of home. In some instances, tragically, where there is violence or abuse there is no alternative but for the young people to leave home. They consistently work to restore a relationship so that ultimately they can move back into their homes.
Zanita Johnson and her people at Hills Accommodation for Youth have been doing a magnificent job. They have basically done it with little help. The Commonwealth has helped with some assistance. We have been able to, by persuasion, bring pressure to bear on the state government. This additional money will be welcomed by the people who are dedicated to providing accommodation for youth in this Hills district.
I have had drawn to my attention in the last week a proposal from Mission Australia to establish a youth homelessness pilot program in the Penrith district. That would reach out into my electorate of Mitchell and the Hawkesbury district. The statistics from that area are very concerning. The median age for young people seeking support through this homelessness pilot program is 15 years. Just over one-third are aged less than 15 years. The gender breakdown is 43 per cent male and 57 per cent female. Parents requested assistance in 55 per cent of the cases, including 27 per cent of cases where both the young person and the parent requested assistance together. 
In 85 per cent of the cases contact was made whilst the young person was still at home or within three weeks of leaving home. The early intervention nature of these proposals is really important. That is what the government is building on. That is what the government is doing here with the allocation of this additional $15 million per annum over the next four years. The median support period is four to eight weeks, longer in cases involving both parents and young people. Four to six or eight weeks is the only intervention proposed for the pilot project in Penrith. That will cover much of Western Sydney. The most utilised family relation strategies were counselling, practical support and mediation.
I want to commend that program to the House and say how worthy I think the early intervention and youth homelessness programs are, seen in the context of a government anxious to create jobs, anxious to see good education, anxious to see stability and reasonable resources within families and anxious to see that abusive substances and influences that debilitate the lives of young people are removed and controlled and that a proper education program about them is put in place.
The second bill before the House today, the  Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 2) 1999 , deals with a range of environmental matters. I know my colleague who will be speaking shortly will want to deal with some of those environmental matters—it is an area in which he is expert—but I just want to let the House know the breakdown of this four-year program: total amounts will range from $214 million in the first year to $233 million in the fourth year. I also want to say that, as far as this government is concerned, the program is a diverse approach to environmental problems such as degradation of our atmosphere. The program is being implemented by the government to assist. Money will be appropriated from consolidated revenue for seven environmental initiatives: supporting conversions to compressed natural gas or liquid petroleum for commercial vehicles and buses that have a gross vehicle mass greater than 3.5 tonnes, applicable also to trains and ferries; developing a product 
 stewardship system for the use and recycling of waste oil; supporting the utilisation of photovoltaic systems on residential and community use buildings; supporting the development and commercialisation of renewable energy; supporting the use of renewable energy for remote power generation; supporting the development and implementation of in-service emission testing capabilities for diesel and petrol vehicles where the diesel emission testing is in connection with the making and/or implementation of a national diesel environment protection measure; and a Greenhouse Gas Abatement Program. These are all worthy programs. The provisions of this bill deal with these issues.
Again I say that these are substantial funds contingent on the introduction of the goods and services tax, but worthy in their own right in assisting and supporting a cleaner, greener environment for all Australians.

name: Crosio, Janice, MP
text:
—In speaking this morning on the cognate appropriations debate before the House I would like to begin my comments with a quote:
It is nonsense to suggest that education is GST-free when you are applying a GST to the single most substantial education resource that students should have at their disposal—books.
There is another which says that a tax on books is a tax on `learning, literacy and literature'. And here is one more:
Taxing learning is hardly a path to making Australia a `clever country' as we enter the new millennium.
Whom do we have to thank for all those quotable quotes on the evils of introducing a 10 per cent goods and services tax on books? Why, none other than the very woman who cut the deal with the Prime Minister that would see the Howard-Democrat GST do just that—Senator Meg Lees. The decision of Senator Lees and the majority of the Australian Democrats to do a backflip on levying the GST on books will go down in our country as a dark day for education. I support the thrust of Senator Lees's comments 100 per cent—a GST on books is against learning, literature and literacy. A GST on books will not help us forge a path towards Australia achieving the 
 mantle of a clever country, and no amount of compensation will make up for these facts.
The very act of offering compensation for a tax on books is an admission on behalf of this government and the Democrats that the tax is unfair and that the people suffering from the tax will be worse off. In fact, the compensation measures which this Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 1) 1999  will fund and which we are debating here at this very moment—measures which the Democrats and the government are trumpeting as being the saving grace for the Australian book industry—will just add to the tax compliance nightmare for thousands of people in industry right across this country of ours. Even the Democrats themselves know that the package will not completely make up for the damage that the GST will do to the Australian book industry.
The joint press statement of Senator Lees and Senator Allison on the package, released on 20 August, said it would `largely' cancel out any adverse effects flowing from a GST on books. `Largely' is not 100 per cent, is it? That is not as good as having no GST on books at all. If the compensation package does not completely make up for the damage that the GST on books will do, how much of the damage will it compensate? Will it compensate 40 per cent, 50 per cent, 60 per cent? The Democrats and this government have no answer to this question because they do not know the answer themselves. Later in that same press release Senator Lees had the gall to say that she would have much preferred that books were GST free. I ask you, Mr Deputy Speaker! I believe it is too late for expressions of remorse from any Democrat senator. It certainly will not mean anything to the Australian authors, to the booksellers and to the publishers, et cetera who will pay the price for the broken promises.
Before I take a closer look at the Howard-Democrat deal on compensation for a GST on books, I would like to make some general observations about the effects of taxing books, both on the book industry and on education standards in this country. I am pleased to see we have some young students up in the gallery. A GST on books will handicap the 
 education of many thousands of children and our young students across Australia, including those in my own electorate. Because books are currently wholesale sales tax free, a tax on books will make them dramatically more expensive and will have the effect of discouraging people from purchasing them. A tax on books is a direct threat to the education of our kids. After the GST is introduced and prices rise, books and their contents will be looked on as luxuries. Low income parents in my electorate will be less likely to buy a book to encourage in their children a love of reading, an important part of developing a child's literacy. Students in high schools and in universities will also find they are less able to purchase textbooks because they have become so much more expensive.
Throughout the long and involved debate over the GST, the government has used the argument that a GST or similar has been introduced in many other Western nations and economies and is therefore right for Australia. When making this argument, one fact it neglects to mention is that, of the 19 major industrial nations with which Australia compares itself, 14 have either no tax on books or a tax at a reduced rate. Canada provides us with a very powerful example of the dangers to education and to the book industry of introducing a GST on this sector. When the Canadian government introduced a seven per cent GST on books, education books sales plummeted by 25 per cent. This was followed by a long-term 10 to 20 per cent cut in demand across all book sectors.
This is the news that sends chills of fear up the spine of the Australian book industry. It sends them cold, despite the compensation that the Democrats and this government are now offering. The Australian book industry is already a very competitive marketplace. As we know, more and more consumers are turning to the Internet to purchase their books through web sites such as amazon.com. The fear within the industry is that placing a GST on books will actually encourage thousands more Australians to purchase their books offshore. It will, in essence, have the effect of herding book buyers towards the waiting arms 
 of these web sites and sending thousands of dollars out of Australia.
The Australian book industry knows this. The Democrats know this. Even the Treasurer of this country knows this—and we all know that he gave his own constituents tips on avoiding the GST on books by doing just that: buying through the Internet. This is what Senator Lees said in a press release on 28 September last year:
A tax on Australian made and sold books will simply see an explosion in the number of books bought through the Internet. Australians are reportedly already the third biggest customers of US online bookstores like Amazon.com.
The fears expressed by Senator Lees last year look like they will now become a reality—and all thanks to her very own work. The government could not get this through the Senate but, with the Democrats' assistance, they did.
What else has the Australian book industry had to say about a GST on books? The Australian Society of Authors has made itself very clear on the subject. It has gone on the record with the following comment:
A GST on books is a tax on thinking. We endorse the British and US models where there are no federal GST/VAT taxes on books. Books and associated products like software and CDs—anything that promotes learning, literacy and knowledge—should be zero-rated.
Australian writers are already lowly paid, earning on average only $5,000 per annum from their writing. Any drop in demand for books will be disastrous. Booksellers and publishers will also be seriously affected.
As for the Australian Publishers Association, its position on a GST on books has been clear from the very start:
The APA has enunciated a clear and consistent position against any form of taxation on books for many years. Despite developments in new technologies and increased electronic communications, books steadfastly remain the most effective tools for providing a lifetime of education.
It went on to say in its remarks:
We are disappointed that the Australian Government has not recognised the educational value of books nor their important role in the community and intends to apply a 10 per cent GST to books in Australia.  

What about Bryce Courtenay, one of Australia's most widely published and well-loved authors? What is his opinion of a GST on books? He stated:
Every now and then, governments do something so incredibly stupid, so incredibly inane, so incredibly thoughtless, that it actually amounts to a crime. For a government to come along and say, `I'll tell you what, we'll put a price on the head of a book,' is the most astonishing piece of crass legislation that I've ever heard of. It is just absurd. You can't do anything better than educate a nation, but here we have a government who is committing the kind of crime that is called `dumbing down the people'.
Well said, Mr Bryce Courtenay. Then you have distinguished Australians like the former Chief Justice of the High Court, Sir Anthony Mason. His opinion was also made very clear when he stated:
The tyranny of distance separates us from the main centres of intellectual activity in the world and adds to the price in Australia of books published overseas. The significant depreciation in the value of the Australian dollar is already having a devastating impact upon the capacity of Australians, especially Australian students and libraries, to buy books. And the education sector in this country is faced with an array of problems affecting funding and resources, that is why the impact of the proposed GST on books is so disturbing. The impact on students, not only in relation to books, but also equipment, is harsh.
All of these commentators and observers know what a GST on books really means for learning, education, literacy and the book industry in general. Compensation or no compensation, it is going to be a disaster.
For the book industry, this was chillingly illustrated in an article which appeared in the Melbourne Age in September last year. Written by author Janet McCalman, it bluntly set out, line by line, how the GST will devastate the Australian book industry. Ms McCalman's illustration began with a book being sold for $10 in a shop. Of that, $4 goes to the bookseller, from which all overheads must be paid, leaving them with a profit of around 20c. $2 goes to the distributor, who then must pay for staff, warehousing and transport around the country. The remaining $4 goes to the publisher. $2 of that goes on production costs, being used to pay editors, designers, indexers, typesetters and printers. Of the remaining $2, $1 is passed on to the author in the form of 
 royalty payments while the remaining dollar is used by the publisher to pay such diverse costs as labour, rent, loans, administration, publicity, taxes, charges, insurance and WorkCover.
There is not a lot of fat there. High rollers in the Australian book industry are very few and far between, and profit margins in the good years hover at around two to five per cent. Then add to this equation a 10 per cent GST after 1 July next year. The tax will hit the book industry at almost every level down the chain—from author to retailer. The GST will have to be added to the costs of freelance editors and designers, the typesetter, the proofreader, the indexer, the printer and the binder. Despite compensation, the production cost of the book has to increase as every link in the chain passes on the cost of the tax and its administration to their clients. If they did not, they could not afford to pay it themselves.
According to Ms McCalman, a small publisher might have an annual turnover of $1 million, for example, of which $300,000 is production cost. With a GST, $30,000 will also have to be paid in tax—often far in advance of sales revenue. Publishers in this position will need to add that $30,000 figure to its bank overdraft. The publisher will also have to add into the equation the extra time and labour costs that will eventuate as the company's bookkeeper struggles to get on top of all the extra paperwork the GST will bring to the business.
The end result is that a 10 per cent GST on the book industry will have the effect of driving up the retail cost—not by 10 per cent but by an estimated 15 per cent to 16 per cent, and that is being conservative. The Howard-Democrat compensation deal that was announced on 20 August might soothe a few jangled nerves in the Australian book industry, but everyone in it knows that no level of compensation offered by this government is as good as having no GST on books at all.
The compensation package is in reality one step forward after two steps backward for the industry and for the health and wellbeing of education and learning in this country. Come 1 July 2000, the Australian book industry and 
 educators everywhere will learn this lesson the hard way. The biggest problem with the compensation package is that it compounds the compliance nightmare, the compliance misery, for every participant in the industry.
Those in the book industry will have to grapple with extra new paperwork outlining the new and complex rebate system—a rebate system which neither the government nor the Democrats have even worked out for themselves as yet. Those individuals and organisations in the book industry with their heads screwed on correctly have rightly seen that this package is just a few crumbs from the government's table to help the Democrats save face.
The Australian Booksellers Association makes the point that the compensation package ignores the fact that over 70 per cent of book sales are consumer sales and not school sales. The ABA states:
These books will all be taxed which will lead inevitably to a drop in demand and therefore impact on our businesses. It—
meaning the compensation package—
does virtually nothing for retail sellers of books. Despite the Democrats good intent, booksellers remain unconvinced that the package offsets the impact of a GST on their businesses.
The Australian Society of Authors stated that the educational lending right contained in the compensation package `can never compensate for the effects of a GST on book sales'.
Then you have the small business people, the owners of the bookshops around our nation. These people are the professionals. They are at the coalface and they know how the GST will affect them and their industry. What do they think of the compensation package? `It will be an administrative nightmare in addition to the one already imposed by the GST itself,' says Mr Roger Mackell, the owner of one of Sydney's finest and most popular independent bookshops, Gleebooks in Glebe.
A few weeks ago, a report from the OECD found that the education levels of Australian adults lagged seriously behind those of comparable countries and that those levels would decline further in the future unless something was done to remedy the situation. Placing a 
 10 per cent GST on books is not part of that remedy; it will become part of the problem.
At a time when Australia should be boosting its education standards and preparing the ground for a knowledge based society, at a time when the government should be actively pursuing policies to improve teaching methods and people's access to learning opportunities, it is imposing a 10 per cent tax on books—a move that nearly every other nation in the world with a value added tax has rejected. It will be a handicap to people's education and it will limit their learning opportunities. In the process it will push our already struggling book industry to the edge.
This compensation package to which the budget appropriation is attached might satisfy the government, it might even assuage the guilt of the Australian Democrats, but it will not go far enough in regard to making up for the damage that the GST will do to the book industry and to education in this country.
 This bill before us today is one of many amendment bills that we know are going to have to come before this parliament. It was estimated yesterday—I think in an article in the Financial Review—that over 40 amendments will be forthcoming. As we all know, you can multiply those 40 by hundreds because the government does not have the package right. There are more and more groups around the nation who are going to suffer from some of the GST clauses, when they fully understand and appreciate what the tax is going to mean to them. This is just one of many that this parliament will be debating. This is a deplorable tax. It is a tax that should never have been placed on books and education. I believe that come July 2000 people will understand and appreciate just how badly this government has handled this tax package.

name: Billson, Bruce, MP
text:
—In my speech on the appropriation bills made shortly after the budget, I said that Australians would breathe a sigh of relief when the government's tax reform package finally passed through the Senate, ensuring that Australians would be better off and the country as a whole would be in a better position to meet the world's challenges in the new millennium. As we just heard from the 
 previous speaker, the member for Prospect, the debate that we are facing today has little to do with the specifics of Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 1) 1999  and Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 2) 1999  before the House; it is a distaste for tax reform generally.
But it is tax reform that the nation has embraced—tax reform that the former Labor government tried to implement but did not have the ticker to carry through. Everybody who knows that we need to finance necessary government works and services understands that we need these tax changes. The bills before the House are supplementary measures to the overall package that we have debated before in this place and that I am sure we will hear more about as time pushes on.
Just as our side of politics was arguing that the budget was a product of decisive leadership action and continuing policy innovation, the Labor Party tried the flimsy argument that the budget was not the real budget—the tax reform package was the real budget. Its logic is looking more counterfeit today than ever before. The budget is a product of the hard work, diligence and policy innovation of the coalition, and these bills we are discussing today supplement that effort and help to bring the next phase of Australia's economic renewal to reality by facilitating the smooth introduction of the tax reform package.
These two bills which are being debated together are an essential part of the transition to the new tax system. They appropriate funds for seven important environmental initiatives, the Book Industry Assistance Plan and the Supported Accommodation Assistance Program.  Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 1) 1999  funds the book industry assistance plan and augments the funding of the Supported Accommodation Assistance Program.
The Book Industry Assistance Plan is designed to ensure a smooth transition for Australia's book industry and its authors and young readers to the new tax system. It was interesting listening to the member for Prospect. She made the very simple point that the book industry is already struggling. She then went on to talk about what that struggle 
 represents and the industry's various fears. The amazing irony is that those fears and that struggle exist, regardless of tax reform.
I put it to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the tax reform changes will neither make nor break the book industry. They will not make an unprofitable business profitable. They will not strip away the lifeblood of a profitable enterprise. So, in that respect, it could well be argued that the tax reform package will have a fairly neutral effect on all sectors of the economy. It may make some changes at the margin but, of itself, it will not overcome every fear that every industry may have, nor will it blunt the advantages that industries have. The member for Prospect was very clear in making the point that the book industry has its problems. These problems are unrelated to tax reform. But the terrific thing about the bills before the House today, which include the Book Industry Assistance Plan, is that they tackle the problems the industry already has—those problems that are unrelated to tax reform.
The member for Prospect went on and said that no-one will be able to afford to buy books. What utter, utter nonsense. We know that, as part of the tax reform package, there will be reductions in income tax, there will be a boost in income support, the bottom line being that there will be an increase in the discretionary expenditure in the hands of all Australians. The challenge before the book industry is the same challenge that is before any other sector of the economy: how to get its hands on the available expenditure; how to make sure that it is the one to take more than its fair share of the discretionary income that now will be in the hands of all Australians as a result of the package.
Under the Book Industry Assistance Plan, $60 million will be provided in each of the four years from the year 2000-01 through to the year 2003-04. The Book Industry Assistance Plan has a number of objectives. The first is to provide financial assistance to those producing books in Australia. As the member for Prospect pointed out, those people are having a bit of a tough time of it now. This package will enhance their capacity to com 
 pete, not detract from it. That seems to be lost on the member for Prospect.
Secondly, there is also financial assistance to Australian creators of books. We heard from the member for Prospect about the income that is available for Australian authors—I think, from my recollection, she said around $5,000 a year. Again, here we are talking about a tax reform package that will increase disposable income. It will mean that, of that $5,000 a year, the author will be able to retain more of what they earn. But, above all, it actually is giving a boost to those authors—and I will come back to that point in a moment.
The third objective of the Book Industry Assistance Plan is to assist retailer sellers of textbooks in Australia. Again, this is a point that seemed to be lost on the member for Prospect. The fears in the industry that the member for Prospect spoke about and the `already struggling nature'—as she described it—of the book industry are not the product of tax reform. But these bills before the House, a complementary initiative that goes with tax reform, directly address those issues.
The member for Prospect spoke about Australians being the third biggest customer of Internet book purchases—and that is happening now—and the exchange rate impacts, unrelated to tax reform, being a challenge that the industry is facing. She spoke of thin margins. Again, that is a challenge before the industry, unrelated to the tax reform package, that this group of measures will address. Within the package of the Book Industry Assistance Plan, there is financial assistance to Australian primary school libraries to help them buy Australian books. We are trying to boost demand for the work of the industry and the authors. That goes to the heart of the challenges that the industry is facing, and that is a complementary measure with the tax reform package. But those challenges are not a product of the tax reform. This is the confusion that we get from those opposite.
There is also assistance for the generation and dissemination of statistical information about book production and sales in Australia. There is the promotion of the value of books 
 and reading. Again, that is a demand measure. That is trying to stimulate interest in the product. It is not tax reform. The demand challenge is there today, and this package of measures that accompanies the tax reform will do something about those pre-existing issues confronting the industry. For instance, my little boy Alexander loves books. He loves reading about Hungry Hippo and Sleepy Snail.
—How old is he?
—He is 20 months old. When he has a moment and he sees his dad or mum sitting down, he goes and grabs a book and we read it together. I cannot begin to tell you how pleasing it is that he has such a passion for books. But that is something we as parents have been trying to instil. This measure will complement those sorts of measures where families will recognise the value of spending some time with their children and generate books and reading as a hobby, as a leisure activity, as something that young people do as a matter of choice. This package has measures that complement that.
As an aside, I have been talking with Geoff Masters from the Australian Council for Education Research and Associate Professor Anne Stonehouse from Monash, Victoria about what I might be able to do to help provide useful information to new parents about the constructive things parents can do to help with the development of their kids. Part of that, I believe, will be explaining how parents quite constructively can introduce their children to books. This Book Industry Assistance Plan promotes the value of books and reading. It also promotes books by Australian authors. It also provides training for book producers and support for innovation and infrastructure development in book production.
These are issues that the industry is facing that are unrelated to tax reform, but we have used the opportunity of tax reform to go to the heart of some of the industry's concerns. Some of you would have heard in the media in recent times about new technology where you can actually order a book over the Internet. New printing and production systems mean that you can fire in a text and it will 
 print it for you in a short run. Then you can either collect it or get it mailed to you. That is an enormously significant change in the book industry for authors who might not be able to sell 1,000 or 2,000 books and for book publishers who no longer have to be concerned about overruns where they need to bring those books back to their outfits and write off the cost of such overruns. It removes those barriers.
It means that anybody with a couple of hundred dollars can become an author and publisher and that the risk faced by publishers of aspirant authors, who come to them with work that they are not sure whether will sell, will disappear. That is an enormous change to this industry. It will change the very nature of book production and, in my view, enhance the range of product available to people. They can access it through modern technology and it can be produced in short runs. It will turn the book industry on its head. These are challenges facing the industry—unrelated to tax reform—and this is what the government is seeking to address in the package of measures before the House today.
The member for Prospect went on to talk about the impact of the broader tax reform on the book production industry. As is so often the case when Labor members of parliament talk about tax reform, they just pick out the bits that they think will make it look bad. They just try to cobble together a half story of half facts to back up a pretty dodgy argument to start with. She was talking about how tax compounds on tax compounds on tax. We all know that that is not the way the tax system that we have put to the Australian people operates. We all know that there are input tax credits available. And the member for Prospect said, `Oh, there is no wholesale sales tax on books.' Excuse me! What about the indirect taxes and embedded taxes that start from the moment the timber is harvested to produce the paper? The transport, the equipment being used and, when it moves from that point to a production level, the equipment, the inks and the technology all have taxes in them. But you do not hear any of that. You do not hear about all those embedded taxes—those indirect taxes that are 
 hidden taxes now—that add to the price of the final product. The interesting thing is that no-one on the opposite side has actually talked about what the net bottom line impact is. They are trying not to address themselves to the very real benefits of this tax reform where we are taking taxes—hidden and indirect—out of the production, wholesale, distribution and retailing stages. But you do not hear those opposite talk about those things.
In addition, the bill authorises an additional $15 million for each of the four years starting from 2000-01 through to 2003-04 to deliver assistance to disadvantaged homeless people in crisis or on low incomes. This funding is in addition to the $60 million over the four years starting from 2000-01 that the government has earmarked for SAAP. The signing earlier this month of the Commonwealth-state memorandum of understanding has further boosted this program and shows how determined the coalition government is to getting on with the task of addressing this important area of unmet need.
We understand that homelessness can be a product of domestic violence and that there are issues in people's lives that mean they have to leave their normal place of abode. This initiative that we are talking about today goes directly to the heart of that social challenge. It is additional funding to make sure that those people who are forced to flee from domestic violence—usually women and children—have the opportunity to again find themselves, get some peace into their lives and get their house and their futures back in order. That is a worthwhile initiative.
It also reminds me of my ongoing campaign for 2½ years to address the unmet needs in disability services. One of the glaring areas there relates to accommodation. One of the main reasons for this is that we do not have a retirement structure for people with intellectual disabilities who are either in an employment program or not in a program at all. So you will find many families with a family member or a loved one with an intellectual disability having to take inappropriate accommodation options purely because, as a nation and a federation, governments in this country 
 have not addressed themselves to the issue of how you provide a retirement structure for people with intellectual disabilities, many of whom have an advanced metabolic rate. While they might be 45, they are actually 65 in their body and they are ready to retire. But we insist on having those people subjected to employment programs that are not of their need or liking and, more particularly, we displace those who could benefit from it. So this is an important complementary measure in that respect.
 Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 2) 1999  funds seven environmental initiatives that are part of the revised tax reform package that passed both houses of parliament. You could almost say that the Howard-Anderson government is the cleanest, greenest government that this nation has ever seen. That point can be well backed up by the vast array of environmental, air quality and water quality measures that we have discussed a number of times in this place.
This bill has a number of initiatives, including supporting conversion to natural or liquid petroleum gas for commercial vehicles and buses that have a gross vehicle mass equal to or greater than 3½ tonnes—this is also applicable to trains and ferries—the development of a product stewardship system for the reuse and recycling of waste oil and supporting the utilisation of photovoltaic systems on residential and commercial buildings. It also embraces support for the development and commercialisation of renewable energy, support for the use of renewable energy for remote power generation systems and funding to support the development and implementation of in-service omission testing capabilities for diesel and petrol vehicles where diesel omissions testing is in connection with the making or implementation of the diesel national environment protection measure. Finally, there is further support for the Greenhouse Gas Abatement Program. The amounts that we seek to appropriate today are very substantial: in 2000-01, $214 million to that task—a very significant investment—and $220 million for the following year. In 2000-03, $227 million and in 2003-04, $233 million.
This funding is designed to meet exciting commitments made by the government as a part of the tax reform package. Despite the ill-informed criticism about the environmental impacts of the tax reform package by the Australia Institute, most Australians will see that the environmental effects of the package are one of the best features of it. They are one of the great virtues of this package. Many people do not like change, and most people do not like taxes, but it is fair to say that the vast majority of Australians recognise the need to change Australia's tax system to make it fairer and less reliant on such a narrow, shrinking tax base as the wholesale sales tax system and that change is necessary.
With that change has come some enormous benefits that not only improve our tax system but also address some of the significant environmental concerns that we face as a nation. The environment is a big winner in the tax agreement. This bill boosts Australia's commitment to the long-term health of our environment. In particular, it puts into place concrete steps to improve air quality—the number one concern for most people, particularly in urban areas. It also helps to ensure that Australia meets the enormous challenge of our greenhouse gas reduction commitments. This package restores the price relativities between diesel and alternative fuels and incorporates new vehicle and fuel standards that will lead to substantial reductions in particle emissions, especially in metropolitan and suburban regions such as the one I represent. Particle emissions in cities are estimated to fall from 5.7 gigagrams in 1997 to 4.2 gigagrams by 2015—a 26 per cent reduction in those emissions. That is good news for our cities and for our environment. The renewable energy and transport initiatives, including support for alternative fuels, are estimated by the Australian Greenhouse Office to reduce CO2 emissions by 0.5 million tonnes by 2010. This estimate does not include the additional benefits that would come from greater market penetration of alternative fuels such as compressed natural gas.
I could talk about a great many other measures but, given that time is moving on, I would like to point to something that is 
 overlooked in discussions about alternative fuels. Tamme Klaster, who is a local LPG fitting specialist in my electorate and also Chair of the Victorian Automobile Chamber of Commerce LPG Group, invited me to talk to the VACC group about the impact of the tax reform package on alternative fuels. We worked through the modelling of the tax changes and how the changes would position alternative fuels relative to more standard and more conventional fuels. In my view, issues of price movement, global parity measures and the like will have a far greater impact on these relativities than will the tax reform package.
Most pressing in my mind is the fact that fuel itself has some dilemmas. LPG does not have a mandatory fuel standard. The composition of LPG can vary dramatically from service station to service station and region to region, and that is one of the great issues facing the LPG industry. One of the biggest disadvantages for the LPG industry is that, where you are getting these enormous variations in fuel quality, vehicle performance falls away. You are getting a very high consumption of LPG, which means that you are not getting full value out of the conversion. These are issues the industry needs to face. I have taken them up with the LPG producers, who tell me, `No, they're all pretty consistent.' The evidence does not support that view. On a tank of LPG, you can see up to a 100-kilometre variation in the kilometres travelled. (Time expired)

name: Irwin, Julia, MP
text:
—Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 1) 1999  and the Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 2) 1999  are part of the government's compromise deal with the Democrats to get its new, simple and noexceptions tax on everything through the Senate. The food complications were bad enough. There was certainly nothing simple in all of that. I was not sure whether we were dealing with recipes for bread or disaster, or with the cooking or otherwise of chooks. Anyway, while the Democrats were in the kitchen they were `courageously'—that word was on everyone's lips at the time—forging a new alliance, a coalition indeed, with the 
 very bastards they were pledging to keep honest.
That is the Democrats' mission statement. That is why they have continued to win their single digit percentage support at elections, along with a once held—and, I think, sincerely held—commitment to protecting the environment from the greedy brigade who line up behind the Liberal and National parties. We have poked fun at their vision statement in the past, but at least they had one—fantastic though it was. Where is it today, now that they have married into the government and given issue to bills such as those before us? They have lost their sight. They have let down their own constituency amongst those who give conservation some priority.
Now the Democrats are about to see how many friends they can lose among the booksellers. I know they have the best intentions and, like the Labor Party, were appalled at what the Howard government was proposing. It has always been an article of faith among civilised people that a tax on knowledge should never be entertained. You might as well burn books. That is the symbolism of it. After 500 years, books are still an economical, convenient and compact means of cultural, educational and information exchange. The Democrats recognised that from the start. Books should not be taxed, yet the GST does just that.
Mr Deputy Speaker, you would recall that the Leader of the Democrats and four other Democrats left the chamber when the vote came up. They abstained to give the government the numbers. It was the same as saying, `Yes, we want a tax on books.' That has happened against the background of the knowledge nation, the knowledge based society and the knowledge economy. They should have voted no. It was that simple. Instead, we have this patchy bit of legislation to compensate for the imposition of a tax on books. It is far from simple. From what I can understand—and it is sketchy, because it is still to be worked out—booksellers will charge the GST but will get a subsidy to charge a lower price, cancelling out the GST. This applies only to textbooks for use in studying at an Australian education institution.
I want to know when a book is a textbook. Can a publisher get a cookbook onto a text list at an Australian education institution in order to get the subsidy paid to the retailer? Can a publisher offer inducements to an Australian education institution to have the book listed, but not necessarily read? Why single out textbooks? What about dictionaries, atlases, literature and biographies? What about every other category? They are just as important as textbooks—in the case of a lot of textbooks, more important. That is making the same mistake. You cannot judge what is more important. To do so is a kind of censorship. So the GST does not discriminate. That is the beauty of the concept, but the bookseller, far from having an easy time of it, will now have to collect the GST as well as take on additional paperwork to get his cash back. He does not even get to go in the draw for a trip for two to Canberra to meet the Prime Minister and the Minister for Health and Aged Care. It is just extra unpaid paperwork.
It would still be easier to exempt books from the GST, which, after all, was supposed to spare small business the red tape associated with sales tax. Of course, sales tax does not apply to books because, as a civilised society, we believe there should be no tax on books because of their cultural and educational value. There is no sales tax on textbooks, potboilers, romantic novels, do-it-yourself manuals, embroidery books, trashy books and bibles. There is no tax on books, but now there will be because it is easier and more simple that way. I cannot understand it, and I am sure the Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats and the book buying public cannot understand it.
While administrative efficiency is not being served by this weird arrangement, transport operators can look forward to the diesel credit scheme as a test of what this government means by efficiency and simplicity. The deal itself is astounding. It has astonished even the Democrats' own people that the Democrats would subsidise pollution and seal the deal behind closed doors. The complexity of the zonal system is so great that everybody will be too busy to drive a truck to claim their cash. Estimates vary, but the ratio is some 
 thing in the order of $7 of pollution encouragement for every $1 of cleaning up. It defies logic.
The green measures in the legislation before the House are worth while. They are in line with the Kyoto protocol to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. A normal government would bring these initiatives forward in the course of normal business. I have previously welcomed the government's Living Cities program in respect of compressed natural gas which receives a positive push in this legislation. The plan for CNG under the Living Cities program is to establish a network of publicly accessible CNG refuelling stations to encourage greater use of this cleaner fuel. I speak from the point of view of south-western Sydney, which is a major transport gateway to Sydney, frequently clogged and frequently experiencing higher than acceptable levels of diesel and dirty diesel pollution. We in south-western Sydney are great bus users as well. I would welcome CNG fuelled bus fleets not only as a quality of life issue but as a necessary health protection measure. Given the traffic volume passing through Liverpool, an injection of $75 million into conversions for CNG or LPG is a constructive move.
As I have said, the other components of this bill should arise as general business in the course of responsible government. Their Democrat authors have been selective, although one can detect some government influence in the drafting. I assume the greenhouse gas abatement effort would have been a necessary expenditure at some time, given the requirements of article 2 of the Kyoto agreement, but I have my doubts that solar cells would ever have been on the government's must-do list, despite the fact that our research efforts and our favourable daylight put us to the fore in opening up and exporting this technology.
Waste oil recycling, renewable energy, cleaner electricity and emissions testing are all good green measures. This government, however, has used these sweeteners to dud the Democrats. The Democrats wanted so desperately to be in the game, to be a player in the big city. To do that, they had to want the GST more than John Howard did. That is the 
 view that Sid Spindler, one of the Democrats founders, put at the time. He said:
I can only assume we badly wanted a deal to show that we had arrived in the big time.
The big time it is. They have made it into government, but they made it when they were already there. Their picking an issue like the GST and then negotiating significantly below the real value of their currency still has people in shock. The Democrats have moved from a position of real and independent power to junior partner. If this is the way they handle the environment, we await with interest when the next tax issue, the Ralph review, is finally, eventually and at long last offered to the stressed-out Democrats. I am sure the outcome of that will be equally bizarre.

name: Hollis, Colin, MP
text:
—Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 1) 1999  and Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 2) 1999  are the final pay-off in a sleazy deal to push the passage of the GST. These bills are the final instalment in the debt owed by the Howard government to the Australian Democrats for agreeing to sell out Australians for a 10 per cent new tax on everything.
