What is it that the Democrats used to say about keeping certain people honest? I ask: who in the new coalition into which the Democrats have entered with the government will keep them honest?
The bills seek to appropriate moneys from consolidated revenue for measures relating to book industry assistance and environmental initiatives, as agreed between the government and the Australian Democrats to pass the ANTS package—and a very sleazy deal it has been.  Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 1) 1999  seeks approximately $60 million for each of the four years from the year 2000 to 2004.  Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 2) 1999  is much more expensive, seeking to appropriate nearly $1 billion from consolidated revenue.
We are debating today two proposals which we need not be debating if the Australian Democrats had not sold out and given the government a handshake in introducing the GST. We are debating the appropriation of $60 million over each of the next four years, starting next year, to the book industry. The 
 book industry would not require this additional plundering of consolidated revenue if the Australian Democrats had stuck to their non-negotiable position on the government's GST.
The Australian Democrats went to the 1998 federal election promising that they would be hard and uncompromising on the 10 per cent new unfair tax on everything. They put that sentence in their pamphlets shoved into letterboxes in my electorate during the 1998 election campaign. But, put to the test, they ran a mile and jumped into bed with the government at the very first opportunity.
The Australian Democrats ought to understand that their record of support for the GST will be well understood by people in my region when the next election comes around. They will be held responsible, along with the Howard government, for the confusion and hatred the GST will engender in the community after 1 July 2000. Those who watch international affairs will well remember the fall of the Mulroney conservative Canadian government in 1993 because the people realised that GSTs are unfair, unjust and unacceptable.
Mr Deputy Speaker Hawker, I do not know if you have been to Canada in recent years, but I was there a couple of years ago and talked to the people. There is hatred engendered by the GST they have in Canada. One has only to talk to anyone who lives there to realise why the government that introduced the GST was so soundly defeated. There is also confusion. We are always told that the GST is going to be a simple tax—a simple tax to administer and a simple tax to collect. Let me assure you that the Canadian experience is anything but simple. It is a very confusing as well as a very unfair tax.
The transition to the 10 per cent new tax on everything in Australia will be very interesting to watch. I suspect that we will go the way of Canada, as we have in so many other ways. As the anger and hatred rise in the community against this GST, the Australian Democrats will not escape responsibility for its introduction, because its introduction rests on their heads. The Australian Democrats are linked to the Howard government like paint on a wall.
It is also interesting, in the context of the so-called reforms to industrial relations, that the Australian Democrats are promising tough talk similar to that adopted during the long-running GST debate. Australian workers should be very afraid when the Democrats offer to be tough on any issue. They are as tough as the next blandishment from the Howard government. The next offer for the Democrats to jump into bed with the Howard government is there.
The simple message I give to workers is not to trust the word of toughness in keeping the government honest on industrial relations. The Australian Democrats—always the marshmallow of the Australian political system—have always been appalling on industrial relations. People always come to me and say, `They're good on the environment and they're good on education.' They are good only because they have never had to introduce their policies. They have always been weak on industrial relations. They have always been a party of the business community on industrial relations and have always gone along with the bosses on industrial relations. That has always been their history. The record of the Australian Democrats on industrial relations quite frankly has been appalling.
The Australian Democrats promised a non-negotiable position on the GST and then sat down and negotiated with the government, and the government, of course, as is well known now, rolled them. The Australian Democrats will try to build up the hopes of workers that they will be protected and that their entitlements will not be eroded. In the end, workers will suffer the same fate as those Australians who trusted the Australian Democrats to remain honest and tough on the GST.
The bill to soften the blow on the book industry from the impact of the GST is laughable. Those going into the bookshop to buy their books will still have the GST imposed on them, and they will know that it is the Democrats who are solely responsible for that. The Democrats like to present themselves as enlightened and progressive. In their sleazy deal with the government, they have imposed not only a GST that will rise and cause misery to ordinary Australians but also 
 a tax on learning—this is from the so-called enlightened and progressive party in the Australian parliament, the party that has been responsible for imposing a tax on learning.
Books are not subject to any tax at the moment. Frankly, if you go into any bookshop in Australia today you will find that books are expensive enough. In trying to breathe life into this deal of imposing a new tax on books—on learning—the Australian Democrats have ensured a decline in the purchase of books in Australia, and the government has the hide to talk about literacy standards.
We on this side are aware of the environmental consequences of the GST through the probable increase in the use of diesel fuel and in greenhouse gases. I would like to know how the Democrats, the so-called environmental party, the green party, can explain those increases to their people. There is also a reduction in the economic incentives to use alternative, environmentally friendly fuels and technology. That is what the Democrats have delivered because of their sleazy deal with the government. The Democrats, as I say, have prostituted themselves. If I were not so generous, I would say they have become the harlots of the Australian political system, but I do not want to say that—I will just refer to them as the marshmallows of the Australian political system. The Democrats have prostituted themselves on this issue by getting into coalition with the government.

name: Kelly, De-Anne, MP
text:
—I rise to speak on the Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 1) 1999  and the Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 2) 1999 . These two bills are important as they will provide greater certainty to community and business regarding the commencement date of the GST and the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme.
Bill No. 1 provides $60 million a year over four years for the book industry to assist both writers and book production. This will ensure that all involved in the Australian book industry—from authors to retailers—obtain assistance. Especially important and of great benefit to students, their parents and those interested in education generally is the finan 
 cial assistance that will ensure that the retail price of textbooks for use in studies at Australian education institutes is reduced. This measure has a historic significance beyond its practical effect. It is the final piece of the new tax system to be put into place following the agreement between the government and the Australian Democrats.
Bill No. 1 also provides for $15 million a year over the next four years, beginning in 2000-01, for the Supported Accommodation Assistance Program, otherwise known as SAAP. This is a critically important program which assists people who are homeless, at imminent risk of homelessness or in crisis to achieve the maximum possible degree of self-reliance and independence. It also includes support for women and children fleeing domestic violence. Some 1,200 community welfare organisations are funded through SAAP, with 36 per cent in regional and rural areas. In 1997-98 about 110,000 people were assisted by the program, which is cost shared between the Commonwealth, states and territories.
Bill No. 2 provides a total of $896 million over four years beginning in 2000 for seven major environmental initiatives, including converting large commercial vehicles, ferries and trains to compressed natural gas or liquid petroleum; the development and use of renewable energy; diesel emission testing; and the Greenhouse Gas Abatement Program. The expenditure of nearly $1 billion over four years is a huge investment in a cleaner, safer environment and will be welcomed by all. These measures will not only ultimately mean a better environment but they should reduce our heavy reliance on imported fuel products and thus will mean a cheaper, cleaner fuel in many areas.
There is no denying the importance of the measures funded by these bills, but I wish to make a few comments on an issue of equal importance—that is, the small business sector in regional and rural Australia. Small business is more important to a small regional or rural community than it is to a metropolitan centre. The reason for that obviously is that in most small centres there is one overwhelmingly large business—usually associated with 
 agricultural or mining activity—and the associated processing plant, harvesting or whatever it might be, but the community and the township are always based on the small businesses. It is those businesses that provide an opportunity for work for young people in the community. They form part of the streetscape of the town. Frankly, Mr Deputy Speaker Hawker, being from a rural centre yourself, you would know they are really the heart and the core of those rural and regional communities.
So not only is small business very important in terms of its contribution to the economy and employment—and we need it obviously to be as efficient and productive as large business—but it also plays a critical role in the social fabric of those in rural and regional Australia. I therefore want to turn to the Joint Select Committee on the Retailing Sector, which has tabled its report entitled Fair market or market failure?
It is significant that this report, prepared by members and senators from all political parties, was unanimous. Given the complexity and emotion of the issue, that unanimity is remarkable and gives the report and its recommendations great weight and significance. As I have said, I am a strong and unapologetic advocate for small business and its role in rural and regional communities. Not only is it the core and the heart but it is the engine room of local economic activity, a very important focus for community activities and the community identity, and a critical source of employment, particularly for the young. I have certainly been outspoken on behalf of service station operators in their battles with the big oil companies.
—Well, support my bill.
—I have made submissions to the Queensland government defending, for example, the hotel and pharmacy industries against the ruthless and self-serving expansion of the major chains. I hope that the Beattie government in Queensland is going to pick up on the committee's recommendations. The member for Hunter is here telling us what to do, but I hope he tells Mr Beattie that we do not want to see liquor stores done away with in Queensland and 
 liquor sold through the large chains. It would be a very backward step if the Labor Party in Queensland saw the destruction of country hotels and bottle shops in favour of the large chains. It would send the message that you can go to a supermarket and buy not only bread, milk and so on but liquor as well. In other words, liquor becomes simply part of the household budget. It is not; it is a specialist, luxury product that should be sold out of a specialised centre such as a liquor store. So before you give us advice, please relay our advice to the Premier, Mr Beattie.
Those are two issues in Queensland that are of critical importance to us: we must ensure that small business continues to have a stake in the pharmacy sector and also in the hotel sector. I have to compliment the member for Hunter and also the Joint Select Committee on the Retailing Sector. I notice that they have recommended as well that the pharmaceutical sector continue to remain largely the province of small business. I think that is a very welcome result from that committee.
I certainly sympathise with those who have had a negative reaction to this report. When I first saw the report, I had the feeling you get when you go home and see one of your old cattle dogs: you are glad it still has some teeth, but it does not have the promise it had when it was young and starting off. I thought the report had more teeth than I expected—and I am pleased at that—but I do not think it really fulfilled the potential that was expected when the committee was first assembled.
However, I make the point that the committee quite rightly suggested that the select committee be reconvened again in three years time to ascertain progress in the interim. I think that is a very sound recommendation and will certainly put the large chains on notice that there is going to be a continued monitoring by the parliament of their activities. I certainly hope that the government picks up on the very sound recommendations of that report.
I now turn briefly to the National Association of Retail Grocers who have described the report as disappointing for not recommending a cap on the market share of the major chains. It is equally true, as the committee chair and 
 member for Cook, Mr Baird, acknowledged, that the main chains are not actually out in the street celebrating the report. In fact, the major chains have been equally critical, saying that if the recommendations are accepted by the government there will be added compliance costs, an erosion of shareholders' funds and prolonged regulatory uncertainty—given the recommendation that the whole matter, as I said before, be revisited in three years.
I certainly support the recommendation which puts the major chains on notice to be responsible corporate citizens. Again, the fact that all recommendations were unanimous underlines the determination of all political parties to ensure that the major chains act in the public interest. I also support the establishment of a government funded retail industry ombudsman, a mandatory code of conduct for the industry, and stronger powers for the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission.
I note also that the committee recommended that in ascertaining whether to approve mergers and acquisitions `regional' be added to the definition of market. I think that is a very welcome initiative. Too often the ACCC has had to look at the effect of such a merger or acquisition in the nation, or perhaps in a state, not realising how vibrant some of our regions are and that there can be a fair level of competition across a state but a monopoly situation in one particular region.
What is absolutely fundamental about the report is a process whereby all retailers, whatever their size and ownership, operate on a genuinely level playing field. So many of the factors and influences impacting on the retail industry are outside the power of the Commonwealth. Issues such as wages and conditions, opening hours, zoning laws, workplace health and safety issues and many others need to be considered. These are the responsibility of state, territory and local governments. For example, retail tenancies are a key issue outside the scope of this committee and the Commonwealth. The government is due to respond to the recommendations within three months. I urge the cabinet to endorse this report. While some in small 
 business may not be entirely happy with the outcome from their perspective, it has to be acknowledged that compromise, as well as fairness and justice, is required.
To speak further about small business, as I come from a rural and regional area I can see how there is a knock-on effect if one small business closes, and heaven help us if a larger business closes. It is very important that small business be generally supported. I was disappointed and pleased at the Productivity Commission's report on national competition policy. National competition policy has been somewhat demonised of late. For some it has been the excuse for many of the disappointments that they see in rural and regional areas but that come from a multiplicity of factors, such as a downturn in commodity prices and increased automation in many of the harvesting operations and rural and agricultural operations that take place.
It is also perhaps a convenient scapegoat for those who are unsuccessful in business. But I think it would be equally true to say that there are deficiencies in national competition policy. The Productivity Commission, although they tried to hide it away in their dot point summary, certainly highlighted the fact that the concerns that those in rural and regional Australia have do in fact have a basis. While the Productivity Commission said that there was really only one regional area that had suffered a detriment due to national competition policy and most others had benefited overall, I notice that significantly they made two points. The first is that metropolitan Australia has benefited over country Australia. If you live in a rural or regional area, that is quite evident. The second is that big business has benefited over small business.
I would not pretend that the Productivity Commission is an advocate for rural and regional Australia, but I thought that its observations were absolutely spot on and need to be considered if any further attention is to be given to limiting the scope of national competition policy to impact negatively on small business in rural and regional Australia. However, we certainly do have a champion for small business—that is, the Minister for 
 Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, Mr Reith. He has been a very strong advocate for small businesses and has assisted greatly in the opportunities for employment growth in rural and regional areas.
I have mentioned this before, but it is really heartening to look again at the small area labour market figures for the December quarter of 1998. For my city of Mackay, in December 1997 the unemployment level was 10.9 per cent. In December 1998 that declined to 8.1 per cent. They are very heartening figures. That was repeated generally right across my electorate. Many of the changes that the minister for small business has implemented have really had a very positive effect in rural and regional areas.
—What will the GST do?
—I will tell you one thing that the tax reform package is going to do: it is going to change some of the fuel excise costs we pay that your mob brought on us.
—What will it do for small business?
—Oh, come on! What about the $530,000 for one transport company in my city of Mackay? We are going to be putting money back into the regions which you had taken from for years. I am supportive of the tax reform package and the very positive results we are going to get in small business and farming. For once, we have actually reversed some of the very negative initiatives you have taken.
I would like now to talk generally about the economic outcomes in Australia. We have seen solid employment growth, as I have said, particularly in my own area. It has averaged 1.5 per cent per annum since March 1996—in stark contrast to the results that we were delivered by those opposite. Multifactor productivity has increased at an average of 2.4 per cent, compared to 1.4 per cent under the Labor Party government. Labour productivity for the same period has averaged 3.1 per cent, compared to our predecessor's efforts of 2.3 per cent. Inflation, as of March 1999, was at an historic low of 1.2 per cent, 
 compared to an average of 3.3 per cent across the OECD.
The level of industrial disputes certainly does tell the story. In 1998, for the second successive calendar year, Australia recorded the lowest number of days lost to industrial action since—wait for it—1913. That is an outstanding result. So there have been some very positive outcomes in terms of the ability to support and assist small business. Obviously industrial disputation is a severe setback to those of us trying to harvest cane and run businesses in rural and regional Australia.
Inflation, driving up the costs for the farming sector, has been gnawing at those who try to make a living out of export industries. Commodity prices are set generally by the world market and domestic costs are going up and up. So controlling inflation has been a big plus for those of us who live in rural and regional Australia. I am greatly heartened by the results that have been achieved for small business in rural and regional areas.
There is also a negative story to tell, unfortunately. The downturn in commodity prices is presently plaguing us. For instance, the sugar industry price has fallen from US12.6c per pound down to about 5.4c, although it varies. The coal price has been declining substantially, likewise with beef. The South- East Asian crisis has been impacting negatively on our tourism industry. It is not easy. Revenue for many businesses in rural and regional areas has, sadly, declined. As you would know yourself, Mr Deputy Speaker Hawker, the mighty wool industry has been experiencing many difficulties. The cashflow effects of that in towns are very negative.
So while I am heartened by the employment figures and the efforts made by the government, particularly the minister for small business with regard to businesses in rural and regional areas, we certainly are facing a very difficult time with regard to commodity prices. I commend the government for the efforts that they have made but remind them that, in many cases, the strong growth figures that we see across Australia—heartening as they are—are not always reflected in those rural and regional areas.

name: Hatton, Michael, MP
text:
—The cognate debate on the Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 1) 1999  and the Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 2) 1999  deals with a series of matters, including those relating to the environment and transport issues. It is particularly to transport but also correlatively to environmental matters that I want to direct my comments today.
Federal governments have responsibilities over a wide range of areas. In this cavernous chamber we hear most of those areas canvassed in debate. Outside here, in the cabinet room, key decisions by the executive have been made and will be made and need to be made on a range of issues. With respect to the transport and environmental issues impacting on Sydney and potentially impacting on regional New South Wales and running through to having an interstate impact, those issues which are currently before cabinet and have been before cabinet for a long period of time now need to be dealt with in a speedy fashion but thus far have not been.
The cabinet has had before it the environmental impact statement on the second Sydney airport for some considerable time. As I pointed out in last week's debates, the cabinet has had ample opportunity, as has the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, Mr John Anderson, to look at that document and to look at its conclusions. There are no recommendations, simply conclusions which are clear and compelling. There is virtually nothing of an environmental nature against building a second Sydney airport. The conclusion of that environmental impact statement is that it should be at Badgerys Creek, a site which was set aside after the 1985 EIS, a site on which $160 million of Commonwealth money has been expended to buy an ample site for—in terms of what Labor proposed previously—what is now called option A.
This federal cabinet has had at least one full day on this issue. The delay in making a decision has simply allowed a plethora of vested interest groups to hit the airwaves and the newspapers of this country and to argue their particular case for their solution to what should be done. The federal government 
 makes appropriations. They made appropriations for $12 million to fund the environmental impact statement. It was delayed because of the inclusion of Holsworthy for a period of over six months, going down a blind alley. We now have a very full document covering virtually all of the matters that federal cabinet needs to take into account.
The delay is not just occasioned by the federal cabinet wanting to look more deeply into those documents or into other related documents. The delay is occasioned by a direct split within the cabinet about what should be done on this major infrastructure and transport problem. We understand from reports—and the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Dr Kemp, who is at the table, would have a particularly good notion of what was actually happening, although he is not able to tell us at this point—that they are very split on the matter.
What seems to be emerging is that one of the reasons for the extended delay is a proposal put up in the public arena, and initially floated by the Minister for Finance and Administration who has responsibility for these appropriation bills, on the basis of his own vested interests as the member for Macarthur, that Badgerys Creek was too hard, there would be too much impact on Liberal seats, including his—as it was then constructed prior to the redistribution processes being set in train—and the easiest thing to do was to dump as many aircraft as possible on Bankstown airport, in the electorate of Blaxland, my seat, and let the problem go away somehow.
He has aided, abetted and encouraged all of those groups who want to find a solution that does not entail making a definitive decision about that site which the EIS reported on. He has aided and abetted all of those groups who want to put this off for another 10 or 15 years and who want to see the second airport outside the Sydney basin. He has apparently, in conjunction with the other members of this cabal, Peter Costello, and some other Victorian and South Australian ministers, allowed the space to be created. He has allowed the situation to arise where an entirely different 
 approach from what was looked at in the EIS is now being suggested.
The situation at Bankstown airport with regard to regional traffic is fairly simple. It has been looked at previously. We are dealing with an airport that employs more than 3,500 people. That is a significant number of people in my electorate drawing their weekly wages from the economic activity of that airport. We are dealing with a piece of infrastructure that was important in World War II, when it was established, that allowed integrated industries to be built up around it and that has continually changed and modified within the context of being a general aviation airport for Sydney—and the most significant one in the Southern Hemisphere. We have an integrated, well working structure that the people of Bankstown by and large support.
They support it because of its employment effects and because of the amount of money brought into the area. They support it, and have done so recently very strongly during my by-election and the last election, because they know that when this federal government came to power they ripped more than 400 jobs out of Bankstown by moving people out of the Bankstown Taxation Office—and they would move the other 220 if they could. They know that the ballast that was there from the Taxation Office, some of the few federal government jobs we had there, has been taken away by this federal cabinet.
They know that a move to move regional aircraft to Bankstown would inevitably displace the general aviation activity there either quickly or over an extended period of time. It would be entirely disruptive. It would knock the businesses and knock the people who are working there and dramatically change their circumstances and put a giant question mark over the future of those jobs.
The simple proposition that just because 99 per cent of the current regional aircraft flying into Kingsford Smith can technically fly into Bankstown, and do when the weather is bad, and that we should simply lift those up and shift them to Bankstown and make it a regional airport fails on a number of tests. It fails on a number of tests when you are looking at how well you should integrate 
 infrastructure that this federal government has appropriated moneys for in the past and will have to do so in the future.
Where there would be an opportunity to open up 25 to 38 per cent of slots at Kingsford Smith airport for bigger jets, 737s and up to jumbos, where that airport would earn more money because every one of those jets landing would bring in more money, the people in regional New South Wales using the regional air services would not have an easy intermodal experience. They would not be able to fly into Kingsford Smith then on-fly to Melbourne, Brisbane or Canberra or go into the city or elsewhere where they have to do their business. They are being told that they would be treated as a group set apart.
There is much more to this proposition than that inevitably you would move general aviation out of Bankstown and move all those jobs. One simply has to look at the current situation with regional airlines, and the fact that at Kingsford Smith the Sydney Airport Corporation would like to jack up their charges and attempt to shift them out, to see that this government could, through the Minister for Finance and Administration, say, `It would be a pretty good idea given all those sorts of pressures to actually go to Bankstown and then we will look after you. We will break our promise to give you guaranteed access to Kingsford Smith under the long-term operating plan, but we will guarantee you absolutely that you can use Bankstown and use that forever.'
The reality is that cost pressures on regional aircraft and regional aircraft services will continue. We already know that Hazelton Airlines are thinking of moving their operations to Newcastle. What would happen if this proposal went through and general aviation was pushed out to Badgerys Creek, therefore denying the opportunity for 10 or 15 years? What is behind this proposal ensures that this federal government would not have to spend one zack on actually building a second Sydney airport and that they would allow Kingsford Smith airport to expand exponentially into the future. That is what this is about. It is the do nothing option that drills and bombards all of the people of Sydney 
 because they would allow the total extension of Kingsford Smith airport. It is the direct implication, inference and outcome of such a measure.
What would happen to those regional services moved to Bankstown? If they maintained the current structure of the airport and the Dash 8s, the SAABs, the BAe146s—that weigh 44 tonnes and can take up to 70 passengers—were based in Bankstown as well as the displaced general aviation, what would happen to them in the future? Would the regional airlines continue to come into the Bankstown airport when they found their customers did not want to get on to the M5? It was promised it would be 25 minutes to KSA. That is a laughable, stupid, ridiculous, impractical promise because anyone using the current M5 knows that it is not up to scratch, knows that it will not be able to get people from Bankstown to KSA and then go from there to the city in an extended fashion if they chose to go that way. It will not be a quick intermodal link. It is choked now and will be choked in the future.
When they get problems from the people who want to use those services, they will also be under another set of pressures. The other set of pressures are the ones that will inevitably come in the future when demand from their passengers—that they really wanted to go into KSA—will move these regional airlines to look, as Hazelton is, at using regional hubs.
It takes one transport minister in this country and the airlines to determine that they would be better served by creating a regional hub at Newcastle for northern flights to run into Newcastle to say: `You can have regional development at that airport and you can have the growth and the business that was otherwise not there because all those aircraft would come into Newcastle. And then we'll run jets straight into KSA and you can have immediate access—there's nothing to stop it.' There is also nothing stopping a west and south-west regional hub, for instance, just beyond the Blue Mountains.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I am reluctant to interrupt my friend, but we are dealing with a cognate 
 debate in relation to two appropriation bills. I fail to see the connection between the wide-ranging comments being made by the honourable member for Blaxland and the subject matter of the two bills currently before the chair.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, on the point of order, it has been past practice in this place when we are dealing with appropriation bills, including those that deal with supplementary measures, for there to be a very wide-ranging debate. We are dealing here with transport issues and those relating to the environment. I would put to you that I am entirely in order and that it is appropriate to speak to these matters relative to these bills, based on past practice.
—I would say to the honourable member for Blaxland that while it is true this has been a fairly wide-ranging debate these two appropriation bills are supplementary measures, they are not actually full appropriation bills. I think it probably would help the debate if you tried to keep more to the specifics of these two bills, only one of which is about environmental matters and transport.
—And environmental impacts and our problems with greenhouse gases. The greenhouse gas program—which directly relates to this bill—has a series of measures to encourage all of those people using public or private transport to change the way in which they do things in order to cut down the impact of greenhouse gases. Those services—the very fast trains, the high-speed trains—that have been proposed for the Sydney to Canberra route and the trains that are now being proposed for services from Melbourne to Sydney and Brisbane as a replacement for a second Sydney airport, how those services would use energy; how they would impact on greenhouse gases; how they would impact on the use of diesel and how they would impact on the diesel fuel rebate and all of those things directly relate to these measures.
It is a question of what the Commonwealth will do or will not do in relation to decisions they should take on major infrastructure projects and the directly related energy conse 
 quences of those projects, the direct implication of greenhouse gases and the direct implication of road, rail or air usage as a result of the measures encapsulated in this bill. This cabinet made a decision to expend these funds in relation to these appropriation bills; it has yet to make decisions about appropriations in the future because it has not made a decision about the second Sydney airport. But that will impact on Bankstown, as these measures will impact on Bankstown and Bankstown airport.
The direct result of moving to use energy and transport services differently by hubbing out to those areas would be that regional air services would, over time, desert our airport at Bankstown. And in deserting the airport at Bankstown—where we currently have 3,500 jobs—the transposition of regional services there could, in the end, see the employment that we have in Bankstown entirely denuded. It would be ripped out because the decision that is currently before the cabinet has gone completely awry. It has gone completely awry because, in terms of the environmental questions raised by these appropriation bills—how we utilise energy and how we can better do that in order to ameliorate the effects of greenhouse gases—one of the things that has been put forward, based on what is here in this environmental impact statement which deals with these very issues, is that there should be a very high-speed train as a replacement for that airport; that the infrastructure demands of Sydney could be served by that. The environmental impact statement clearly looks at the potential for that.
I must say that with all of the problems that both Europe and North America have with greenhouse gases, when people in Europe looked at very fast trains, transport usage and the conjunction between rail, road and air usage they made a quick decision. In Europe the very high-speed train system is used as a substitute for air travel. What is being proposed here is that a very fast train running from Melbourne to Sydney to Brisbane could entirely substitute for a second international airport and have different effects on the environment. The effects of airport noise on the environment are very well covered by this 
 environmental impact statement; the ones in relation to a very fast train are not. The impact on energy usage, the impact of greenhouse gases—all of those things in regard to this train—are not set out, and yet people pop it up and say, `This is an easy solution to the situation.' Europe is a lot smaller in terms of the landmass served by those trains than is Australia.
People who need to do business in both Melbourne and Sydney on any one day are faced with a choice of transport. They have the choice of a 1½-hour flight to Melbourne in the morning to do their business. They finish at 5 o'clock or 6 o'clock and then fly back to Sydney. Even with all the delays that we have had in the past, I think people would choose that rather than choose to take a very fast train, a high-speed train, which would take four hours at best to travel from Sydney to Melbourne. Using a very fast train, it would cost people four hours in the morning and four hours at night just to do one day's business. When people in Europe look at which mode of transport to undertake, they determine the mode of transport according to their needs and according to what they can do within a business day. It is lunacy—whether it is on environmental grounds, on the grounds of efficient use of our transport or on the grounds of efficient use of our fuels and creating a situation where the greenhouse impact would be ameliorated—for people to think that you can entirely substitute a slower form of transport.
There is one minister in this government who is very supportive of the Maglev train, the German one which has not yet got a service in practice. This government chose the Speedrail one. It also appropriated moneys for the proving-up of that process. Now we see that the extension of that should run. In last Saturday's paper, Malcolm Farr reports:
Speedrail has a $3.7 billion privately funded project to run a fast train, travelling at up to 320km/h, between Sydney and Canberra by 2004.
It proposes extending the services along the east coast from Melbourne to Brisbane.
Because of the scale of the project the Government would have to help, possibly through tax relief rather than direct cash contributions. 

All of this is related to how the government makes decisions and what it determines the infrastructure needs of Australia to be. We do not need a proposal that just will not work as a substitute for an international airport and for a government that is afraid to make a decision about Badgerys Creek but is, seemingly, not afraid of looking at imposing all of the regional services on Bankstown and crushing the existing Bankstown airport. (Time expired)

name: Morris, Allan, MP
text:
—The Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 1) 1999  and Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 2) 1999  in themselves seem innocuous enough and straightforward but in fact, on consideration, they are about a $1 billion seduction. I particularly refer to the second reading speech where the words are identical on both bills:
The funding proposed in this bill meets these environmental commitments—
and these are the words that are common—
of the government to the Australian Democrats in the context of our tax reform package.
We are talking here about $1 billion of tax revenue being appropriated and spent. Mind you, it may not be spent. It might be appropriated, but lots of this money may never get spent. When one looks at the amendments and the complications of it, it is a bit hard to be sure just what will happen to the funds—if anything.
For example, for 2000-01 in appropriation measure No. 2, $66 million is to be appropriated over each year for four years, supporting the use of renewable energy for remote power generation. Well, it is a bit hard to know where, when, how or if it will actually happen. I would not be at all surprised if we suddenly discovered each year that there were not enough projects to actually put these funds into. That would not be the government's or the Democrats' fault, but somehow things would not be there. How these numbers have been chosen is a bit of a black art of backroom deal making, and it is all about salvaging the Democrats' reputation and standing.
When the government said it would spend $1 billion of taxpayers' money because of its commitments to the Democrats in the contents 
 of the tax reform package, this was a bribe about the GST, to get the Democrats into the cart. But, looking at the bribe, you start thinking that it is so complicated and confused and confusing that there is a very high chance that it will never be paid. The example I mentioned was just one of those examples, but it does give us a very ready indicator as to what lies ahead.
We are now seeing, day after day and week after week, more deals and more pay-offs. We know that there is always negotiation in politics—it is supposedly the art of the possible and so on—but it has never been so blatant, so expensive or so deceptive. The implication in all this is that these things are all somehow negotiated and worked out, and it is very obvious that they are not. The second reading speech of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration was half a page on each appropriation measure, so he has spent $1 billion in less than a page.
If these things were done well, why isn't there a policy statement? Why isn't it expanded and spelt out just how the money is going to be used? All we have got is a series of dot points. This is the quickest spent billion I have seen in a long time. The amounts are appropriated quite carefully: $20 million here, $4 million there and $10 million there, and yet no indication of where and how—just the numbers in columns. I wonder how they are going to appropriate for, for example, the very fast train. Will we see a deal coming up in the next year or two where the government puts money into a very fast train to buy the Democrats' vote on who knows what—on reconciliation or on cuts to education?
We have got it here. We see in the book appropriations the pay-off for the Democrats to break their own policy on the GST on books. We see a pay-off there which the book industry clearly does not support and does not accept as being adequate.
—It came cheap.
—It came very cheap, because it may never get spent. It is so caught up in complications and provisions that most of it will very likely never be spent. Yet the Democrats went to the election with 
 a promise of no GST on books and no tax on knowledge—for which they had widespread support as a very principled and moral position, and one that I very much agree with and accept as being fairly important. To switch across to what we have got here now is a very shoddy and sleazy little exercise.
One would have expected that the government, in spelling out the promotion of it, would have actually spelt out how it is going to happen. They have some wonderful objectives. All of these carefully phrased half-pages of dot points, about objectives and promotion of the intrinsic value of books and reading, is wonderful stuff. But the fact is that they are going to tax them. That is what it is about. This is about taxing books.
What kind of hypocrisy, double standards, smokescreens and mirrors and magic tricks are we playing at here? If it was so well thought out, why aren't we told? This was done within a very short time behind closed doors by some skilful Treasury negotiators and PM&C bureaucrats and some very naive, innocent Democrat politicians who really wanted to be in the cart and wanted to run the country and have the significance of being in charge of things and yet still meet their promises. This was the snow job that was done; this was the $1 billion seduction bribe that we will watch played out month after month.
I am really interested to know how the Democrats are going to support it on the VFT. We are almost certainly going to see from this government substantial tax concessions and tax bribes in that particular area, which the Democrats will probably put forward as reduced diesel expenditure. Having got the diesel fuel rebate going ahead now and having reduced the price of diesel, we will probably see the Democrats finding a way to tie that into the VFT proposal. Who knows, it may reduce GST expenditure for some sections of the community, but make no mistake about it: this government and our friends in the Democrats will find a way to sugar coat some of the nastiest measures that we have seen in many years.
Appropriation bills are about spending money. The amount of $1 billion being spent 
 here will not be available somewhere else. That is really the nub of the issue. If we take the book industry as an example, it is hard to equate what the GST on books will be because most of the figures from government projections that I have seen have been flaky and faulty. I do not trust the projections on the various levels of tax raising.
The Democrats are giving the GST revenue on books to the state governments and then improvising some measures in here somewhere and somehow that are supposed to compensate the industry. But the fact is you cannot compensate for making books more expensive. Giving some nice objectives on the training of book producers, the promotion of literacy and so on does not make books cheaper. They are still going to be made dearer.
Let us look at some examples that we have had in recent times of the government's reliability in this area of what things will cost extra. We all remember late last year the Prime Minister saying that funerals will cost only four per cent extra. So, for anybody buying a contract for funerals beyond 2000, the extra cost should be only about four per cent. I have now talked to many funeral directors, the associations and a range of other people, and the only thing we could find that would reduce the cost of a funeral would be the service if it is conducted by a clergyman, not if it is done by a non-clergyman. Out of an average $3,000 funeral cost we found that $150 would be exempt from a GST. That is 0.5 per cent of the cost. The tax being paid right now by people in Australia on funerals is in fact 10 per cent extra—not the four per cent that the Prime Minister said back in December but 10 per cent.
When you look at the projections that this government has made on inflation, on the impact of the GST, on the revenue raised and so on, most of them to me look to be flaky and faulty. That view is being reinforced almost daily by people coming forward and explaining how their business will be affected and what the likely cost impacts will be.
We have had this wonderful denouement in recent times about the difference between profit percentage and profit dollars. The 
 government suddenly realised—when they talked about profiteering and the effect of a GST on small business—that if you reduce the gross profit dollars, which you would do by shifting the sales tax and switching the collection point and rate, you will reduce the gross profit in dollar terms for small business. This would mean that unless small business could increase their profit margin—and hence `profiteered' in the government terms—they would go broke. The government woke up to this only very recently.
We saw that wonderful denouement where—shock, horror!—that was not what was intended and profiteering was not really about increasing margins at all. The government recognised that they had misled people for the previous year and a half on one of the most fundamental, simple aspects of business—gross profit and gross margin. We all knew that in this House because this issue was debated thoroughly back in 1992 and 1993. There was not a member of the House who was not aware of that. But the government allowed and promulgated the fallacy and the fiction that there would not be profiteering and that prices would go down because the government would make sure that business did not take any extra margin from those tax reductions that were supposed to be met.
We had the same situation last December when the Prime Minister, in a sense, harassed the funeral directors by saying that funeral costs would go up by four per cent with the GST, not 10 per cent. The fact is he was wrong then and he is wrong now. People right now are paying and have paid in recent times 10 per cent extra for funeral contracts in advance. That is an inescapable fact.
 If the government can show the House and the funeral directors of Australia how they got the four per cent figure, then we would all be amazed. As I said, from my investigations and discussions, we cannot find anything that would be reduced through the removal of other taxes other than if a minister or a clergyman conducts the service. It appears that even the medical certificate that is required for a funeral is taxable because it is not strictly a health service. So, of the $3,000 cost that I have gone through and examined 
 item by item with funeral directors and with the associations, the only one we could find that would definitely be reduced would be the funeral service.
What we are seeing here is a cobbling together of $1 billion worth of PR—and `PR' in that context would actually mean promised responses—from the Democrats in an attempt to try to pretend that they did not break their word, which they clearly have. There is a GST going on books. That is clearly a breach of promise. No amount of cant or cobbling together of promotional literacy on the value of books and of reading is going to deny that. The Democrats have now gone down in history in the most tawdry way. For a party that for all those years insisted on full public debate, full exposure, full examination and so on, to allow this to happen is an absolute travesty of the arguments over all of their life.
The Democrats have turned their whole history on its head because they no longer require accountability and full exposure. We no longer know the terms and conditions that underpin this. Clearly, behind this legislation, there are some other deals. How do we know what will happen, for example, if the money is not spent? Surely the Democrats have made a deal with the government that, if these estimates are wrong, other things will be done to make sure that the money is spent. What else is behind this? What other conditions are there? What other agreements have been made? Surely, the Democrats could not have agreed to things on such a flimsy, shallow basis. One imagines that behind this legislation, which is the tip of a very big iceberg, there is a raft of frameworks and agreements that will come into play if these estimates do not stack up.
I think it is time for the Democrats to come clean and tell the community at large, particularly the parliament, just what in the hell is going on, what they have agreed to and what they have sold out for—because it certainly cannot be for the things we are seeing here. Of course, there is that wonderful contradiction of theirs about the diesel fuel rebate, and so on, which has brought such horror to so many Democrat supporters in the environmental movement. Clearly, without doubt and 
 absolutely, the GST legislation and the diesel fuel rebate will increase the consumption of diesel. At the moment we do not know by how much—and, again, I would be very wary of government estimates. But what do they have in place to cope with it if it goes up by more than expected? What will the government do if in fact it has these conclusions from the Democrats with false or faulty projections? I expect that the Democrats do have things in place and I would be grateful if they would let the community know just what protection they have put in.
The $1 billion that will not be available to the community or to Australian taxpayers because of this legislation is an important $1 billion. For example, it could have helped in the health bill. It could have helped in a range of other areas where we have had cuts. I hear the Treasurer boasting about the surplus—and he calls it his surplus. We know whose surplus it is. It is the surplus of the pensioners who cannot get access to dental care. It is the surplus of the people who cannot get into hospitals because of the massive cuts, the huge cuts that have been made over four years, commencing from the 1996 budget, to the state health systems. It is the surplus of the universities who have had their grants cut. It is the surplus of the child carers who have had their funding cut.
Across the country, the poor and the disadvantaged have had their funds and resources cut to help produce a surplus. That is who the surplus belongs to. What is happening here? That surplus is being given away by the government to others to pay off the Democrats. The unabashed fraudulence of this whole exercise is mind boggling.
We had the government defending itself in 1996 as to why its cuts were so essential and why they were in the national interest. We now have the Treasurer boasting about how he will give away tax cuts in the years ahead because a surplus is there. In other words, having taken it off people, it now becomes his to mete out as he wishes. If there is a surplus because of cuts from which people have suffered, surely the people who have paid for the surplus should get some of it back. Surely this government is not about transferring 
 resources from the health system into tax cuts which obviously advantage the more highly paid.
From my observations of this whole tax mix, GST switch and so on, I understand from accountants that an average parliamentarian's taxes will probably decrease by something like $4,000 a year. If I am $4,000 a year better off, who is paying for it? It cannot be true that we could all enjoy that level of benefit or that we even should. So if 224 parliamentarians are at least $4,000 a year better off—because I gather that ministers will benefit even more than that—what poor sods are paying for that? Surely, it is their surplus. How come it is ours? How come the surplus belongs to the more highly paid?
The surplus has been taken off the lowly paid. It has been taken off the pensioner who cannot get dental work done. It has been taken off all the people in the areas that we know are being squeezed, whether that be a HACC program or a nursing home program—$½ billion for nursing homes was cut in 1996 and $80 million was cut from HACC. This surplus has been produced by all those cuts that this government has put in place. We are watching $1 billion of it being flicked away without debate, without discussion, without explanation, with ministers giving half-page speeches to the parliament.
In any other country, the spending of almost one per cent of our national budget in such a flimsy, shallow way with so little explanation would be a scandal. We know that we have gone through massive shifts of funding away from areas of disadvantage, and we are not even being given the courtesy of a decent explanation as to why this shift of money has been so essential. All that we are seeing at the end of it is: this meets the commitment of the government to the Democrats in the context of a tax reform package. This was the bribe, this was part of the seduction—and they sold out cheap; they sold out real cheap. As I said earlier, I believe that in the time ahead we will see a lot of this money not being spent anyhow. In many cases, it is basically window-dressing. 
Yet the areas of real need that are deprived of funds, that are desperate for money, are being turned away. We all know about such circumstances. Week after week constituents are coming to us with difficulties. I know of 2,000 people who will lose their jobs in three weeks time. Those people will not be entitled to any income support until they have worked out all of their entitlements, including long service leave, any leave they did not take or were not able to take and holiday leave which they did not take advantage of and have therefore postponed and put off. They have to work out all of that before getting any income support from this government. That was a change. That was part of this surplus. That was part of the cuts.
 Those 2,000 people are direct employees of BHP. There probably are another 2,000 or 3,000 people outside of BHP who will be as equally worse off, who will have the same problem. That is how this government has achieved the surplus we are talking about. This $1 billion might have gone some way towards helping those people feel that they are part of our society, that they are entitled to some level of support. It is really nice that we have taken their money and given it to people on high incomes. As I have said, using parliamentarians as an example, a yardstick, if we are $4,000 a year better off, who on earth is paying for it? These bills are a scandal.

name: O'Keefe, Neil, MP
text:
—I will address my remarks particularly to Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 2), which incorporates some aspects of funding for environmental issues. But, before doing so, I would simply endorse the comments of my colleague the member for Newcastle. He has probed very assiduously the weaknesses that are quite apparent in the impact of the GST legislation and the deal that has been done with the Democrats.
I have two reasons for focusing particularly on the environmental aspects in my speech. One is to point to the fact that I believe the world now is starting to close in on the Australian government in response to the pathetic position it took at the Kyoto conference two years ago. Australia is now suffering 
 appalling after-effects in world assessment and is being focused upon with a flowthrough of requirements.
Secondly, I want to put into context the appropriation in this bill. It represents, I suppose, almost picture-framing funding to appease the Democrats on some transport funding measures to try to offset the just criticism that comes from granting the transport industry a concession in diesel fuel prices with the obvious greenhouse impact that that is going to have. Thirdly, I would like to put that into context with a matter occurring in my own electorate at the moment relating to the forest issues that have to be resolved and that tie into this whole environmental approach.
 Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 2) 1999  provides funding for a number of measures which I absolutely support, such as encouraging conversion to natural gas and LPG for commercial vehicles, particularly the larger vehicles, a stewardship system for the reuse and recycling of waste oil, the utilisation of photovoltaic systems on residential and community reuse buildings—in other words, the development and commercialisation of renewable energy and the use of renewable energy for remote power generation—more work on testing in-service omissions for diesel vehicles and providing for a Greenhouse Gas Abatement Program.
Of course, the Australian government was at some point going to have to provide more funding for these sorts of activities. When the government came to office in 1996, it decided that the smartest action it could take was to slash all the Labor government programs and eventually come to the question of putting back those that had to be put back. Here we have a whole raft of such programs—programs that were in existence in one form or another and that, as part of the deal with the Democrats, are now being refunded and expanded. All that has happened really is that Australia has suffered a four-year fall-back in its work on alternatives to the normal fossil fuel energy consumption. There was, of course, the huge battle at Kyoto to try to get the world to accept that Australia might just stay a coal producing, mining, woodchipping 
 and forest nation while the rest of the world focused on genuine greenhouse gas emission cutbacks. That approach failed at Kyoto—the world made it very clear that they were going to impose some disciplines on Australia—so  there have to be some measures such as these to start encouraging the shift away from fossil fuel energy use.
I absolutely support the funding of those programs. I just make the point that the government has been dragged into the cart very reluctantly. It has been dragged, kicking and screaming, into making these sorts of funding concessions. In saying that this has been a trade-off, I want to place on the record an observation that I think is pretty significant, and that is that the Worldwatch Institute has prepared a state of the world report on progress towards sustainability and, in that report, the institute views the cutting of fuel taxes in Australia with considerable alarm. Of course it would. We know that the modelling provided to the government predicts that there is going to be an increase of 60 per cent in greenhouse gas emissions from the commercial transport sector in Australia between 1997 and 2015. In other words, bringing in a diesel fuel pricing scheme that encourages even more use of diesel fuel cuts against the whole concept of Australia's international obligations and sensible environmental management. These measures are very important. I hope they are ultimately successful and that the government does get serious about encouraging the shift to alternative uses.
That brings me to the matter that I really wanted to touch upon today which is very local to me—and it is an important time for some decision making locally—and that is how this all fits into the context of forest policy and the management of forests. It is all very well to try to deal with motor vehicle omissions, but this has to be in the context of Australia's continuing obsession with cutting down forests and exporting woodchips and the steps that we are going to have to take to continue to balance this up. In central Victoria, which is at the heart of my electorate, the RFA process is under way at the moment, and it is not going very successfully for the government. The Central Highlands RFA— 
 which I might say was set in train four years ago by the former Labor government—has stalled because the Minister for Forestry and Conservation, Mr Tuckey, has come to the same conclusion that we have all reached over the years, and that is that you simply cannot trust the information provided to Canberra by the Victorian state government about the management of the Wombat and Cobaw forests. That is quite an extraordinary position to find ourselves in—the fact that you simply cannot trust the information coming from the Victorian government. On the basis of that, the federal minister has now appointed an independent environmental assessor to look at the process.
We are moving into a Victorian state election in three weeks time. There is now emerging a very strong demand from the community to know the future of this forest and how it fits the National Greenhouse Emissions Strategy. In a normal RFA process where you can trust the information, the key criterion is that the state and federal governments can come to an agreement about the forest being well managed on a sustainable basis. That means that the timber allocated to the timber industry is in sustainable volumes, that the residue from that timber that is not suitable for value adding manufacturing is used in an appropriate way and that the environmental management strategy of the forest is consistent with a sustainable, long-term policy. In this particular forest area, we also have some significant water values because it is a catchment area for a significant amount of water both for the Murray Valley and for the south, for Geelong and Melbourne.
The second component in all of this is that whatever policies you adopt need to encourage the industry to invest in significant and upgraded value adding and in research and development. We have always accepted that as part of an RFA process you would be giving the industry long-term security of access to quality timber. It also requires that you recognise the environmental values and the local perspectives and that if you are going to close down the forest, because the use of timber in the area changes or the 
 community perception of the forest changes, the industry is entitled to compensation. All those things are an agreed set of values and an agreed process, but they all hinge on genuine and transparent information coming to the federal government that allows it to be confident about any agreement it reaches.
What do you do when you cannot trust the state government? I am saying very clearly to the federal government that you cannot trust the Victorian state government. That has been very clear and has even been accepted by the federal Minister for Forestry and Conservation. What you do is you suspend the process. You say, `It is flawed, and we won't go ahead with it. We agree that, until the environmental assessment by independent auditors is carried through, this goes no further, because the process is flawed.' Secondly, you say, `Even if it does go forward down the track, what do we do with the woodchips?' Under no circumstances do you provide for woodchips from this forest to be export woodchips. In my time, when Labor was in government, we fought very hard to make sure that the chips residue from this forest went to the local value added plant at Bacchus Marsh, CSR. Since the change of government, CSR has closed, and there is therefore no market for those chips.
This government has got to get off its backside and take the Australian industry to the point where there is an Australian pulp mill so there is somewhere to send these chips. I will not support any process that continues to think that the solution is sending chips out of the forest somewhere overseas so that we can continue to buy back the pulp. It is absurd. Four years after the change of government, we are still in the situation of not having a pulp mill in Australia,  yet we send shiploads of chips overseas. And this is supposed to be part of Australia's environmental solution. It is supposed to be part of our sensible approach to greenhouse strategy.
I am foreshadowing to the minister and the government a major local confrontation when this debate comes to a head—and we have not had one until now because we have been able to manage this through sensible principles. I think the state minister—who is attempting to 
 transfer from his upper house seat to the lower house seat of Gisborne, which is right in the heart of this—should ignore Jeff Kennett's instruction not to debate these issues locally. He would be pretty stupid politically if he failed to take up the call to attend a public debate about these issues, because he is in the hot seat. It is his government that is feeding bum information to Canberra. It is his government that is planning to woodchip this forest into extinction. He has three weeks to get himself on deck and to explain his position to the people.
I am publicly signalling here that, unless we get a sound and transparent management plan for this forest, a genuine commitment that any woodchip residue goes to an Australian pulp mill and a genuine, value adding and sustainable outcome for the local timber industry, this forest needs to be pulled out of the RFA process. If it is pulled out of the RFA process, that means no woodchips for anybody. It means the local timber industry is in difficulty, but it also means that you avoid the serious public confrontation which is brewing because the Victorian state government cannot be trusted and the federal government is so embarrassed by this performance that even the federal minister concedes that is the case.
Mr Deputy Speaker, I have taken that opportunity to try and be as constructive as I can about this matter, because it is one I have been involved in for a long time. I have the corporate knowledge to know very well that what is happening here in Canberra is spot on. I am putting on the public record via this statement today my suggested approach to a resolution of this issue before it becomes a hot flame in central Victoria. That suggestion is put forward constructively with the intention of our industry building its value adding investment but giving the forest and the people a future.
I thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, for the opportunity to put those points on the table. I reiterate my earlier comments that I support the investment contained in  Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 2) 1999  regarding alternative fossil fuel options. However, I make the point that it is very little. We should not have had the four-year lag in these 
 programs. I think that circumstances are closing in on this government as its environmental performance and its performance at Kyoto comes under the spotlight.

name: Jenkins, Harry, MP
text:
—The long title of these bills states:
A Bill for an Act to appropriate the Consolidated Revenue Fund for certain purposes, and for other purposes.
In the case of Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 2) 1999  the words `relating to the environment' are added. The purpose of these two bills can best be summed up in the final sentence of the very short second reading speech delivered with these bills, both of which are basically the same sentence. In Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 1) 1999  the sentence states:
The funding proposed in this bill meets these two commitments of the Government—
and with bill No. 1 that is to do with the Book Industry Assistance Plan and the Supported Accommodation Assistance Program—
to the Australian Democrats in the context of our tax reform package.
In the case of bill No. 2, the sentence states:
The funding proposed in this bill meets these environment commitments of the Government to the Australian Democrats in the context of our tax reform package.
That is what these two bills are basically about. These bills seek to appropriate funds for a variety of measures resulting from the government's grubby, puerile, sleazy deal—you pick the appropriate adjective, Mr Deputy Speaker—with the Australian Democrats to ensure the passage of its legislation to charge Australians 10 per cent on nearly everything they do or buy.
These measures are part of the deal under which, after 1 July next year, every time Australians go to buy something, when they put their hands in their pockets into that pocket will go the hands of the Prime Minister, John Howard, and the Treasurer, Peter Costello, and together with them as partners in crime will be the hand of Senator Meg Lees, the Leader of the Australian Democrats. Over the next two and a bit weeks I will be reminding people in Victoria that, 
 not only have they got all those hands in their pockets, but they had better have deep pockets because Premier Jeff Kennett was there as one of the partners in crime to ensure that the Prime Minister got his GST package up. The people of Victoria have to know that, despite his humping around the countryside saying what a tragedy to small business GST compliance costs are, Jeff Kennett was able to ensure at the Premiers Conference that the deal got through.
When it came to books, housing and the environment the government and the Democrats were able to come to some arrangement to reach their deal. However, a casual glance at these two bills reveals just how greatly the government took the Democrats for an absolute ride. It prompts the question how and why the Democrats sold out so cheaply on issues that they professed to be part of their raison d'etre. If the Democrats' non-negotiable GST-free books election policy is looked at, it has been watered down to a book production bounty and grants to assist writers. Grants to writers are an admission that the GST will decimate the book industry, whether it be those writing them or printing them.
These measures add up to $180 million over three years, or $240 million over four years in this bill, and they are vulnerable to budget cuts in the years after that. The Democrats have not in any way secured the future of the book industry in this country. If the government does cut these measures in outyears after that, the book industry is left to the full mercy of the goods and services tax. These measures do not compensate for the massive burden that the GST and compliance to it will place on the industry. They directly compromise the Democrats' GST-free education policy, which they also sold out on and showed no signs of wanting to—let alone being able to—secure from the government.
These bills also appropriate funds for the Supported Accommodation Assistance Program, or SAAP. The extra $15 million per year appropriated with these bills to deal with a national crisis such as youth homelessness is totally inadequate, but totally expected, given the Howard government's whole attitude towards issues of housing and homeless 
 ness since coming to office. The budget announcements on funding for housing were all recycled previous announcements. In some cases, the Minister for Family and Community Services tried to get away with announcing the same funding three times hoping no-one would notice that it was not new money.
At the time of the budget the government did announce an additional $45 million over six years for the SAAP. Of course, this translates to a mere $7½ million per year. The great irony of this is that the funding is merely to allow SAAP agencies to pay their staff award wages. Of course, those staff deserve to be paid and should be paid properly for their work. However, the fact remains that none of the additional $45 million was to increase services for those in need.
Now comes a paltry amount of $15 million in these bills each year which adds further insult to injury. It is widely known that this amount is too little, because last year the government sponsored a review by the Australian Housing and Urban Research Institute. The review recommended 25 per cent growth funds for SAAP just to service the current unmet demand. Now it is unclear whether this additional $60 million, which was supposedly extracted by the Democrats from the government, is actually more than what might have been announced late last year in response to other studies. The finding for the need for 25 per cent growth funds was supported by the Department of Family and Community Services, but has been totally ignored by the government. That gives the House some idea of the magnitude of the problem the nation faces with regard to issues concerning housing and homelessness and the total inadequacy of the Howard government's response to it. It also speaks volumes for the Australian Democrats and prompts the question why they sold themselves out on the issue of GST for so little.
Of all the issues the Democrats sold out on in this deal, the environment is perhaps the most surprising, given their rhetoric over some 20 years. The environmental consequences of the GST were totally ignored by both the government and the Democrats. The GST is a disaster for the environment because 
 of the likely increase in the use of diesel fuel and the increase in greenhouse gases. The Democrats' non-negotiable reduction of the tax cuts on diesel and petrol through increased weight thresholds failed to materialise in this shonky deal. Instead, the nation will be lumbered with a totally unworkable system of transport credits for so-called regional transport vehicles. The definition is yet to be outlined.
The Democrats sold out to the government and handed a raft of environmental powers over to the states and territories in the biodiversity legislation. The government have been winding back funding for the environment steadily since coming to office under cover of the Natural Heritage Trust fund set up with the proceeds of the sale of Telstra. Now the Democrats have joined them in this attitude to the environment.
As others have said in the debate, the measures contained in  Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 2) 1999  which relate to the environment of course have some merit. As was revealed in the debate and discussions which surrounded the talks the Democrats had with the government over the GST, a number of these measures had been earmarked as measures that the government would be putting in place. In fact, even in the measures which are to do with the environment, we find that all we have had is a public announcement that ties these measures into the deal done with the Democrats at that fateful meeting down at 4 Treasury Place in Melbourne after Senator Harradine had made his principled views known on the GST package.
When all is said and done about this deal, after 1 July next year a GST will be put in place. All these measures came about when Senator Lees and Senator Murray sat down with the Treasurer and the Prime Minister around the table at 4 Treasury Place: they discussed the issues; they put certain ideas on the table; they sent Max Moore-Wilton busily off over the weekend, distracting him from what he was really going to say to Mr Barratt, the then Secretary to Defence, about his future; and they cobbled these measures together. Then they came back the next week 
 and the Democrats rolled over and said they would tick off on the GST package. What we get—amongst other things—are the measures contained in these two bills.
It is just not good enough. It is not good enough that a political force in Australia should sit down and so easily agree to measures that in many cases would have occurred; and to measures contained in these bills that go nowhere near far enough to redress the damage that has been done in the case of the book industry and a number of items dealing with the environment. They go nowhere near far enough towards redressing the difficulties that occur in the post-GST environment.
Of course, the opposition have made it clear that they will be supporting these bills, because there is a certain inevitability that we have to in order to put some of these things in place. As I have said, a number of them have merit. But the Australian public has to remember that the issues that arose and that led to the need for these two pieces of legislation have their base in fact in a deal which was made between the Australian Democrats and the coalition government.
