As has been indicated in this debate, there are many provisions of these two bills that should have happened and would have happened without this tawdry deal. I would suggest that the next time the Australian Democrats enter into negotiations they ought to have a due diligence test where they at least look at what is actually in the pipeline, is near announcement or has been announced, and not sign off, underline and highlight announcements that are going to be made or have already been made, because that short-changes them on any decisions and deals that they make of this magnitude.
I fear the consequences of the GST package and the damage that will materialise. I fear that, at the end of the day, the Australian public just might forget that it is not only the coalition they have to blame for those consequences, but they have to remember that the Australian Democrats played a very big role in putting those consequences together.

name: Slipper, Peter, MP
text:
—in reply—In 
 commencing my summing up I would like to thank honourable members who have participated in the debate on these two important pieces of legislation—the Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 1) 1999  and the Appropriation (Supplementary Measures) Bill (No. 2) 1999 —which, as I said in my second reading speech, deliver on the government's commitments to the Australian Democrats on 31 May 1999.
It ought to be placed on the record and recognised that the agreement reached between the government and the Australian Democrats represents a defining moment in history. It secured the government's historic tax reform changes of which all Australians can be very proud. I would like to wholeheartedly applaud the words of the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Meg Lees, who when commenting on the tax package stated:
The Democrats have won more in 13 hours of talks with the Howard Government than they did in 13 years under the Labor Government.
The Democrats and the government have acted responsibly in securing genuine tax reform for this country, and the Australian people who voted for a new tax system in the October 1998 election will certainly be much better off for it.
 It is very sad that the Labor Party continues to criticise members of the government for being prepared to implement the very important changes voted for by the Australian people. It is also interesting to note the Labor members who stood up one after the other and bagged the very constructive role the Australian Democrats played in this legislation. We heard words like `puerile' and `tawdry'. The honourable member for Throsby claimed that the Democrats had jumped into bed with the government. The honourable member for Wills even attacked the Democrats for negotiating on environmental initiatives.
It is interesting that members of the former Labor government who are now in this chamber have turned on the party with which they used to cooperate in the upper house just because the Australian Democrats are displaying incredibly positive initiatives in dealing 
 with the government. Let us just look at editorial comment made following the GST compromise. The Sydney Morning Herald on 31 May said:
The GST compromise between the Howard Government and the Australian Democrats represents a triumph for the Prime Minister. He held his nerve through the last election campaign, and for most of the ensuing tax debate.
It went on later to say:
The significant loser from the GST deal is the Labor Party, specifically its leader, Mr Beazley. For three years Labor has ditched the great economic reforms of the Hawke-Keating governments for a leftist populism that is associated with its prized recruit, Mrs Cheryl Kernot. The adamantine refusal to do anything but launch attack after attack on the GST has led Labor into a dry policy gully.
The Adelaide Advertiser  on 31 May said:
The deal is to be supported and even applauded.
. . .              . . .             . . .
The overriding fact is that Australia has overdue tax reform and, had this compact not been made, that would have been impossible for the foreseeable future.
The West Australian  on 31 May said:
The compromise deal agreed between the government in the Democrats shows that the system is working.
The deal—
finally opens the way for long overdue reform of our ramshackle, illogical tax system. It heralds the arrival of a transparent and equitable new system.
The Labor Party—
rendered itself irrelevant to the tax debate when it put perceived political advantage ahead of responsible reform.
So, as a result of discussions between the government and the Australian Democrats, we will have a new tax system, and the two bills currently before the chamber are important elements in securing the passage of the legislation. The government is very proud not only about having reached an agreement with the Australian Democrats but also about the very positive measures included in these two bills.
This government, despite what Labor members would have you believe, is the greenest government in Australia's history. We delivered the Natural Heritage Trust, which has spent well over $1 billion on 
 repairing the impact of 200 years of European settlement in Australia. We have an enormous range of environmental achievements, and it is about time that those opposite gave the government credit—the very real credit—for what it has achieved, for what it is achieving through this legislation and, indeed, for what it will continue to achieve in the future.
Labor members also sought to suggest that the GST in some way would adversely affect a greener Australia. The new $1.2 billion strategy to improve air quality and to reduce greenhouse gas emissions was negotiated with the Australian Democrats and will be implemented as a result of the legislation currently before the House. This new air quality package includes faster introduction of new technology machines to cut down on vehicle emissions; cleaner fuels to power those engines; increased support for alternative transport fuels, such as compressed natural gas and LP; incentives for households to switch to solar power; and an extra $100 million a year for increased efforts to combat global warming.
The honourable member for Burke endeavoured to suggest that cheaper diesel would in some way create more pollution. That simply is not true. I want to place on the record that, thanks to the new air quality package negotiated with the Australian Democrats, there will be actually less, not more, pollution. There will be cleaner air and a better quality of life for Australians. The Bureau of Transport Economics has predicted that air pollution levels in the year 2015 will be lower than current levels, because of the changes to engine technology and fuel standards.
The honourable member for Wills seems to participate in most legislation relating to Australia's tax system. He claimed that the process for distributing money with respect to the Supported Accommodation Assistance Program is not clear. I would like to reassure the honourable member that the Commonwealth government will agree on the distribution of the funds with the states in accordance with the normal processes for distributing Supported Accommodation Assistance Program moneys. The extra money being provid 
 ed by this legislation will not adversely impact on that.
The honourable member for Prospect and, indeed, the honourable member for Newcastle both claimed that a tax on books will make books more expensive, as they are currently free of wholesale sales tax. It is true that books will go up in price slightly. We anticipate they will go up by about four per cent—certainly not by the 10 per cent that was suggested by some. But one has to look at the global picture. One must also consider the very positive benefits for the book industry included in this legislation. In addition, it must be recognised that Australians will receive dramatic reductions in personal income tax. The wholesale sales tax is being scrapped. Other taxes are disappearing, and there will be a four per cent boost in pensions and benefits. So people will have more money in their pockets.
The honourable member for Wills also claimed that the legislation before the chamber would provide an administrative nightmare for the book industry. The simple fact of the matter is that there will be less red tape as a result of Australia's new tax system. The government is distributing $500 million to small and medium business with respect to GST implementation, and it has been calculated that across the board there will be reductions in red tape rather than the reverse. Certainly we will be having consultations with respect to the industry, and we certainly intend to make sure that this very positive scheme introduced in this legislation works, and works well. It will work, and it will work in a very positive way.
The honourable member for Prospect also appeared to be caught in a time warp, because a lot of her speech related to the situation that existed before the arrangements with the Australian Democrats. She spoke about what she perceived as being the impact of the GST on books. But one really has to look at the situation which will flow from the passage of this legislation to see the assistance being given to the book industry. I would just like to highlight a media release dated 20 August 1999 issued by the Australian Publishers Association. It said:
The Australian Publishers Association today welcomed the release of details of the Book Industry Assistance Plan.
Further down it said:
Sandy Grant, President of the APA, said today, "I congratulate the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Democrats in working together to arrive at a package which brings benefits to various sectors of the industry.
It also said:
Sue Blackwell, Executive Director of the APA, in welcoming the announcement said, "there has been full industry consultation on the components of this important package. The APA was consulted at several stages during the consultations and we were pleased to be involved."
The legislation before the chamber certainly includes many benefits with respect to textbooks, and I refer to a media release dated 20 August 1999 issued by the Co-op Bookshop, a very well-known university bookshop. It said:
Australia's largest tertiary textbook seller, the University Co-op Bookshop, which runs fifty stores Australia wide, has expressed its strong support for the 8% textbook subsidy announced by Democrats leader Meg Lees this morning.
Further on it says:
"The deal struck between the Government and the Democrats is very similar to the Canadian model proposed in the Co-op's own submission and I believe works very well in that country."
The honourable member for Scullin claimed that this legislation meant that education would not be GST free. The lie to that particular comment is also enclosed in this media release from the Co-op Bookshop. It says:
"The Government made a commitment last year that educational costs would be GST free and with this deal it has honoured that commitment."
The honourable member for Scullin has been caught out with respect to that particular matter. The honourable member for Prospect also claimed that a tax on books would encourage book buyers to buy through the Internet and that money was leaving Australia. She mentioned certain of the difficulties which she considered the book industry was currently experiencing. People in this country, under Labor's old tax system, and in other countries are already buying books through the Internet, and many of the problems of the 
 book industry which the member for Prospect highlighted have absolutely nothing at all to do with the legislation currently before the chamber.
The honourable member for Mitchell made a very much more positive and erudite contribution to the debate on this legislation. He spoke about the benefits of it. He also praised, most appropriately, the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs for his absolute determination to improve literacy standards in Australia. The honourable member for Dunkley also referred to the overall benefits of the tax plan. He pointed out, as I just have, that the difficulties experienced by the book industry mentioned by the member for Prospect have absolutely nothing to do with our tax reform proposals.
The honourable member for Fowler joined her colleagues in what I thought was a fairly cowardly attack on Senator Meg Lees and the Australian Democrats. But she, unlike the member for Newcastle, did have the decency to actually praise the green initiatives in this legislation. The Labor Party is not actually opposing this legislation, but the honourable member for Newcastle said words to the effect that this legislation was disgusting and that the $1 billion being spent as a result of these bills was inappropriate expenditure whereas most people in this country, including those in the opposition, would say that these are very positive and important initiatives and certainly worthy of strong support.
The member for Blaxland thought he was speaking on a bill related to Sydney airport, and he only peripherally touched the subject matter of this legislation. I thought it was a pity that he did not spend time praising the very important initiatives being brought about by the government.
The member for Newcastle also criticised the government's responsible economic management. He forgot that when we came to government there was a budget deficit of $10.3 billion. He overlooked that we as a nation simply could not go on spending more than we in fact earned. This government did not create that problem, but we resolutely accepted that we had a responsibility to fix it, and fix it we certainly did.
Certain members from Victoria failed to remember that they were in the federal parliament and sought to bring the Victorian election within the four walls of this chamber. I certainly do not intend to dignify their comments by participating in the Victorian state election.
The government are very satisfied with this legislation. We are very proud of our record in the areas covered by the two bills before the chamber. We have been particularly pleased that what we are proposing has been strongly supported by people in the industry and by the community generally, and it is with a very great deal of pleasure that I commend these two bills to the chamber.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

name: Lee, Michael, MP
text:
—The States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1999  implements a number of the government's budget undertakings and, in particular, it provides an additional $36.3 million for the national literacy and numeracy plan and for literacy improvement strategies for the middle years of schooling and $26.4 million for the year 2000 to extend funding for the National Asian Languages and Studies in Australian Schools strategy.
In the lead-up to the 1999 budget, the Prime Minister raised expectations amongst teachers, state ministers for education, parents and even a number of students who follow debate about education policy matters quite closely. The Prime Minister said on the Neil Mitchell program that the 1999 budget would be an education budget. Having made massive cuts to funding for education, including massive cuts to funding for universities and TAFEs, many people were hoping that the Howard government's 1999 budget would be different.
When it actually appeared, unfortunately, the 1999 Howard budget turned out to be—certainly for education—unbalanced, short-sighted and unfair. The reason that we on this side of the House argue that the 1999 Howard budget could in no way be described as an education budget is that, in the first case, it was unbalanced as far as funding for schools was concerned. The government provided a 
 massive increase in funding for non-government schools, with a minimal increase in funding for students at government schools across the nation, so it was unbalanced.
It was unfair because the government abolished the merit based equity scholarships for university students. That was a token program that was established when former education minister Senator Vanstone made the massive $800 million cuts in federal funding for universities. Yet, the Prime Minister in his education budget abolished those merit based equity scholarships, so kids from poor families, rural backgrounds and non-English speaking backgrounds would no longer be able to receive those scholarships. In fact, the $700,000 that the Prime Minister has spent on renovations to the Lodge and Kirribilli could have paid for 200 of those scholarships for kids from needy backgrounds. So we would certainly say that it was not only unbalanced in the way it funded schools but also unfair in the way the merit based equity scholarships for kids from poor backgrounds who wanted to attend university were concerned.
It was also short-sighted because in this so-called education budget no money was found to restore growth funding for TAFEs. Of course, as we have raised on many occasions, the government is continuing to cut back the Commonwealth government's investment in education, training and research. In the last year of the Labor government, Commonwealth investment in education, training and research hit three per cent of gross national product. I have met many people involved in schools, TAFE colleges, universities and vocational training who would argue that, even in 1996, an investment of three per cent of the national income of the Commonwealth's budget for education, training and research was not enough. But if three per cent was not enough to be investing in 1996, look where we are today—investment by the Commonwealth government in education, training and research has fallen away to only 2½ per cent in the most recent budget, with the forward estimates showing a further decline to only 2.3 per cent.
I am sure that the students in the galleries today understand that if Australia does not 
 invest more in their education, does not invest more in giving them opportunities to develop their vocational skills for employment, does not invest more in giving them the opportunities to become software programmers or medical researchers who discover the next big breakthrough for diagnosing and curing illness, and does not invest more in giving industrial researchers better ways to produce goods and services in Australia, then Australia's long-term future will be compromised.
Australia needs to invest more in education, training and research. I know my colleague the member for Rankin, with a number of us on this side of the House, has played a very close role in putting together the figures that demonstrate quite clearly that the 1999 Howard budget—the so-called education budget—was actually a retreat in the Commonwealth's effort for investing in education, training and research.
The point to make is that the government's legislation which is currently before us does a couple of things for schools. I will turn first of all to literacy. I will say a few things about literacy this afternoon, but the first point to make is that we currently have in Dr Kemp, the member for Goldstein, the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, a person who believes that getting political coverage and grandstanding on literacy are more important than actually improving literacy in Australian schools. That is not the view just of the Labor Party. Speak to Liberal Party state ministers for education around the country and they will point out that in the current Commonwealth minister for education we have a person who uses literacy every time he is placed under pressure.
—You would spend a lot of time trying to confirm that.
—We will challenge the member for Macquarie to indicate what his views are on these issues because I would like to contrast the views of the member for Macquarie with the views of, for example, the Victorian Liberal Minister for Education, Mr Phil Gude, who, on 15 September 1997, described Dr Kemp, the member for Goldstein, as a spin doctor on literacy matters. In a media release on 24 September 1997, he said, `This is 
 typical schoolyard bully stuff.' On Four Corners  a few weeks ago, on 9 August 1999, Phil Gude, the Liberal Minister for Education, said:
Well I think what he was clearly trying to do was to gain a profile on an issue, and I thought it was not cricket if you like . . . to use the kids . . . 
—Are you opposing—
—These are not my words; these are the words of your colleague the Victorian Liberal Minister for Education. Let me give the member for Macquarie the full quote again. On Four Corners , on 9 August 1999—a few weeks ago—Phil Gude, Liberal Minister for Education in Victoria, said:
Well I think what he was clearly trying to do was to gain a profile on an issue, and I thought it was not cricket if you like . . . to use the kids, use the teachers, use the profession in that way. I've found in my life that honesty has never got me into any trouble.
The interviewer asked Mr Gude:
You accused him at the time . . . [of] `Deliberately and mischievously manipulating data to portray literacy at a perilous level'?
To which Mr Gude answered, `Yes, I did . . . because I believe that's what was done.' There you had the Victorian Liberal Minister for Education saying, `Yes, Dr Kemp, the member for Goldstein, the minister for education, deliberately and mischievously manipulated data to portray literacy at a perilous level.'
—A damning indictment.
—It is a damning indictment when the minister for education's own colleagues point out the truth about his attempts to use literacy to advance his own political career rather than to try to make sure that Australian kids have a better chance to improve their literacy skills.
It has always amazed me that the federal minister for education would support state governments actually cutting back the number of teachers trying to help students to improve their literacy and numeracy. It has always amazed me that the minister for education would support conservative state governments which have actually reduced the number of teachers who are out there. We were just talking about Victoria. Mr Gude has presided 
 over a reduction of 9,000 teachers in the state of Victoria—9,000 fewer teachers, 9,000 fewer people able to work one-on-one with those students who might be having difficulty with literacy and numeracy.
How can Dr Kemp, the member for Goldstein, argue that you can improve literacy for Australian kids by having fewer teachers available to sit down and work with students to resolve their problems? It is our contention that if the federal government were prepared to work cooperatively and try to develop a spirit of bipartisanship in improving literacy, then we would do a lot better than by using bullying and headline grabbing as Dr Kemp, the minister for education, has sought to do.
The most recent development is that the states have now sidelined the federal minister for education. We had an announcement on 4 August by the Labor government in New South Wales, the Liberal government in Victoria, the Liberal government in South Australia and the Liberal coalition government in the ACT that they would be undertaking nationally comparable tests, with the Labor government in Queensland to participate from next year. All of this completely excludes the federal minister for education. We welcome that the states are doing what Dr Kemp could never achieve. The states are getting together to make sure—
—It was a Commonwealth initiative.
—So it was a Commonwealth initiative, was it? I hate to tell the member for Macquarie—
—The member for Dobell will ignore the member for Macquarie.
—I know he is testing your patience, Mr Deputy Speaker, but we do our best to educate members such as the member for Macquarie. We do our best to try to make sure that they understand that it is their own coalition colleagues who have sidelined the minister for education.
It is certainly true that the federal minister for education stands up in this House and claims credit for the fact that the states have sidelined him and that the states have now 
 established comparable tests in literacy. But I make the point that these are not tests that have been developed by the federal minister for education. These are tests that have been developed in spite of the federal minister for education. These are tests that Labor and Liberal states have put together through a spirit of cooperation. If the minister for education were more interested in advancing that cooperation and spirit of bipartisanship rather than seeking to grab headlines for himself, then even more progress could have been attained.
You would almost think that there was no focus on literacy until the federal minister for education came along. That completely ignores the fact that as far back as 1987 New South Wales was conducting basic skills testing. In Victoria and South Australia, it has been taking place since 1995. Since his first day as the minister for education, the member for Goldstein has sought to use literacy as a platform for self-promotion. He has dishonestly portrayed the National Schools English Literacy Survey, set up under the Working Nation plan of the federal Labor government, as his own initiative. The member for Goldstein has never acknowledged that $17 million was provided in 1995 and 1996 under the former government's early literacy program.
He has also never acknowledged that he manipulated the results of the NSELS in order to manufacture a crisis atmosphere. Of course, he was not happy with the initial results that were produced by that study so he had the figures redone to produce his own benchmark figures, which then allowed him to go on 60 Minutes—a disgraceful performance—in September 1997, where he suggested that there was some massive conspiracy between the teacher unions and state departments of education to cover up the fact that one-third of all kids cannot read and write properly. If that were true, how does the minister explain the results that have been coming through since the mid-1980s in states like New South Wales? How does the minister explain that his own Liberal colleagues, in states where his party has been in control, completely reject the bogus conclusions that he has developed? 
 It is quite clear that on literacy more progress needs to be made.
Just before I leave the matter of literacy, there is the important issue of parents working with their children to improve their literacy by sitting down at night and reading to their kids. Reading in the morning rather than letting their children watch TV would also help. A few minutes ago in this House we had a parliamentary secretary arguing that the government's new GST and its rebate for books will mean that education is now GST free. This bill provides funding for schools because it says there should be more money going into literacy. But what the government cannot deny is that its GST legislation places a 10 per cent tax on books such as this one—Test your child's reading level 3—that parents can use. A parent in your own electorate, Mr Deputy Speaker, can purchase this book at a bookshop in your electorate and work to improve their child's reading, assess the level of reading that their son or daughter may have and then work with their teachers to try to improve it. All of these books will have a 10 per cent GST placed on them. None of these books will qualify for the rebate if they are purchased by a parent, and it is completely misleading for the government to claim that education will now be GST free—let alone the GST that will be imposed on the uniforms, the bus fares, the lunches and all of the other expenses that parents have in making sure their children get a good education.
I would like to turn to the second element of the bill that seeks to provide $26 million for the year 2000 to extend funding for the National Asian Languages and Studies in Australian Schools strategy. We note that the minister's praise for this program and its value in developing cultural understanding and skills for participation in the global economy never includes recognition that this was established under the former Labor government, with strong support from governments such as the Goss government in Queensland. It was through the cooperative efforts of the federal and state governments in those days that these Asian language programs were introduced in schools right across Australia. 
This is no surprise, given that the current federal minister for education also takes credit for other Labor government initiatives such as the Australian Student Traineeship Foundation and the Jobs Pathway program. He actually told the House in question time on 25 August that the Jobs Pathway program had been established by the coalition—a complete and utter falsehood. This minister tries to take credit for the good ideas of others when he has never had a single good idea himself.
We believe this minister has an obsession with undermining our great public institutions—our universities, our TAFE colleges, our government schools. This minister has an ideological agenda about shifting education as far and as quickly as possible from our great public institutions into private institutions. It is effectively a privatisation of education. The point we make is that it is not the way the future of education in Australia should go.
The other point is that on budget night there was a commitment from the minister to provide an additional $77.7 million for teacher professional development. `Teacher professional development' rang a little bell. While we welcome these funds, we have to point out that it was the former Labor government and not the Howard government that introduced funding for professional development for teachers. But it was the coalition that broke its 1996 election promise to continue to fund the professional development programs that the Keating and Hawke governments had funded.
Mr Nairn interjecting—
—So you do concede your promise on professional development funding was broken? I thank the member of Eden-Monaro for that concession. You promised in 1996 to provide professional development funding, and you broke that promise. In this budget you again promised $77 million for teacher professional development, but where is it? This is the bill that funds budget announcements from the 1999 budget. There is money there for literacy in middle years, there is money for rolling over the Asian language strategy, but where is the money for teacher professional development? That is the money that will give us the best chance to raise the 
 quality of teaching in our schools, that will help teachers update their skills to make sure that they have the latest training and the latest information at their fingertips and that they are providing the best possible quality of education to students in schools right across the country. Where is it? We are entitled to ask.
This is the bill that implements budget promises. The sum of $77 million was promised for professional development for teachers to increase the quality of teaching in our schools, but it is not in this bill. So this afternoon we challenge the federal minister for education to tell us where the money has gone. Where is the $77 million that was promised for professional development for teachers? The coalition broke the promise in 1996 to continue the Labor government's funding for professional development for teachers. Again the government promised $77 million in this budget, but it is not in this bill. So, as he enters the chamber, we challenge the minister for education: tell us what happened to the $77 million, David, for professional development for teachers. You broke the promise in 1996 and there is no money in this bill that implements the budget promises for the professional development of teachers.	The point we make is that this money needs to be committed now so that the money can be allocated from 1 January next year.
While the minister is in the chamber, let me set a question for the minister—a question that every primary school student who might be in the gallery here today can answer. What is 32 minus four? Every student in the gallery could tell us that it is 28. When David Kemp, the federal minister for education, subtracts four from 32 he gets 33. In this House he told us there was an increase in new apprenticeships from 204,000 to 232,000 and that that was an increase of 33,000. Do you remember that, Minister? Two days ago the minister said that 32 minus four is 33. You would fail a primary school student who made that mistake. We say this minister has failed on many occasions in the way that he has manipulated and distorted statistics. He is the person who needs some numeracy education, and today I am prepared on behalf of the 
 Labor Party to fund a numeracy remedial course for this minister of education. We will pass the hat around to fund a remedial course in numeracy for this federal minister for education because he does not know that 32 minus four is 28 and not 33.
—Order! It being 2 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 101A. The debate may be resumed at a later hour and the member will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed.
debate_title: <title>STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1999</title>

name: Crean, Simon, MP
text:
—On Monday, the Prime Minister claimed Australia as the `miracle economy'. Today's national accounts and Monday's current account figures should send him a wake up call. In all the government's hubris and arrogance, there are fundamental issues that need addressing—our current account, our savings, the composition of our growth and the sustainability of that growth because that is what determines whether or not we get the jobs.
Not only are these issues not being addressed, the government will not even talk about them. It will not debate them. The Treasurer will not come into the House and debate the economic policy in this country. 
 He sends his shadow into this place because he will not come and debate the issue.
Opposition members interjecting—
—He is a very fulsome shadow, and gets more fulsome by the day. We are commenting about those new suits. It is all for the fitting.
The truth of it is that, if we are to achieve sustained economic growth, all of the issues have to be addressed, not only those that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer choose to speak on. The Treasurer will not come into this place and talk about the current account. He will not talk about the increasing imbalance in our economic growth. He will not talk about his decimation of household savings or how he has lumbered households with debt.
That is pretty extraordinary because, prior to 1996, you could not stop him talking about these things. This is the man who gave us the current account measured per hour in nominal terms and the foreign debt measured per person. In a week that has seen our nation's athletes strive for and win gold, the Treasurer has been racking up his own records. He is now the Australian record holder for a record high current account deficit, a record high foreign debt, a record high trade deficit, a record quarterly drop in business expenditure on capital, a record low household savings rate and a record high household debt rate. It is little wonder the cartoonists are lampooning him for the miracle economy.
This is the Treasurer producing world records that he is ashamed of and will not talk about. These records are not the product of an accident; they are outcomes which neither the Treasurer's hubris nor his smirk can ultimately hide. It is the economy that Treasurer Costello will not talk about. It no longer surprises us that he will not come into this place when he is required to and debate it.
This afternoon I want to highlight the Treasurer's wilful economic negligence in failing to heed the wake up call that has been sounding for months now to highlight the economy that he just will not talk about. But we need to look right across the economy, not just stand up and pretend that it is all good and that everyone is a winner. For all the 
 rhetoric of miracles, there are underlying problems emerging in the economy. The benefits of growth are not being shared. This is the current reality. The future reality is that, without a rebalancing of the economy, the growth that he always wants to champion and rave about will not be sustainable. Quite frankly, the bankcard has its limits.
Only this week when the Australian Bureau of Statistics released data on Australia's twin deficits—the current account deficit and the foreign debt—the Treasurer talked about everything but the current account deficit and foreign debt. This is the Treasurer who claims to have fireproofed the economy, but the current account deficit has blown out to a record 9.4 thousands of millions of dollars, to use the Treasurer's preferred linguistic term. One would have thought that he would have heeded his own advice of February 1995, when he said:
I mean, look, my analysis is this . . . my analysis is that this is a government that has completely failed Australia on the current account deficit and produced the highest current account deficit ever, which is a total failure of economic policy. That's my analysis.
But, when asked, the Treasurer simply dismissed the problem saying it was ignorant to use dollar figures. What hypocrisy! Not use dollar figures? Really? He claims it is ignorant today to use dollar figures but what did he say in 1995? I quote him again:
A $1,500 million deficit is better than a $2,000 million deficit, but it's still a deficit—it's a jolly big one. If we were in government, we wouldn't be parading a $1,500 million deficit as a success.
Sounds like dollar figures to me from the Treasurer who now says we cannot talk in them. Why? Because what they are exposing are the flaws in his economic management.
Beyond the hypocrisy, his defence this week to his record current account deficit was, first, to blame the Asian crisis—but this is the same person who trumpeted about having fireproofed us from that same crisis; second, to blame the domestic economy; and, third, to claim the record a success because he had predicted failure and he achieved it. This is a Treasurer who believes success comes from predicting failure. This is a Treasurer who aims low and achieves it. This is a 
 Treasurer not in control of the fundamental issues that need to be addressed so far as the economic management of this country is concerned. On 20 September 1995, the current Prime Minister launched the infamous debt truck.
Opposition members interjecting—
—Do you remember that? That was the truck that broke down on the hill up the Blue Mountains. It is now a B-double. The Prime Minister in relation to that debt truck made two promises to the Australian people.
Opposition members interjecting—
—Order! I would remind some members of the warning that they are under, and it would be most inconvenient for the Deputy Leader of the Opposition if I were to take any other action. Out of deference to him, I call him.
—This is what the Prime Minister had to say in making two promises about that debt truck:
I can promise you that we will follow policies which will, over a period of time, bring down the foreign debt.
What a joke. He continued:
Our first priority as Peter Costello and I have made repeatedly clear, our first priority in Government economically will be to tackle the current account deficit.
Two promises? The facts clearly speak for themselves. This week not only did the current account blow out to be 42 per cent higher in 1998-99 than in 1997-98, but Australia's foreign debt grew to be nearly 20 per cent higher in the period that Peter Costello took over the debt truck. As I said before, that debt truck has now been upgraded to a B-double.
The current account deficit is really the manifestation of a more fundamental problem, an imbalance between savings and investment. Without genuine micro-economic policies, social policies and a coherent strategy for employment or a commitment to the future, neither the efficiency nor levels of investment and savings will improve. When the Treasurer slashed programs to help the unemployed, when he raised the costs on families by 
 increasing child-care costs, when he pulled the shutters down on the futures of young Australians by cutting education and when he abandoned policies to increase research and development, he claimed that these would all rescue national savings.
Despite destroying the basis by which we invest in our future, 3½ years later after all of that pain, national savings have barely moved but household savings have plummeted and household debt has skyrocketed. Not content with running down the savings of Australian families, he is now going to lumber them and Australian businesses with a new GST. His advice to families has been eat, drink and be merry, charge it up to the bankcard, but we won't mention the hangover. His response these days is to quote the balance sheet. What he will not tell you, though, is that households are far more susceptible today to changes in external factors. No doubt he will also be claiming that putting families at risk is another one of their successes.
What we have seen under this Treasurer is an increasing imbalance in our growth. Consumption is dominating the composition of it, and it is beating investment by a long way. Whilst one would never begrudge Australians their consumption, and economic sustainability is importantly dependent on it, what we need for prosperity is a better balance between consumption and investment. I will quote someone who believes in that:
You can't run sustained economic recovery without growth in business investment. You can't run it off diminished savings and you can't run it indefinitely off increased consumption and this is where the risk is going to come.
Who said that? None other than the erstwhile Treasurer. This is the Treasurer's assessment about what needs to be the balance in growth, but it is a balance that we are not seeing. The economic facts again speak for themselves. Growth in private investment has slowed under Peter Costello compared to Labor's last three years. Today's figures demonstrate that the contribution of consumption for the quarter is 0.7 per cent but business investment is minus 0.2 per cent and net exports are minus 0.5 per cent. A sustained economy is one that grows from consumption, investment and net exports, but this one is going back 
 wards on the latter two fronts according to the most recent quarterly figures.
Last week, the Treasurer presided over the largest quarterly fall in private expenditure on capital since the ABS series began, and the average annual growth rate since he took over has been minus 0.2 per cent—minus 0.2 per cent in the time that they have held office and he claims that he has got it right. Research and development has been nobbled. Education has fallen dramatically. In short, what we are seeing the Treasurer preside over is nothing other than economic irresponsibility.
What Labor wants to do is this: we want to invest in our people, in their education and in their wellbeing, in their ideas. We want to develop the knowledge economy, invest in our future and share the benefits of growth. We need a return to balance in the economy, to lift savings and to lift investment, to make them more productive and to foster net export growth. The national accounts today ought to be the wake up call, and we hope the government hears it. This is a nation of huge opportunity. But if we continue down this path we will squander that opportunity. Labor repeats its call for a bipartisan approach so that we do not squander that opportunity.
The next important policy issue that this government has to address is business tax reform. Labor's position on this is absolutely clear: call on the government to release that report, not hide it. What are you hiding? Why won't you release it? We want there to be an opportunity for consultation around that report. We want the government to talk with us and negotiate to try to find the common ground. This, like so many of these issues, ought to be above the bickering across this table. It ought to be the basis upon which we do reach agreement, and I can assure you that there are many areas on which we can reach agreement. If we get that agreement, we will guarantee speedy passage for the agreed matters. We could leave it up to the leader of government business in the House to muck up that process, but we would guarantee speedy passage. Getting process right from the start obviates the need for a long Senate process. In this way, we can avoid the mess that the GST got the country into.
These are issues of great national importance for which Labor offers its bipartisan support. The Treasurer has taken us down an unsustainable path. It needs to be corrected. We need a return to balance in our growth. We need to invest in education, training and innovation. We need to invest and save more and invest and save better. The Treasurer must start addressing these issues and deal with them—not strut and remonstrate, not show his hubris and arrogance every time he gets up at question time in the parliament but rather come in here and debate the issues sensibly to find the common ground. Labor stands ready to be a participant in it.

name: Hockey, Joe, MP
text:
—We have just had a dissertation from the sand boy—from the guy who runs on to the field and hopes one day to play in the game. Yet again we have heard from the Labor Party how they want to be in there, how they would like to have a bipartisan approach. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition comes into the House and says, `We want to work in a bipartisan way. We want to be there. We'll guarantee a speedy resolution to the bills before the House.' Why hasn't he the courage to come in here and lay on the table Labor's proposals for business taxation reform? He will not do it. I will tell you why he will not do it: because the Labor Party stand for nothing. They believe in nothing. They have no policies. They have no policy debate. When it comes to taxation and the economy, the Labor Party are bereft of ideas, especially at the leadership level.
Let us look at their record. First, the Labor Party ran up budget deficits totalling $70 billion in their last five years of government compared to our surplus budgets, which are starting to pay off the Beazley black hole. Second, Commonwealth general government net debt rose from $16.9 billion in 1990-91 to $95.8 billion when we came to government—from $16.9 billion in 1990 to $95.8 billion when we came to office. We have already repaid $24 billion of their debt. Third, when Labor were in power, business interest rates, as so many small business people know in Australia, went to above 20 per cent per 
 annum in 1989. Today, business interest rates are at their lowest rate in 30 years.
Fourth, unemployment under the Labor Party and specifically under the now Leader of the Opposition as the then minister for employment reached the highest level since the early 1970s of around 11.2 per cent in 1992. So unemployment at a record level was 11.2 per cent. Today it is seven per cent. Fifth, inflation under the Labor Party averaged 5.2 per cent per annum. Today, under the coalition, it is one per cent. And the Labor Party has the gall to come into this House and lecture us about budget deficits and lecture us about unemployment and lecture us about the performance of the economy and lecture us about household debt when in every single case the Labor Party set records when it was in government.
The credibility of your argument today is assessed on your performance in the past. Promises are absolutely meaningless if you do not have the capacity to deliver what you promise. The Australian people on every indicator will ask the Leader of the Opposition and will ask the Labor Party, `How can we believe what you are saying?' You know what, it is a fair question. The punters out there are smart. They know exactly what this mob are up to. They know the hypocrisy and the gall of them coming into this House and lecturing us about the performance of the economy. They know they are telling untruths. They know they are telling half the story. Why? Because seared on the minds of every Australian small business is a 20 per cent interest rate under the Labor Party. Seared on the minds and in the memories of every Australian mortgage payer—the battlers out there—is an interest rate of up to 22 per cent on their household mortgage.
And seared on the minds of a generation of Australians is the performance of the Labor Party on unemployment. When youth unemployment reached 44 per cent, nearly one out of every two young Australians could not find a job under the Labor Party. And 11.2 per cent of the general population could not find a job under the so-called workers' party when they were in government. Yet this mob comes 
 into this House and lectures us about economic performance.
The Deputy Leader of the Opposition today decided that he was going to talk about a number of issues, including the current account deficit. He said, `The country is in a slide now.' The Deputy Leader of the Opposition comes into this House and talks about the country being in a slide because of the current account deficit, which came out at 6.2 per cent this week. What he conveniently forgets is that, in 1985-86 under Labor, the current account deficit was 6.5 per cent. In 1989-90 under Labor, the current account deficit was 6.5 per cent. In 1994-95 under Labor, the current account deficit was 6.5 per cent. Today it is 6.2 per cent. Do you know what was said in 1995 when the Labor Party had a current account deficit of 6.5 per cent—higher than what we have now? Ralph Willis, the then Labor Party Treasurer of Australia, came into this House and said:
It is all about improving savings. . .
The policy of the government is to improve national savings by reducing public sector dissavings.
The Labor Treasurer of Australia came into this House and said that the way to solve the current account deficit was to increase government savings. He then went out of this House and lied to the Australian people, along with the Leader of the Opposition, about the state of the government's budget. They said that it was in surplus. They told the Australian people that we had a surplus budget, yet it was $10,000 million in deficit.
Mr O'Connor interjecting—
—The honourable member for Corio will withdraw that remark.
—I will consider withdrawing the remark if the minister withdraws his imputation about the Leader of the Opposition lying about the budget deficit.
—The honourable member for Corio will withdraw unconditionally.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, in deference to your position in the chair, I 
 unreservedly withdraw and ask you to ask the minister to do the same.
—I was unsure whether the minister had actually referred to a serving member of the opposition at the time that he made that remark. That is why I allowed that to go through. I would hope that both the honourable member for Corio and the minister will take care in the comments that are made.
—The Australian people will judge him for that sort of activity. It is disingenuous. Everyone knows that the Leader of the Opposition as Minister for Finance pledged a surplus budget during the 1996 election campaign. This follows the words of the Labor Treasurer at the time saying, `The only way to solve the current account deficit is to have public sector savings, that is, run public sector surplus budgets.' The finance minister at the time ran a $10,000 million deficit. That was his solution. Over the course of two budgets, when the current Leader of the Opposition was finance minister, they ran up over $20 billion of government debt at a time when we had a current account deficit higher than it is today.
It is hypocrisy. And the Australian people can pick it a mile away. They have a great capacity to see the wood through the trees. They have a great capacity to be able to see through the rubbishy rhetoric that can come out of this place and make a value judgment about whether someone is telling the whole story. So when the Deputy Leader of the Opposition comes into this House and starts talking about major problems with the current account deficit and about the diminution of household savings, the Australian population out there—the plumbers, the doctors, the lawyers, the factory workers, the farmers, everyone—makes an assessment on how many bucks are coming into their pockets each week, whether they can pay their bills, whether their kids can get into a decent school, whether they can give their kids a holiday each year. They are the sorts of issues that Australian people make a judgment on about the performance of the economy. I ask the Labor Party to speak with Australians and ask them if the economy is in terrible shape.
It so happens that we have got the best performing economy in the world. That is not us saying that. That is every independent analyst. That is Paul Krugman from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, one of the world's leading economists; the South China Morning Post; the Wall Street Journal; the Economist; Forbes magazine; and every investment banker in New York and London and Tokyo and Hong Kong and Singapore. They are all saying that Australia's economy is the best performing economy in the world. We have done all this when our two most significant trading partners—Korea and Japan—are in recession or depression. We have done it in the middle of the worst Asian economic downturn in history.
Our trading partners have gone into depression and Australia is running the strongest economy in the world. Yet the Labor Party has the gall to come into this place and lecture us about the performance of the economy. They say, `No, no, no, we can do it a lot better.' I heard the words of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. He said, `The best way to solve Australia's problems'—which he failed to identify—`is for the government to spend more money on a range of issues.'
The solution is to spend the budget surplus—the budget surplus that has insulated us from the Asian economic downturn, the budget surplus that is repaying Labor debt, the budget surplus that has caused some political hardship on this side but we do it not because we like doing it but because we know it is in the best interests of the country. That is why we do it. The policies on this side of the House are not politically pragmatic, they are in the best interests of Australia. That is why we had the best performing economy in the world during the worst Asian economic crisis ever.
Everything the opposition Labor Party do is aimed at destroying the initiatives we put in place, whether it is taxation reform—which Australians overwhelming support and which they re-elected us with—whether it is junior wage rates, whether it is workplace relations reform, whether it is the sale of Telstra. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition comes in 
 here and says, `We want to be bipartisan on business taxation reform. Give us a look at Ralph. We will talk to you and we will give it an expedited trip through the parliament.' If they cared about Australia they would give it an expedited trip through parliament without any qualifications. Instead, as an opposition they choose to oppose everything that has been proven globally and historically to be in the best interests of our nation.
We will talk when the opposition comes in here and says, `Let us work together. We will support you guys because you have runs on the board, you have delivered the fastest growing economy in the developed world, you have delivered a better outcome for all Australians.' That is a deal. But on every occasion until now the Labor Party has shown itself to be full of hypocrisy. (Time expired)

name: Cox, David, MP
text:
—On Monday the Treasurer was finally forced to come back into this House and talk about the current account deficit. He was forced to do that because he had yet another bad current account figure. Before that, day after day, he has come in here and had a rave about how brilliantly the economy is going and a rant about how badly it went under Labor. All of the time I have been in this parliament, the one thing that he has stayed right away from talking about is the unsustainably high current account deficit. He has talked about everything except the one thing that he should be focusing on.
Is he ignoring it? Does he hope it will go away? Or worse, does he not understand it is a problem? One thing is certain, he has taken no action to reduce the current account and he offers no strategy for reducing the current account. He will wait for world economic events to realign and solve Australia's current account problem. It is an optimistic strategy for an optimistic Treasurer—or a fool in denial. Rather than adjusting policy to meet the challenge, the threat, of a high current account deficit, the opposite has been the case.
The fundamental cause of Australia's current account problem is Australia's poor domestic savings performance. In the March quarter of 1996, the last period Labor was in 
 office, the household savings ratio stood at 5.6 per cent. Now after three years with Peter Costello as Treasurer it has collapsed to 0.4 per cent.
On Monday, in one of his rare shifts from rhetoric to brief interludes of substance—and they were brief; there were only about four paragraphs that had any substance at all—the Treasurer used as an authority the FitzGerald report commissioned by Labor in 1993. Mr Costello said:
The one thing that the FitzGerald inquiry and report made clear, the one thing that the Labor Party would agree with—
and we do—
is that building public sector savings is the best thing that a government can do in the face of a current account.
This was confirmed as government policy by the Secretary to the Treasury in his post-budget Australian business economists speech, when he said:
In recent years, we have not been asking monetary policy to address the current account problem. Rather emphasis has been appropriately put on the role of fiscal policy—the generator of budget surpluses and contributor to national savings—to do that job, leaving monetary policy free to concentrate on its objective of maintaining low inflation without undue constraint on growth.
This is a very desirable balance in the use of monetary and fiscal policies which may hold part of the answer to our longstanding current account concern; it is also part of the framework which underlies the judgments on medium term growth potential.
The simultaneous achievement of sustainable CAD outcomes and low and stable inflation would be put at risk by a complacent attitude to the use of fiscal surpluses. A breakdown in the performance of one policy inevitably compromises the other.
My fear is that that complacent attitude to the use of fiscal surpluses is exactly what we are about to see with a dramatic loosening of fiscal policy provided by the Howard government's so-called new tax system. If fiscal policy is the chosen instrument to control the current account deficit, then why is the Howard government contemplating a large fiscal loosening through its tax package when the current account deficit is already historically high?
A second related question is: how sound is the surplus on which this fiscal loosening is built? Let us look at the Treasurer's $5.4 billion estimated surplus this year. In it there is a 43.2 per cent increase in dividends from government business enterprises—that is, $1.8 billion. Take that away and you have a $3.6 billion surplus. That is a very modest improvement on the 1998-99 outcome of $3.1 billion.
There are always extraordinary items in any budget or set of financial statements, but there has not been much, if any, real growth in the size of the surplus. Even after the big fiscal loosening next year with the introduction of ANTS, the surplus will be only $7.2 billion. However, when you look at the underlying cash surplus next year, that is projected to be only $3.1 billion. The principal reason for that discrepancy is the bringing forward under accrual accounting of PAYG, although the tax is paid in subsequent years. That suggests that after the introduction of ANTS the government will not be left with much latitude as far as the surplus is concerned. In his post-budget speech to the Australian business economists, the Secretary to the Treasury, Ted Evans, put all this in some historical perspective. I regret that the minister has left the chamber. Mr Evans said:
Looking at Chart 1, which shows the underlying cash balance over a long period, we see that surpluses stretch out into the projection period. We should keep in mind, however, that of the six years of surplus there shown, only one is currently behind us. The 1999-2000 surplus we could take as being reasonably assured, but beyond that we are talking about mere projections, subject to all of the uncertainties of the world economy. Taking the 1999-2000 surplus as being `in the bag', the cumulative surplus over the three years would amount to 1.5 per cent of annual GDP. The scale of that might be assessed against the surpluses in the late 1980s, our last period of fiscal consolidation. On that earlier occasion, the cumulative surplus over the first three years amounted to 4.1 per cent of annual GDP—well over twice that achieved in the latest round.
The original A New Tax System package had a negative effect on the fiscal balance of almost $5 billion. To that must now be added the further loosening resulting from the Howard government's agreement with Democrats—at least a further $1.4 billion. In my 
 view these are risks which need to be considered after eight years of continuous economic growth when loosening fiscal policy to such a significant degree in the face of a record high current account deficit. The Treasurer's explanation for the high current account deficit is entirely an external one—it is not his fault. He said on Monday:
. . . when you are running a strong domestic economy and you are in the biggest downturn of your time—meaning export values are low—you would expect pressure on your current account. We forecast it. We do not control the prices of Australian commodities.
Australia is presently operating with a current account deficit of about six per cent. A large contributing factor is the high level of domestic demand which is sustaining a higher than expected growth performance. Admitting that fact might cause the Treasurer to have to do something about it. Instead the Treasurer thinks he can forecast the current account deficit away. On Monday he said:
Why is it that we forecast the current account to come down next year? Because the international economy will pick up. The Australian growth rate will be lesser but the international economy will pick up.
What does the Treasury say about that? The first sentence of Statement 1—Fiscal Strategy—of Budget Paper No. 1, says:
The 1999-2000 Budget demonstrates the Government's commitment to maintain the budget in surplus while Australia's economic growth prospects remain sound.
The key word is `while'. What does `while economic growth remains sound' mean? It depends on whether and how far economic outcomes diverge either up or down from the budget forecast. One of the reasons for the early election last year was that the government was, at the time it was called, much more concerned about the outlook for growth this year than it seems to be now.
Statement 2—Economic Outlook—contains a section specifically dealing with risk in this year's budget papers. Weighed against doubts about the sustainability of recovery in East Asia and Japan is the possibility that the US could continue to exceed expectations. Of course, US economic performance may not continue to exceed expectations. Treasury 
 admit that the downside risk is worsening of the current account deficit should the world economy not pick up. On the other hand, we must also look at the upside risks. If growth is stronger than expected, particularly if the contributing factor is higher than expected US economic growth and even a  monetary tightening there which would be combined with the impact of the government's loosening of fiscal policy with its raid on the surplus and some additional inflationary pressure, including from the GST, then pressure on the current account will be higher than would otherwise have been the case and the momentary authorities may have to decide that interest rates will have to go up. This concern was raised in a Senate estimates committee by the Secretary to the Treasury earlier this year.
The high current account deficit means this is not a good time to loosen fiscal policy in the manner prescribed by the renegotiated ANTS package. Australia is presently operating with a current account of six per cent. It has only had to do so three times previously in Australia's recent economic history. The first time was in 1986, and resulted in a currency crisis. The second time was in 1989-90, and it was corrected with monetary policy which resulted in recession. The third time was at the beginning of 1995. That was, however, controlled without crisis by intelligent use of both fiscal and monetary policy. On that occasion we recognised we had a problem, we told the markets and the public we had a problem, and we took appropriate corrective action on both the fiscal and monetary fronts. Let us hope that this current account deficit can be moderated without crisis.
It is certainly the case, as was demonstrated in 1995, that as a result of the economic reforms of the last Labor government Australia is much less vulnerable to external shocks than was previously the case. However, without an appropriate policy response there is a significant risk that there could be a rapid market response with implications for the rest of the economy. (Time expired)

name: Cadman, Alan, MP
text:
—I can only interpret the remarks of the previous speaker as being a call for an increase in the 
 interest rates. That is all I can see that Labor Party policy comprises—increase interest rates and release the Wallis report. What a policy you have: Australia living on more reports produced by the ALP and putting up interest rates. They are familiar with that story. They know those policies and they have rejected them. That was the whole theme of the address to the House by the previous speaker, as it was the theme of the shadow Treasurer. Sure, if one goes back over a period of time, one sees that during the Labor Party's time in office Australians did save. But we have to look at what they are doing now. They are not saving now. Why is that? I just looked at the statistics put out by the ABS, and I find that they are wealthier. How can they be wealthier if they are not saving? They are investing. That is why they are wealthier. They are investing.
I refer the House to the statistics that are freely available to any member that wants to gets them. It just so happens that the Australian Labor Party has not chosen to draw on the full range of statistics. It is strange, isn't it, that it should half-tell the story? If one looks at what the average Australian citizen has done over the period of the past few years, one will see that during the mid-1990s, before the election of the current government and during 1996 and half of 1997, Australian families saved. They saved because they were concerned about the future. They did not know what was going to happen to interest rates and were uncertain about their jobs, and so they put some money away for a rainy day—very sensible people, the Australian people.
If the Australian Labor Party ever learnt to trust them, they would know that they can learn a lot from their average fellow citizens. So, when things were uncertain, what do the statistics show? That Australian people, Australian families, were actually saving. They were putting money away because interest rates were uncertain and because they were unsure of their jobs. And they did not trust the current government either, for the first 12 months, to put interest rates down and keep them down. They were uncertain about whether we would create jobs as well. And so 
 for 18 months after the election of the current government they kept saving.
But from that point on they started to release their savings, and what do you know has happened? If you look at the value of the average Australian household and the value of unincorporated enterprises in Australia—which is the way we measure households—their wealth is increasing. Analyse the statistics, my friend. It is so easy to do. I know that the chief whip does this all the time in his spare moments. He understands the Australian people. He understands what they are doing and he understands the fact that they are not saving. Where is their money going? It is going into dwellings, superannuation and investments—into things like Telstra, with record sales.
Australia is a high investment owning nation now, and that started about three years ago. As people relaxed and knew that the unemployment figures were coming down and that they could depend on the government to retain low interest rates, and as they learnt to trust that we would stick to what we had actually promised, they started to do other things with their money. Instead of squirreling it away at 1.5 per cent or two per cent in a bank savings account, they put it into something that was going to be of real benefit to their future. They put it into new homes or into expanding their homes. They put it into renovations and additions. They put it into superannuation for their retirement. It was far more important to them in many instances than having holidays was, to make sure that their retirement was safe.
They also invested in great institutions. They put it into shares: into Telstra and even into the Commonwealth Bank—which you said you would not sell but which you proceeded to sell. Surprise, surprise! Another promise broken. The Australian Labor Party encouraged people, by that hypocrisy it put on the Australian people at the time, into investing in institutions. So what have we got? We have got a completely changed scene in Australia. We have got families who are now more certain of their future because they know what their home payments are going to be. They know that they can borrow to extend 
 their mortgages to buy a new house and to do renovations. They know that their job is secure and that they will be able to continue to save for their retirement with superannuation. They also know that, if they continue to invest in the great Australian institutions, they will benefit by that ultimately.
—Where do you live?
—Look, my friend, just read up on the statistics. The ABS can tell you everything. If you just pull out the statistics, I think even the simplest of the members opposite will be able to see for themselves the way that this government has changed the whole outlook of the Australian community. It is very interesting to read the press about the Labor Party's attitudes. I refer to the press of 24 August and the report of your caucus room. You do not like being told about your caucus room, but the report in the press says that Mr Beazley told Labor MPs and senators that a lot of voters could see that the economy was going well but believed that they were missing out on that success.
He referred to some polling, we are told, which showed the confidence that is in Canberra by politicians and said that their confidence in the economy is not necessarily reflected out there in voterland—as a caucus spokesman told reporters. The caucus spokesman went on to say that Mr Beazley made a point that Costello's comments about there being sufficient in the surplus two or three years out to consider further tax cuts was a good omen from the point of view of the Labor Party, and that meant they might not be hamstrung in terms of the limitations of the budget, assuming they won the next election, than they thought they might have been.
There you have it: a big spending idea of, `We hope they have got a real nest egg for us to get into if we should be elected at the next election.' It is out there in print. Fancy saying that in public. It will be quoted back to you, my friend, time and time again during the next election that you want the nest egg to fritter away and waste again. You will get into the hard-won savings of the Australian people and you will waste them. You will increase interest rates, because that was the 
 argument here today. Higher interest rates was the call from your front bench today.
Not only was it a call for higher interest rates but it was a call for irresponsibility as far as the savings of the Australian people are concerned. They are wealthier now. They have more assets than they have ever had before, because they can now trust the government with interest rates and with jobs. They have made that investment, they have made that decision and they will continue to support the Australian government that they have today.
Let us go back through some of the statements of the Australian Labor Party over a period of the last week or so, because it seems to be that the call consistently for the past four or five months has been from the front bench to say, `Things are in a mess; you need to make a change.' At the time that the Labor Party leadership is saying that things are in a mess, Australians are investing in shares, in superannuation and in housing. That is because they are confident. If you want to spiral down confidence, I guess that you have to keep saying that things are in a mess. Mr Crean and Mr Beazley have been consistently saying that over the last few months.
I take the House back to 1 June, when the opposition spokesman, Mr Crean, said that the Treasurer should take his eyes off the changes to taxation and focus on Australia's deficit. For goodness sake! If anything is going to encourage the accumulation of wealth and assets and a sense of security, it is going to be a better tax system. So here is Crean, the shadow Treasurer, calling on the Treasurer to take his eyes off tax cuts.
Then just yesterday Mr Beazley said that we were paying a big penalty for our private savings—the same argument we have had here today. He did not look at where they are putting their money. They are putting it elsewhere. They are not saving it because they are confident and they have certainty. Mr Beazley on 24 August said that Australia has become a credit card economy depending on foreign savings and that the government is to blame. What a joke that is! He has not looked at any of the statistics. He has not looked at the real economy. He has not looked at what 
 the small investors are doing. He has not looked at what the mums and dads are doing. He has not looked at what small business is doing.
The Labor Party will never get into government if they continue to talk the economy down in that way. There has to be more substance to it than that, because the facts are not there. You have only to go through the basic statistics. I am sure that the Australian Labor Party would learn if they would only listen to the way the Australian people think. So, despite the talking down of the economy, despite this credit card talk of the Leader of the Opposition, the facts are quite different. The facts are that Australians have never been better off, they have never been more wealthy, they have never had better incomes and they have never had better job certainty. (Time expired)
—Order! The discussion has concluded.

name: Nehl, Garry, MP
text:
—I present the amended report of the Selection Committee relating to the consideration of committee and delegation reports and private members business on Monday, 20 September 1999. Copies of the report have been circulated to honourable members in the chamber.
Report—by leave—adopted.
The report read as follows—
Amended report relating to the consideration of committee and delegation reports and private Members' business on Monday, 20 September 1999
The Selection Committee has amended its determinations relating to the order of precedence and times to be allotted for consideration of committee and delegation reports and private Members' business on Monday, 20 September 1999. The amended order of precedence and allotments of time determined by the Committee are shown in the list.
COMMITTEE AND DELEGATION REPORTS
Presentation and statements
1	 AUSTRALIAN PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO THE 7TH ANNUAL MEETING OF 
 THE ASIA PACIFIC PARLIAMENTARY FORUM, LIMA PERU:  Report on the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to the 7th annual meeting of the Asia Pacific Parliamentary Forum, Lima, Peru, 11-14 January 1999.
The Committee determined that statements on the report may be made—all statements to be made within a total time of 15 minutes.
Speech time limits—
Each Member—5 minutes.
2	 ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER AFFAIRS—STANDING COMMITTEE:  Video explaining the Committee's report "Unlocking the Future: The report on the review of the Reeves Report on the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 ".
The Committee determined that statements on the video may be made—all statements to be made within a total time of 1 minute.
Speech time limit—
First Member speaking—1 minute.
3	 INDUSTRY, SCIENCE AND RESOURCES—STANDING COMMITTEE:  Report on the effect of certain public policy changes on Australia's R & D.
The Committee determined that statements on the report may be made—all statements to be made within a total time of 15 minutes.
Speech time limits—
First Member speaking—10 minutes.
Other Members—5 minutes each.
PRIVATE MEMBERS' BUSINESS
Order of precedence
Notices
1	 Mr Albanese  to present a bill for an act to establish an Aviation Noise Ombudsman and for related purposes. (Notice given 30 August 1999. )
Presenter may speak for a period not exceeding 5 minutes—pursuant to sessional order 104A.
2Ms Irwin  to move—That the House:
(1)	 notes the failure of the Howard Government's Tough on Drugs Strategy, in particular, that after two years there has been:
(a)	 an increase in drug use, with the average age of first users decreasing;
(b)	 no significant decline in the amount of illicit drugs entering Australia, even after a number of high profile "busts";
(c)	 inadequate funding for community-based programs in those areas of greatest need, particularly the south-west of Sydney; and
(d)	 a lack of evidence that zero tolerance policies have achieved anything other than 
 making the illicit drug trade the world's fastest growing industry; and
(2)	 calls on the Government to take a more effective and creative approach to stemming the social tragedy being caused by the increasing use of heroin and other dangerous, addictive and illicit drugs. (Notice given 24 August 1999. )
Time allotted—remaining private Members' business time prior to 1.45 p.m.
Speech time limits—
Each Member—5 minutes.
The Committee determined that consideration of this matter should continue on a future day.
3Mr Pyne  To move—That the House:
(1)	 reaffirms the fundamental principles of human rights that must be practised by the entire international community;
(2)	 condemns the false arrest and imprisonment of thirteen Iranian Jews on spurious espionage charges; and
