That other sectors of education—universities, TAFEs and senior secondary—continue to fail to assist their primary school colleagues and their school communities in securing a higher level of allocation of resources is highly regrettable. That they continue to do this against their own future interests—because these primary students will all become TAFE, senior secondary or university students at some time in the future—is simply beyond my comprehension. For some reason, those sectors have been convinced that a fair deal for young children in resources means fewer resources for their particular sector, and they have behaved accordingly over the last 20 years.
That is just gross irresponsibility. The overwhelming majority of these young children will in fact take their place at senior secondary, TAFE and university level at some time in the future. There are many examples of those three sectors criticising governments for taking on short-term goals, and we have had evidence of that almost every year for the past 20 years. But, in this instance, they are guilty of exactly the same offence.
Why is there no effective voice in this country to defend and promote the interests of young children? It seems that it does not matter what is discussed—whether it be education, drugs, literacy and numeracy, family relationships or whatever—when the subject of the debate is children aged between five and 15 no-one is seriously interested. Take drugs, for example. Governments around the world are struggling to deal with the drug problem in their communities. At the risk of causing offence to others who have occupied this House, I suggest that no government has embarked upon a serious drug education program in this country.
It is well known that prevention is always far cheaper and far more effective than cure. It is also well known that the attributes and skills of our young are largely acquired between the ages of seven and 12. If our efforts with that age group fail, then no program, no amount of money, no amount of bleating and no amount of rhetoric and grandstanding will solve the problems that drugs and dysfunctional behaviour are causing in our communities.
Who in this House could identify a business, a union, a welfare group, a religious or community group or a teaching or political organisation that reflects accurately the needs of our developing young and does something positive about it? Absolute silence would greet that particular question. What happens in this country is a deliberate demeaning of any need expressed by any group of people trying to address the primary needs of young children. It is something to be greatly ashamed of and something which started very badly 20 years ago, and we are paying for the consequences now. This is a generational 
 negligence. The negligence is demonstrated a generation down the track.
The literacy and numeracy problem among young children should not be a partisan matter. It is a matter of national importance and should be treated as such. But the failure to do so has allowed the problem to become progressively worse. In 1979, it was largely accepted that 10 per cent of children had grave literacy and numeracy problems. In the late 1980s, the figure was 20 per cent. Now, in the late 1990s, it is 30 per cent. It is an escalating problem and it is about time that serious action was taken to turn it around. Bureaucrats have fudged their findings because they have averaged out the top 20 per cent of students, who over the past 20 years have done progressively very well indeed.
The problem for the non-achievers has got progressively worse. The question is how much longer parents and grandparents will have to put up with an inadequate response to literacy, numeracy and other resource implication problems for young children in this nation. The answer is at least until the removal of the Howard government—and maybe a few state governments along the way—if the trivial provisions in this bill are any indication of their intentions.
The bill also makes provision for the continued funding of the National Asian Languages and Studies in Australian Schools Strategy, an initiative of the previous Labor government. Labor instigated this program because it understood just how important it is for the future of this country that young people develop a better understanding of our near neighbours, including a competence in their languages. But the irony is that, while on one hand the government is encouraging young people to take up the study of foreign languages, on the other hand it is doing virtually nothing towards helping them gain a better grasp of their own language.
It should be obvious that if they are unable to operate effectively in their own language then it is so much harder to learn to speak a foreign language. With grave literacy and numeracy problems on the rise, the study of foreign languages and the job opportunities it gives rise to is becoming an impossible goal 
 for an increasing number of our young people. Perhaps if the world language were Russian or Chinese, then governments in Australia might do something serious about literacy and numeracy inadequacies amongst our young. But, with English being the language of politics, finance and trade, we continue to delude ourselves about the failings of the education system in Australia.
Everyone in this House knows that those countries in our region and in Europe which have enjoyed great success in recent years have committed gross amounts of national gross domestic product back into massive investment in education, and they did it a generation ago. The latest figures I examined, which compared the investment in education by countries in the OECD, placed Australia right down near the bottom of the list. This fact does not seem to have registered with state governments and the current federal government, and that is a cause of great national shame.
While the federal government must take the primary responsibility for this situation, the problem is endemic right across the country. Religious, other private schools and institutions also fail to acknowledge the differential resources between primary, secondary and further education. Business, union, welfare and other organisations still fail to acknowledge the needs of children in primary school. Until this outlook changes, until a more appropriate allocation of resources is achieved, the problems we are facing in this  nation with our young will simply get worse. Unfortunately, this bill will do very little to address what is becoming a very grave problem in this country, and one that will harm our collective future. (Time expired)
debate_title: <title>STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1999</title>

name: May, Margaret, MP
text:
—Contrary to what the member for Port Adelaide says, this government has not missed the point with regard to funding for literacy and numeracy programs. It is not just going through the motions. I commend the Howard government's steps to ensure that Australian youth are equipped with the necessary reading and writing skills. In this modern age, if you cannot read or write it is very difficult to hold down a job. It is like when the starter's gun 
 goes and you cannot get your feet out of the starter's block—you cannot move, your feet are caught. You cannot progress. You cannot even start the race, let alone reach the finishing line.
Research shows that young Australians who have poor literacy and numeracy skills are more likely to leave school early. They also have poor access to further education and training and are at much higher risk of unemployment. Acquiring literacy and numeracy skills has been proven to reduce people's risk of unemployment by boosting their ability to participate in education. Acquiring literacy and numeracy skills improves one's ability to successfully participate in the work force, and acquiring literacy and numeracy skills enables one to make decisions in life.
In the past, many young people could leave school early and get a semiskilled or unskilled job. Nowadays these jobs do not exist. Jobs have shifted as the second half of the 20th century has seen the explosive growth in communications and information technologies. The reality is that society has changed. We are moving into a society which is driven by technology and requires higher literacy skills. While at school, the experiences a child gains shape his or her skills, attitudes and knowledge. As a government, we have a responsibility to ensure that each Australian child has the opportunity to acquire literacy and numeracy skills.
Dr David Kemp, the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, said last week in this chamber that improving the literacy and numeracy levels of young Australians is probably the single most important thing you could do to assist the educationally disadvantaged people in this country. As a mother of three adult children who had tremendous opportunities in the government school system, I am a strong advocate of ensuring that every child is given the best chance to fulfil his or her potential and that each child has access to educational programs and resources to acquire the skills he or she needs for their future.
I strongly support any government measures to ensure our children do not miss out on opportunities but are given the best chances 
 for success in life. The  States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1999  reflects the coalition government's concern with literacy and numeracy achievements of Australia's school students. Literacy and numeracy have been a concern of the Howard government since coming to office, and Dr Kemp has played a tremendous role in ensuring Australia has a clear direction and goals for a national approach to literacy and numeracy.
This government, for the first time, has put into place a comprehensive range of programs which are opening up for young people horizons and opportunities which they were denied for the 13 years that the Labor Party was in office. We now have a national plan to make sure that every child coming out of primacy school has the foundation skills for life. The governments of the states, the territories and the Commonwealth have committed themselves for the first time to national literacy standards, to a system of comparable testing for young children and to a national goal that every young person coming out of primary school should be able to read, write and spell at an adequate level.
This plan follows the government bringing together the best experts in Australia to tell us what level of literacy skills children need to have at the end of year 3, at the end of those early years of schooling, to continue successfully through their schooling. Out of this we put in place the national literacy standards. We conducted the first national literacy survey. We analysed the results against those standards and found that 30 per cent of young Australians in year 3 were below that standard.
The Commonwealth has agreed with the states that every child in the government system will be assessed against that standard and that they will report those results from year to year so that we can see whether every child is coming up to the standard. Following further negotiations with ministers, we have had another victory for Australian youth and their parents, with the standardising of primary school literacy tests across state borders to ensure that every young child acquires the 
 literacy skills to enable them to read at the national standard.
Since the beginning of last month, the states and territories have engaged in assessments of young people in years 3 and 5 against the national literacy benchmarks. As a result of these measures in developing a regime of comparable testing against benchmark standards, for the first time school children in Australia are being assessed as to whether or not they meet literacy standards and whether or not they have the skills to continue successfully with their education. As Dr Kemp said last week in the chamber:
Parents have a right to this information. Young people have a right to learn to read and write effectively.
The additional funding allocated through this legislation is a positive step in improving the literacy and numeracy skills of students in the early and middle years of schooling.
A significant point I wish to make is that the legislation focuses on middle years of schooling. In the past, those years have not been addressed to such an extent as this. By `middle years of schooling', we refer to students in upper primary and secondary school through to year 10. In the past the coalition government has focused on numeracy and literacy standards in the early years of schooling and in the final years through the Full Service Schools Program, which caters for students who are at risk of not completing school or who have returned to school through mutual obligation requirements.
The legislation currently before the parliament takes into account those students in middle schooling. An amount of $47.1 million over four years will be provided for strategies to improve the literacy and numeracy skills of underachieving students in the middle years of schooling. The funding will be directed towards students who have not developed basic literacy and numeracy skills and who, therefore, have difficulty coping with the demands of the school curriculum. Literacy and numeracy support for such students will reduce the risk of unemployment by increasing their ability to participate in education and training and improve their ability to successfully participate in the work force.
The allocated funding is, in a sense, a completion of the government's policy focus on literacy and numeracy. It recognises that there is a need for support for improved literacy and numeracy achievement throughout schooling, particularly for those students who miss out on acquiring adequate skills in their early years of schooling. Ensuring that our children have adequate literacy and numeracy skills is vitally important in the education equation. As I mentioned earlier, research shows that those without these skills increase their risk of unemployment. Our unemployment rate is the lowest it has been in decades—7.2 per cent. The coalition government is committed to lowering this rate even further. I believe it is through programs like those of literacy and numeracy that we will ensure our youth have adequate skills for the workplace.
Australia is a bountiful nation by any measure, including where I live on the Gold Coast, the nation's sixth largest city and arguably the nation's tourist capital. We are also rich in our diversity of people. Programs such as those of literacy and numeracy enhance opportunities for our youth and allow us to best prepare for the future. While in Japan recently at a lunch hosted by Japanese business organisations, the Prime Minister announced his intention that Australia become a can-do country. These simple words formed headlines in many of our Australian newspapers the following day. While they are simple words, they convey a tremendous amount about the will of the Australian people and the government's determination to ensure that Australians have a fertile ground in which to achieve their potential, whether it be through innovative business opportunity or fast growing industries such as biotechnology.
Programs of literacy and numeracy are in line with the Prime Minister's vision to create a can-do country; literacy and numeracy programs parallel this vision. I would go so far as to say that the Australian government is taking steps to ensure that, as a government, we foster the development of can-do children so that, when they are ready to exit school, they have acquired adequate literacy and numeracy skills.
The additional capital grants funding which forms part of this legislation is another real example of the coalition government's commitment to education in this nation. This funding for non-government schools is a continuation of the government's commitment to maintain funding at current, real levels. Likewise, the National Asian Languages and Studies in Australian Schools strategy is a forward thinking program, designed to equip our youth for the future. Asia is important to Australia and will continue to be so. This strategy goes far in supporting our links to key regional neighbours including China, Indonesia, Japan and Korea.
Under this strategy, by the year 2006, 60 per cent of students in years 3 to 10 will be learning one of the four targeted languages—that is, Chinese, Indonesian, Japanese and Korean. The remaining 40 per cent will be learning other languages. Fifteen per cent of year 12 students will be learning one of the four targeted languages, and another 10 per cent of year 12 students will be learning other languages. All school students in years 3 to 10 will have Asia content incorporated into the subjects that they are studying.
This legislation extends funding to the National Asian Languages and Studies in Australian Schools Strategy. The Commonwealth, states and territories have endorsed this strategy and its associated targets until 2006. If we do not continue with this strategy, I firmly believe it will be to the detriment of Australia in the medium to long term. Many leading authors and foreign affairs experts, including Professor Stephen FitzGerald, Australia's first Ambassador to China, have argued the point that, if Australian children are not educated about our Asian neighbours, we will be left behind in the next millennium as we participate in the global economy.
This legislation takes funding for the strategy to the end of 2002. Including this funding, the Commonwealth will have provided $207 million to support the study of Asian languages and studies since the commencement of this strategy in 1994-95. This is a tremendous indication that we are committed to educating our Australian youth to ensure that Australia is in the best position to work 
 with our Asian neighbours to benefit our nation in the 21st century.
I commend the government's plans in allocating this funding in a move designed to develop students' understanding of Asian languages and cultures so that tomorrow's work force is well placed to participate in the global economy. Our children will be the winners out of the  States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1999 . They will become better equipped with the vital skills of reading, writing and counting that will better prepare them for the decisions they will make in life. They will also be better prepared for participating in the global economy.
The government's renewed commitment to literacy and numeracy and expanding education programs for our youth is an indication that the coalition is responding to the education needs of our young students. It is an indication that the coalition is determined to ensure that we have equity in our schools and attention is paid to the needs of students likely to be educationally disadvantaged. The policies this government is putting forward will create jobs for young Australians. I commend this bill to the House.
debate_title: <title>STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1999</title>

name: Emerson, Craig, MP
text:
—In the time allocated to me this evening I want to address two major issues in connection with the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1999 . The first is the very severe doubt that has been cast over an election promise from the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Dr Kemp, to improve the quality of schoolteachers in Australia through the National Professional Development Program. The second is the entire area of literacy and numeracy—where we are heading in improving literacy and numeracy in Australia.
In relation to the first issue, I would be very interested if the minister could explain to the House and the people of Australia whether he intends to keep the promise he made to improve the quality of teaching in Australian schools or whether he has in fact scrapped that 1998 election promise. This bill was an ideal opportunity to include the commitments made by the minister in the lead-up to the 
 1998 election. Going back to the 1996 election campaign, the Howard government promised not to abolish Labor's Professional Development Program, but they did abolish it. I refer to a statement contained on page 2 of the `1996 Coalition Schools and TAFE Policy', which says:
A Coalition Government will continue the National Professional Development Program.
Obviously, this was a non-core promise. Just a couple of years later, in the 1998 election campaign, they realised their mistake and promised to restore the program. Here I refer to page 10 of the `1998 Coalition Schools Policy', which says:
The Coalition will provide $75 million over three years to strengthen the skills of the teaching profession.
If the minister plans to keep this promise, he must explain to us why there is no money in the schools legislation that is now before this parliament and how he will meet his promise that `program activities will commence at the beginning of 2000'. That statement was contained in the minister's press release of 11 May this year. How can those program activities commence at the beginning of the year 2000 if there is no provision in the legislation for that funding? It is an ideal opportunity lost. We would be very interested in the minister's explanation on this matter.
I want to now spend some time discussing the second issue of literacy and numeracy. This legislation allocates $36.3 million for the year 2000 to increase funding under the literacy and numeracy program, especially for the middle years. So there is a special program to boost literacy and numeracy in the middle years. This is obviously something that we support. We think it is terrific that there is an increase in funding for literacy and numeracy, and we do not really have any difficulty with the concentration on the middle years. However, I do question, very gravely, the adequacy of funding for literacy and numeracy under this government.
A very significant statement was made in March 1997 by the Commonwealth, state and territory education ministers. They agreed to the national literacy goal that every child leaving primary school should be numerate 
 and be able to read, write and spell at an appropriate level. That is an admirable goal and one to which all members of the House of Representatives would be committed. However, my concern is that the minister is spending a lot of time trying to create some sort of political row over this issue of increasing literacy and numeracy in Australia—more for the sake of his own self-aggrandisement and getting himself on programs such as 60 Minutes, and less fortunately for him Four Corners. He is trying to fabricate some sort of fracas so that he can say, `I am the hero and the rest of you are the bad guys.' That is simply not true.
In fact, in early August of this year there was a historic announcement by the state and territory governments of New South Wales, South Australia, Victoria, Queensland and the ACT that they would undertake nationally comparable literacy testing. That announcement has everything to do with a sensible, bipartisan, cooperative approach based on the basic skills test introduced by the New South Wales Labor government 12 years ago and nothing at all to do with the minister's bullying and grandstanding. My colleague the shadow minister for education and member for Dobell earlier in this debate very eloquently pointed to the deficiencies and criticisms of the minister in his grandstanding on this matter. I will simply repeat a number of the statements that have been made about the minister's behaviour—not by Labor state ministers but by the Liberal Minister for Education in Victoria, Phil Gude. He said, among other things, in the Herald Sun on 12 May 1997:
Literacy is our highest priority and, despite Dr Kemp undermining the previous collaborative process, we are determined this important process goes ahead.
Next, Mr Gude, in the Herald Sun  on 15 September 1997, said:
He ought to do the right thing . . . own up to the fact that he's manipulated the figures in a most dishonest and disgraceful fashion.
Then Mr Gude, in the Age  on 16 September 1997, said:
It is a debate that has hit the public arena as a result of political grandstanding by Dr Kemp. 

The Liberal Minister for Education has exposed the federal Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs for what he is: someone who is content with grandstanding and creating division around this issue instead of using a collaborative approach. We should not be surprised about this, because the Prime Minister was very happy with the entry of the current Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs into the parliament. Mr Deputy Speaker, you may recall that the current minister took over from the then sitting member for Goldstein, Mr Ian Macphee, in 1990. Mr Ian Macphee would be generally regarded as a wet, someone with a genuine social conscience. He was preselected out of that seat by the present minister.
I see the present minister as being someone from a long line of punishers and straighteners. He is more concerned with punishing kids and schools where there are real difficulties and funding problems. He has said publicly on a number of occasions that his own idea of a literacy and numeracy program is to have a national list of the schools, which then puts the students in those schools in the position of being shamed. What he really wants is a shaming list. Why does he want that? Because it makes great headlines in the tabloid newspapers, in radio interviews and on television. You get the television cameras and say, `The kids in these schools are illiterate and innumerate. Isn't this a terrible thing?' That is not a constructive approach to education and addressing a vital issue in this country, an issue that goes to the heart of inequality.
The member for Curtin and I will be sharing a platform at the Sydney Institute on 6 October, where we will be talking on the issue of inequality. Going to the heart of inequality is the problem of literacy and numeracy in Australia. What is the minister's approach to it? `We'll get a list, and we'll expose the schools that are performing poorly, and then we can get the media and get photographs of the kids.' There is nothing more despicable, in my mind, than that sort of approach. That is self-aggrandisement and promotion on the part of the minister but absolutely devastating for the kids involved.
The states have got their act together: they have been doing literacy and numeracy testing for a number of years—the Victorian government for 12 years. In my state of Queensland, they have been doing that since the mid-1990s, when funding was provided by the then Goss government for a literacy and numeracy program called the Year 2 Diagnostic Net. It is working extremely well. However it could do with a greatly increased influx of funding. The Year 2 Diagnostic Net identifies the kids who are having difficulties in reading and writing, and then a Reading Recovery program follows for those children so they get the intensive assistance—which is costly—to enable them to boost their literacy and numeracy.
The results are tremendous. After the Reading Recovery program, more than 90 per cent of the children who are identified in the Year 2 Diagnostic Net in Queensland have been brought up to the appropriate level of reading and writing for their age. This is a tremendous result, made possible by the foresight of the Goss government and by the funding the Goss government provided. Here, I give credit where credit is due: the Borbidge government continued the funding for that program. Now the Beattie government has continued the funding and is applying additional resources. It is a very encouraging situation in Queensland. It is a less encouraging situation in Victoria where, I am advised, the state government has very substantially reduced the number of teachers. That then detracts from the intensive support that the children who are identified through these literacy and numeracy testing programs are able to receive.
We do not need punishers and straighteners when it comes to literacy and numeracy and looking after the future of our children. We need expanders and creators. Sadly, the minister is neither an expander nor a creator. But that is the sort of approach that we need. In this budget, in the vital area of education, it is regrettable to report that the government has provided less than $10 a year of extra funding to the children in government schools. The minister likes to incorporate in his figures an adjustment for the cost of living 
 and then say, `See—we're providing more money.' That is not more real resources. At a time which is absolutely vital to Australia's future, kids in government schools are receiving an extra $10 a year from this government. Yet, through its enrolment benchmark adjustment, the Commonwealth government has presided over a $21.1 million cut to funding for government schools. In my home state of Queensland, there has been a lift in enrolments between 1996 and 1998 of 9,351 students and a commensurate curtailment of funding of $3.5 million through the enrolment benchmark adjustment. What are the priorities of this government when they cut funding to government schools through the enrolment benchmark adjustment?
As my colleague the member for Dobell, the shadow minister for education, mentioned earlier in this debate, if the Prime Minister of Australia had maintained the previous government's investment in education and research—that is, the Labor government's investment in education and research—at three per cent of gross domestic product, which is where it was when this government assumed office, Australia would be spending an extra $2.87 billion on education and research. Tragically, we are seeing a very substantial reduction in the investment in the future of this country and the investment in education and research.
This should not really surprise us. On 2 March 1987, when he was under siege from the Joh for PM campaign, the Prime Minister boasted proudly in an interview with John Laws in these terms:
Everybody who knows me knows that I am the most conservative leader the Liberal Party has ever had.
There was never a truer statement, and he is at least as conservative today as he was then. That statement was made within weeks of a declaration by the Prime Minister that he would take a scalpel to Medicare and pull it right apart. He was beaten badly at that poll and decided that he needed to rescind that policy, but he has put a very large nick in the vein supplying funding to Medicare, and it is bleeding to death. He is still achieving his objective there.
On industrial relations legislation, it is the same thing. His long cherished goal was to tip the balance in favour of employers over employees. Now we have the second wave of industrial relations legislation designed to do precisely that. Going back to his days as Treasurer, his other long cherished objective was for a GST. It has been a long time coming as far as he is concerned, but from 1 July next year we will have a GST. Yet on the fundamental issues of closing the loopholes and repairing the income tax base through the fringe benefits tax, capital gains tax and foreign tax credit system, the current Prime Minister described those taxes in debates in the parliament as `nasty', `stupid' and `madness'. There we have the attitude of the current Prime Minister and the attitude of the current Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs. They come from the same stable. They boast about how conservative they are, and they are right.
The future of federal-state relations is brought sharply into question through the legislation that has been through this parliament in relation to the tax package, the sorts of funding arrangements that are contained here and what will happen to those arrangements from 1 July next year. From 1 July next year, the untied grants from the Commonwealth to the states will not be reduced or diminished but will be abolished in their entirety. Eighteen billion dollars will be gone because the states are going to get the GST. It has been made quite clear that there are no guarantees from the Commonwealth about ongoing funding in the tied grants to the states after the so-called GST transition period. That transition period may be three or four years, but Treasury officials made it quite clear to their state counterparts at the most recent Premiers Conference that there are no guarantees on funding for the tied grants.
What are the tied grants spent on? They are spent on literacy and numeracy programs. Australia is confronting the prospect of having those tied grants, including literacy and numeracy programs, cut back or abolished after the so-called GST transition period. Our fears about that were compounded 
 the other day when the Treasurer declared, `I am an income tax cut man.' He wants to continually reduce the top marginal rate of income tax. He said a few weeks before that that he would like to see the top rate pushed out to many multiples of average weekly earnings. A couple of weeks ago, he said, `I am an income tax cut man. We've got to get that top rate down.' That is how they are going to finance it—they will keep reducing the top rate of income tax and providing extra income tax relief for high income earners, funded by cuts in these vital literacy and numeracy services through the tied grants to the states.
The country's future is in the balance when we are faced with these sorts of choices. People say, `What really is the difference between Labor and the coalition?' There are fundamental differences, but nothing more fundamental than the commitment of Labor to invest in the nation's future. What is the nation's future? It is our children. I have three children. I want to see them succeed. There are children in Logan City who would love to get some extra support at school in literacy and numeracy through home visiting, parenting programs and so on.
All of these possibilities are open to us, and the funding can be identified, except we are facing a choice between the government's risky tax scheme or Labor's commitment to provide affordable basic services. The Labor commitment is to provide decent, affordable services in the form of education of our kids and investment in the nation's future in research and development. That is the choice that we are looking at. That is the choice that will clearly be put in front of the Australian people at the next election: either further income tax cuts and a risky tax scheme or an investment in the nation's future by the Labor Party. (Time expired)
debate_title: <title>STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1999</title>

name: Bishop, Julie, MP
text:
—There could be few greater gifts to a young child than the opportunity to have an early and successful start to learning to read. If children are provided with the right literacy and reading experiences in their early years and learn to read, they will go on to read to learn. To introduce young children to lan 
 guage and literature at an early age so that they learn to read successfully is to open a world of adventure to them, to feed their appetites for learning, wondering and living, as the member for Rankin rightly acknowledges. I look forward to our shared platform at the Sydney Institute on these issues on 6 October.
The supreme importance of positive literacy, language and reading experiences for young children must surely be acknowledged as setting the stage for useful and productive citizenship in later years. Reading is indeed learned. It therefore must be taught, supported and sustained. Reading does not come naturally, as speech does. Reading the English language requires understanding of the alphabetic writing system. There has been research at national and international levels to support the view that effective classroom instruction in the early grades by well-prepared teachers is the most powerful method for preventing reading and learning problems. The most effective classroom method for early reading, so the experts say, involves a combination of explicit instruction in word recognition skills and reading comprehension strategies with opportunities to practise these skills in literature.
The importance of a progressive and effective education system cannot be overstated. Our education system is the vehicle by which our young people learn many of the skills that will ultimately take them into the work force or into further education and training. Our education system should be the best it can be, constantly looking forward with new ideas and measures to provide the maximum opportunities for our young people in the increasingly competitive Australian and global labour market.
I have spoken of the need for literacy skills. Numeracy skills are no less important. The ability to have a good basic understanding of mathematics is no less applicable in our information age of highly sophisticated computerisation. To prepare for further education, for employment or for everyday activities, our young people require basic numeracy skills. Mastering the challenge of mathematics for success in higher education is one thing, 
 but basic mathematics can teach a way of thinking that will apply in every workplace and is essential for informed civic participation.
We need numeracy skills to understand a daily newspaper, to pay taxes, to invest for the future and to participate in any community activities where budget decisions are made. Whether a young person aims to be a mechanic and needs to apply physics formulae to wire electrical circuits for today's cars, whether they aim to be a research scientist in the biotechnology industry or whether they want to work in a retail store, their introduction to numeracy skills in early school years will help set their path. Mastering basic mathematical concepts or more complex approaches to solving problems will prepare young people for the careers of the 21st century as well as the demands of everyday life.
Possibly one of the most important policy decisions by this government in terms of education has been the focus on literacy and numeracy. This focus has extended from early school years now to middle school years and, in the context of employment policy, as an aspect of mutual obligation. Reading, writing and basic numeracy are amongst the most essential skills one needs in order to get ahead in life. The absence of such skills is a distinct disadvantage in today's competitive job market.
With the emerging digital world and its driving force in the economic wellbeing of our nation, we must ensure that Australians have the necessary information tools and skills which will be crucial to their participation in the information technology age. In the 21st century, our work force will need to be technology literate. We must not allow anyone to be left behind because we did not give them the opportunity to get the fundamentals right in their early schooling. This government recognises the importance of literacy and numeracy and has done something about it. In March 1997, Commonwealth, state and territory education ministers agreed to a national literacy goal that every child leaving primary school should be numerate and able 
 to read, write and spell at an appropriate level.
The  States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1999  gives effect to the national literacy and numeracy plan and the subsequent initiatives announced in the 1999-2000 budget, building on the coalition's commitments to delivering better education for our young people—and I note the gracious acknowledgment of the member for Rankin in respect of his support for this bill, as far as it went. The bill does have a number of provisions, including a $36.3 million increase in the year 2000 under the literacy and numeracy plan to improve literacy and numeracy outcomes for students in not only early but also middle years of schooling.
I have spoken of the necessity to improve literacy and numeracy skills in the crucial early years where there must be a mix of early diagnosis and assessment, appropriate teaching strategies and professional development. In 1998, the government focused on the early years of schooling when it provided $176 million for literacy programs. In the 1999 budget, there was a general increase in funding for the national literacy and numeracy plan, but it went further than that. The funding was extended to support new initiatives targeting students in the middle years of schooling, just beyond the early years, in upper primary and secondary school through to year 10.
Why is this so? It is apparent now that those children who went through their early years of schooling more than three years ago, before this government came to office, did not have the benefit of this government's policies in funding literacy and numeracy programs for early schoolers. Labor did nothing of note in its 13 years in government to address the fact that we had an unacceptably low level of literacy and numeracy standards among our school children. It has only been since 1998 and the advent of the national literacy and numeracy plan that it has been an aim of federal, state and territory ministers for classroom teachers to assess the literacy needs of all children in their first year of school, with the aim of having every child reading 
 and writing properly by the end of primary school.
Having focused to date on the early years of schooling, the government also supported students, through the full service schools program in their final years of schooling, who were at risk of not completing school or who had returned to school as a result of the mutual obligation provisions of the youth allowance. The government is now completing the circle—mutual obligation, of course, being the concept we embrace; reciprocal responsibility being the British Labour leader's description of that same concept that he has embraced.
The new literacy funding provided for by this legislation targets those students who have slipped through the net between the literacy programs for the early years and those directed to the final years. These middle years of schooling are also of critical importance in a child's literacy and numeracy skill development at a time when their rapid physical, emotional and intellectual development is crucial.
The coalition's commitment to lifting literacy and numeracy standards has been adopted in a number of innovative ways, and not just in primary schools. A special school in my electorate of Curtin, the Speech and Hearing Centre for Deaf Children in Wembley, receives some funding under the national literacy plan for educationally disadvantaged children. It is an exceptional institution that works with children with hearing disabilities or hearing impairments and whose oral language or speech development has been retarded compared to their chronological peers. This school assists children with special language or speech needs to acquire skills so that they are able to enter regular school programs.
Under the national literacy plan, a number of schools have shown great initiative in enhancing children's appreciation for language and literature. Another school in my electorate, Mount Hawthorn Junior Primary, introduced a program whereby older members of the community visited the school and told the children stories of their life and experience as they grew up in the area. The children 
 then adapted the stories told to them by these older people and created their own pieces of inventive and imaginative work. This literacy program was designed to nurture their skills in comprehension, expression and language.
This government is committed to raising literacy and numeracy standards to give young people the best possible chance in life. The total funding of almost $680 million over the next four years to 2001-02 is money spent that will have an immense impact on educational opportunities for young Australians in our competitive knowledge-based economy. The funding provision of $36.3 million in this legislation for the year 2000 is an increase to government schools grants in literacy and numeracy from $111.7 million to over $135 million and to non-government schools from $43.2 million to nearly $48.6 million. Grants for national projects to foster literacy and numeracy are to be extended into the program year 2000 with nearly $7.63 million allocated.
It is perhaps a matter of serendipity that we speak on this bill just days before we celebrate National Literacy Week. Next week, Australia will celebrate for the first time National Literacy Week to coincide with International Literacy Day on 8 September. The federal government initiative has been developed in collaboration with state and territory governments and non-government education authorities to celebrate the progress Australian schools are making to improve the literacy and numeracy levels of all students, as well as acknowledge publicly the results that have been achieved. I am confident that National Literacy Week will raise the community awareness of the importance of all students developing effective literacy and numeracy skills.
There is another important aspect to this bill about which I propose to speak—that is, the provision of $26.4 million to extend funding for the National Asian Languages and Studies in Australian Schools, the NALSAS strategy, for the year 2000. Just as the government wants to give school students the fundamental skills in literacy and numeracy to give them every possible chance to lead a productive life, we are also committed to giving our 
 students a range of other skills to assist them in their employment opportunities.
To speak another language is a much admired ability. If that other language has the potential to add to one's employment prospects in the short or longer term, it becomes a much sought after ability. The government's funding commitment targets the enhanced and expanded study of Asian languages, specifically Chinese Mandarin, Japanese, Indonesian and Korean. The aim of the government's NALSAS strategy is to ensure 60 per cent of year 10 students and 15 per cent of year 12 students are studying an identified Asian language by 2006. The $90 million allocated in the 1999-2000 budget provided for in this legislation extends the funding over the next three years to 2002.
This far-sighted objective for Australian students recognises that closer engagement with Asia is a foreign and trade policy priority of this government. The study of Asian languages throughout the school system can only improve Australia's capacity and preparedness to interact with our Asian neighbours through their economies, their cultures and their communities. This gives our students greater opportunities when they enter the work force to participate in the global economy.
I am personally aware of the impact a second language, particularly an Asian language, can have on a potential employer. As the managing partner of a large law firm in Perth, I was responsible for employing our solicitors. In that role, I was increasingly aware that there was a need for lawyers to work in areas with an increasing interaction with Asian clients or Asian businesses. Any prospective employee with Asian language skills was at an immediate advantage, for there was an escalating need for our law firm to demonstrate that it had the skills within its work force to do work for or with Asian companies and businesses. I know I speak for many other employers in that regard.
Finally, this legislation provides for the continuation of previous capital funding arrangements for non-government schools to maintain funding at current real values. This is a continuation of our election commitment 
 to provide additional funding to maintain capital grants in current real terms. Further, this legislation provides for contingency funding for struggling non-government schools in the transition to the new system of funding for non-government schools.
In this year's budget, the government introduced some fundamental reforms to the way non-government schools are funded. We have moved away from the old notion that funding is based mostly on the way the schools structured their finances. This only limited the ability of non-government schools to respond to the needs of their communities or to raise additional income.
The socioeconomic status funding approach is more equitable. It is a fairer assessment of the school's needs because it focuses on the school's communities, not the school's accounts. This funding model measures the ability of the school community to support a school, and thus their level of entitlement for federal recurrent funding. No school will be financially disadvantaged. No school will be advantaged over another.
The additional short-term funding provided for in this legislation recognises that, if a school is affected by the changes in arrangements, there is a contingency fund to assist those schools that need support during the restructuring phase. These changed funding arrangements provide educational equity and offer choice. It better allows Australians choice in selecting a school which meets their children's needs. The increased funding has not been provided at the expense of the government schools.
Government schools are of course the domain of the states essentially, but the federal government has added to that pool with an additional $243 million in this year's budget for government schools. There is an extra $1 billion from the Commonwealth over the next four years, which will build on the 25 per cent increase in federal funding for the government sector already provided by the Howard government since 1996. So this legislation increases the capital grants for non-government schools from $74.5 million to $84.6 million for the year 2000 and increases the amount of short-term emergency 
 assistance for the transition phase in the funding model changeover from $614,000 to $2.5 million in the year 2000.
This legislation is another step forward in the implementation of this government's education policy. It is a policy of equity, fairness, opportunity and vision. Labor's education policy? Total disorder. As the member for Werriwa said last October of the Labor election policy on education, `They stuffed it up.' Perhaps not how others would phrase it—
—You wouldn't use that language, would you?
—I certainly would not, but we do get the picture. This government is working to prepare our young people for the demands and challenges they will face in the years ahead, in a world with a rate of change the likes of which we have not seen before. Tonight I recall the opening line in one of the books I studied, L.P. Hartley's novel, The Go Between , which goes something along the lines, `The past is a foreign country; they do things differently there.' Perhaps a truism we would do well to recall from time to time, but the 21st century is also a foreign country and we must do whatever we can as federal legislators to ensure that our young people have the skills and the opportunities to not only survive but also thrive in their journey through that foreign country—beyond the year 2000. I commend this bill to the House.
debate_title: <title>STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1999</title>

name: Cox, David, MP
text:
—One of the subjects which is never far from a parent's mind is the quality of their children's education. I know from very recent experience just how important this becomes when your children are about to start school. Parents know that the early years can be the most important. Problems that occur with literacy or numeracy in the very first years of schooling will be very hard to correct. When parents are worrying about that, they want to know that governments, both state and federal, share that priority. The only way governments can demonstrate that sense of priority is to ensure by their policies and funding that both government and non-government schools are 
 able to provide the quality education that children need.
More than ever before, it will be a good education that will be the key to your child realising his or her full potential. The States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1999  helps by providing a modest amount of funding to the states as specific purpose grants for education in four areas: $36.3 million to fund literacy and numeracy programs for students in the early and middle years of schooling for the 2000 school year; $26.4 million to extend funding for the National Asian Languages and Studies in Australian Schools strategy for the 2000 school year; continuation of previous capital funding arrangements for non-government schools; and contingency funding for struggling non-government schools in the transition to the new system of funding non-government schools. The literacy programs funded by the Commonwealth provide grants to schools to foster literacy and numeracy development, targeting educationally disadvantaged students. The additional money provided by this bill will support new initiatives for middle school—that is, upper primary to year 10 students.
 The national Asian languages strategy deserves special mention. As a result of it, children in their first year of schooling are learning a language. My five-year-old son who has just started at a local primary school is learning Japanese. That will open up for him and his classmates 12 years from now opportunities which probably would not otherwise have been available to them. The capacity to speak Japanese will certainly improve their job prospects. Some examples are running a cellar door at McLaren Vale catering to Japanese tourists, working as an engineer at the local Mitsubishi engine plant and negotiating trade contracts for Australian products or commodities in Tokyo. Much of the credit for the national Asian languages strategy must go to my colleague the member for Griffith who, in one of his former professional lives as the Director-General of the Queensland Cabinet Office, extracted a commitment to it from the former federal Labor government.
The additional capital funding grants for non-government schools honours a coalition commitment to maintain that funding at the same real value as was provided by the former Labor government in the years 1993 to 1996. The additional funding for short-term emergency assistance for non-government schools will assist those schools which are expected to benefit from the new funding system announced in the 1999-2000 budget but which are having difficulty surviving until it takes effect. But these modest provisions to help fund our children's education should not be looked at in isolation. What needs to be kept in focus is how the Howard government has reduced the capacity of the states to fund education.
At the time the Howard government came to office, Commonwealth grants represented about 13 per cent of total funding on government schools with the balance being met by state governments. About 38 per cent of total support for non-government schools is provided by the Commonwealth with 18 per cent being provided by the states and territories and the remaining 44 per cent from private sources. The Howard government has cut financial assistance grants to the states and territories which has reduced their capacity to fund schools from the resources available to them. In both 1994 and 1995 the federal Labor government had provided the states and territories with a real terms per capita guarantee for financial assistance grants. But when the Howard government took office in 1996 it maintained the real per capita guarantee base but negated it by requiring the states to make a fiscal contribution to the Commonwealth.
That fiscal contribution amounted to $1.5 billion over the first three years of the Howard government. The precise amounts were $619 million in 1996-97, $627 million in 1997-98 and $313 million in 1998-99. The liability for those contributions was allocated amongst the states on an equal per capita basis. That meant that the smaller states, like South Australia, carried a disproportionate burden given their relatively higher cost structures and smaller capacities to raise revenue. The result was a reduced capacity 
 for the states to fund their school systems. The ABS government financial estimates show how much in total the South Australian government was able to spend on primary and secondary education since 1993-94.
In South Australia's case, severe budget pressures predated the cut to financial assistance grants in 1996-97. The last year that Labor was in office at a state level was 1993. Because of Premier Arnold's commitment to education—he was both a former teacher and education minister—he had endeavoured to quarantine funding for schools from the significant cuts that were necessary elsewhere in his budget. Spending on schools from the state's own sources, including financial assistance grants, was $834 million in 1993-94. As soon as the Liberals took office, they cut it, first to $807 million in 1994-95 and then as low as $744 million in 1995-96. South Australia's education system has been struggling ever since.
There was a small increase in 1996-97 to $776 million. Schools got a larger increase to $899 million in 1997-98, which was, of course, a state election year and a year in which the education department got some supplementation from the state government for a pay rise for teachers. Commonwealth grants to South Australia for current school spending over that period rose steadily from $198 million in 1993-94 to $208 million in 1994-95, $218 million in 1995-96, $213 million in 1996-97 and $261 million in 1997-98. However, in the Howard government's first budget in 1996, it made a general cut to direct Commonwealth funding for education by applying an efficiency dividend to Commonwealth own purpose outlays and specific purpose payments. The consequence for the total education budget was a cut of $13 million in 1996-97, $35.2 million in 1997-98, $46.5 million in 1998-99 and $55.4 million in 1999-2000. With this efficiency dividend spread over the whole of the education budget, the implications for school funding are small.
The big issue with specific purpose payments for schools is the shift in funding growth from government to private schools. The 1996 budget papers showed expected 
 growth in funding to government schools of 3.8 per cent in 1996-97, 1.1 per cent in 1997-98, 1.2 per cent in 1998-99 and 0.7 per cent in 1999-2000. By comparison, growth in funding to non-government schools was expected to be much stronger: 6.1 per cent in 1996-97, 6.9 per cent in 1997-98, 6.9 per cent in 1998-99 and 6.3 per cent in 1999-2000. This shift in funding is the result of a combination of factors, including higher average specific purpose payments for children in non-government schools and a growth in the number of parents seeking better educational opportunities for their children through private education.
However, in the 1996 budget the Howard government introduced a more controversial factor—the enrolment benchmark adjustment. The Howard government claims that the cost to state governments of a child in a non-government school is some $3,400 less than the cost of a child in a government school. The enrolment benchmark adjustment uses 1996 as the base year and compares shares of enrolments in the government and non-government sectors for each subsequent year.
Each year, if the comparison with 1996 shows a decline in the percentage of enrolments in government schools, the Commonwealth takes away approximately half the claimed savings to the states. That is around $1,700 per student represented in the percentage change. The calculation is done on a state by state basis. A buffer has been applied in each of the EBA's two years of operation—500 in 1997 and 1,500 in 1998. The Howard government claims that the states achieve significant savings from declines in government school enrolments, but in reality the changes that occur are spread thinly across the state education system and there are no significant changes in teaching or administrative costs.
The enrolment benchmark adjustment has cost South Australia $2.28 in 1997 and $3.1 million in 1998. Nationally the savings to the Commonwealth were $11.9 million in 1997 and $21.1 million in 1998. The EBA cut is a cut in addition to any shift in per capita payments from the Commonwealth as a result of changing enrolment populations. Because 
 the EBA formula is based on the proportion of enrolments rather than raw numbers, government schools can actually increase the absolute number of students they enrol and the state will still be subjected to EBA cuts.
—And still lose money.
—Yes, they will still lose money, because private school enrolments have increased by more. Fortunately, this has not happened in South Australia. It is also the case that the EBA does not work in reverse. That is, if the proportion of students in government schools grows, no additional EBA funds are provided.
There is also a big question mark hanging over the future of Commonwealth funding for the states general purposes including schools and directly for schools. Financial assistance grants will be replaced by the revenue from the GST from 1 July 2000. Initially the GST revenues will not be enough to fund the states' current expenditure and the new responsibilities they will have to assume. The arrangements for distributing GST revenues between the states are yet to be worked out. That means that it is an open question whether the states, particularly the smaller states, will have a large enough revenue base to properly support their education system, in the long term. While there will be a transitional period during which the Commonwealth has guaranteed that the states will not be worse off under the new arrangements, this is far from a long-term guarantee of maintenance of all of their funding. Clause 5(v) of the Intergovernmental Agreement on Commonwealth-State Financial Relations says:
The Commonwealth will continue to provide Specific Purpose Payments to the States and Territories and has no intention of cutting aggregate SPPs as part of the reform process set out in this Agreement, consistent with the objective of State and Territory Governments being financially better off under the new arrangements.
The words `no intention' are very far from a guarantee that SPPs will not be cut. Even if they are maintained in aggregate, they may be cut in real terms or not given growth funding commensurate with growth in demand for the services they are supposed to cover. This is how the Howard government will claw back the growth in state revenues which the GST 
 is expected to provide. Whenever it is necessary to cut Commonwealth expenditure, it will always be easier for a coalition government to cut specific purpose payments to the states for education than it will be to cut the federal government's own programs.
South Australia's school system will be extremely vulnerable to any adverse changes in specific purpose payments or the level of GST revenues. One of the main functions of a federal system is to ensure that there is a fair redistribution of resources amongst the states to fund essential government services like education. Whether or not running a school system is, in the first instance, a role of the states, at the end of the day the federal government shares the responsibility to every child in Australia to see that their school is properly funded.
debate_title: <title>STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1999</title>

name: Thompson, Cameron, MP
text:
—The member for Kingston reminds me of that lost ABC radio program The Could Have Beens . I do not know whether members recall that radio program. It used to be on late at night. It was quite a good program. One of the big features of that program was the regular appearance of `Stan the Statistician'. `Stan the Statistician' could prove anything by way of statistics. For example, he knew how many left-handed Australian batsmen were nightwatchmen in tests where the Australians had lost the toss. He knew important bits of information like that. When that radio program was gone, I lamented the loss of `Stan the Statistician'. At the time the program was running, I thought that `Stan the Statistician' was just an eccentric listener. It turns out that he was in fact the member for Kingston. I am relieved to be here to witness the wit of the member for Kingston and to hear some more of those great statistical high points.
—He was halfway there.
—He was halfway there. I suppose it is a below par performance for a statistician, but it was a pretty good exercise in remembering past glories.
The  States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1999  amends the States Grants (Primary and Secon 
 dary Education) Assistance Act 1996. It enacts several initiatives from the 1999-2000 budget. I will refer to some of the budget announcements relating to education. For example, the budget increased funding for education of $870 million over the four coming years. This money will support higher standards, increased opportunity and greater choice in education for all Australians and in 1999-2000 represents an increase of $183 million over the previous year. The $11 billion allocated to education includes approximately $5 billion for schooling.
Some of the other highlights included in the budget is funding for indigenous education programs totalling $996 million over the five years to 2004. The government announced strengthened accountability arrangements for particular programs, including literacy and numeracy programs, which are to be simplified and streamlined. In 1999-2000, $354 million is allocated for New Apprenticeships and $1.6 billion for vocational education and training.
There was a provision for the maintenance of funding of about $13 million per year for the continuation of the Jobs Pathway Program to help young people move successfully from schools to work. Some $60 million is to be provided over four years to continue the Job Placement, Education and Training Program. The funding allocated to JPET will allow 40,000 young people to be assisted in that period. Those were the general attributes of the 1999-2000 budget.
We are looking today at a couple of the important specifics announced in that budget. To begin with, I refer to increased funding of $36.3 million for literacy and numeracy in the year 2000. We find in the budget that the government has allocated an additional $131.1 million for 1999-2000 through to 2003-04 for literacy and numeracy programs for school students, making a total of almost $869 million to assist students with special needs in literacy and numeracy in those four years.
There were some important milestones recognised with regard to literacy and numeracy. The increased funding supported two initiatives announced as part of the government's 1998 election commitments. The first 
 is to improve literacy and numeracy in the middle years of schooling, for which $47.1 million has been allocated. The second is funding of $84 million for a national literacy and numeracy plan.
At the time, the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs stated that there was a great need for action to deal with the problems of the middle years of school because in many cases those students had missed out on acquiring vital skills in the early years of schooling. As a result, they have difficulties coping with the demands of the school curriculum. Dealing with literacy and numeracy problems does not end in the infant years of schooling. For the people experiencing difficulties with literacy, those problems can worsen dramatically as time goes by and their self-esteem and the problems associated with a lack of basic skill get worse.
Another $26.4 million was allocated to extend the National Asian Languages and Studies in Australian Schools program, NALSAS, to the year 2000. That is an allocation dealt with in this bill. That harks back to the budget announcement of additional funding over the next three years of $90 million to continue NALSAS and recognise the important goals that NALSAS is seeking to realise. To highlight some of the achievements of that program, between 1994 and 1997 the number of students studying Japanese increased by over 50,000, the number studying Chinese by 20,000 and the number studying Indonesian by over 100,000. Those are important achievements and we must set about continuing to promote the study of those languages.
Another area dealt with in this bill that reflects the budget announcements is the change to a more appropriate system for funding non-government schools. The budget announcement states that Australia's 2,519 non-government schools will get Commonwealth funding based on a socioeconomic status assessment of the school communities. That comes straight out of the very reliable and reputable ABS data, and it is an important improvement on what has gone before. The new arrangements will give non-govern 
 ment schools drawing enrolments for low income communities a substantial increase in funding. Schools serving the neediest communities at present receive 56 per cent of average government school recurrent costs. Under the new arrangements they will receive 70 per cent. This represents, in 1998 dollars, an estimated increase of $672 per primary student and an estimated increase of $762 per secondary student in schools serving the neediest communities.
Debate interrupted.
debate_title: <title>STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1999</title>

name: Sidebottom, Peter, MP
text:
—It is a sad irony that, in this International Year of Older Persons, in Tasmania those responsible for caring for the aged in our community hold grave fears for the future of the nursing home sector. Furthermore, their frustration over this government's handling of funding to nursing homes is an indictment of the minister responsible. May I give you an example. Aged Care Tasmania, an association representing nursing homes in my state, tells me it has written to Minister Bishop no fewer than seven times in the past three months expressing its concerns and seeking answers to funding questions. It has had just one reply which, I am told, did absolutely nothing to alleviate its fears.
Nursing homes in my electorate and around Tasmania are bracing themselves for harsh funding cuts that they fear will cost jobs and severely impact on the quality of aged care. In Tasmania there are currently more than 4,000 people in nursing homes and the demand for nursing home beds and quality care certainly is not diminishing. In my electorate there are 24 aged care facilities with a combined total of 800 nursing home places. Half of the elderly residents in these nursing homes require a high level of care, yet double the amount of beds would not even go close to meeting the demand. As I have just said, the demand where I come from is not diminishing. Close to 24 per cent of the population is 
 50 and over, and 10 per cent is 65 years and over. Nursing home operators are only too well aware of the demands an ageing population puts on the system, but the government has responsibility to look after the elderly in our communities.
Aged care providers in Tasmania sum up one of the biggest threats to their industry in one word—coalescence. We have recently seen the second stage of this government's coalescence policy introduced, a policy aimed at equalising Commonwealth funding for aged care providers across Australia; in other words, working towards a national average. While in theory this may seem equitable, in practice it is a looming disaster for Tasmanian nursing homes and their elderly communities. It is recognised that the cost of providing aged care in Tasmania is considerably higher than in other states and territories. We cannot do anything about that—it is the price we continually pay for living where we live—and there is little scope for Tasmanian nursing homes to mitigate their relatively high cost structure. But at least the cost differential was recognised under the previous funding arrangements where sufficient compensation was paid for the higher input costs faced by Tasmanian homes. That is why Tasmania received the highest care subsidies in Australia and therefore stands to be the hardest hit and to suffer most under this policy.
Aged care providers in Tasmania have done their homework. They have done the sums and they do not add up to a fair and responsible funding policy. They have calculated that cuts to nursing homes because of coalescence will see a reduction in Commonwealth subsidies to Tasmania of around eight per cent over the next six years. This will mean the loss of about $6.8 million a year to nursing homes in my state. On average each nursing home resident will receive $2,730 less a year—and it gets worse. It has been estimated that coalescence, once fully implemented, will result in the loss of more than 330 jobs in the aged care industry in Tasmania and will result in redundancy payments of more than $5 million. Not only will basic care standards be jeopardised; coalescence threatens to impinge further on the quality of life of elderly 
 Tasmanians, affecting the little things that now may be taken for granted—things like the regular bus outings for residents of the Eliza Purton Home at Ulverstone. For this home, like many others around Tasmania, it will be a matter of survival. They will be forced to prune costs if they want to survive. Yet this Minister for Aged Care continues to turn a blind eye to the dilemma.
It is claimed by the minister the impact of coalescence in Tasmania will be offset by a 38 per cent increase in aged care funding to Tasmania, yet despite its best efforts through the department and within its own membership the industry cannot find the extra money. In fact, by its own calculations funding from the Commonwealth this year is $20 million short. The industry is concerned someone is attempting to fudge the figures, so I challenge the minister to prove these concerns wrong and I urge Tasmanian Liberal senators to vigorously take up this cause. I join the providers of aged care in Tasmania in their challenge to the minister to implement the findings of this government's own Productivity Commission report into aged care. The Productivity Commission proposed the government identify a benchmark of quality care and then determine how much funding was required to reach that level of care in each state in regions like my own. As Aged Care Tasmania puts it:
We support coalescence rates for the provision of care throughout Australia but we cannot support coalescence rates where money is taken from some and given to others to make it `even'.
This policy of coalescence directly contradicts the overriding policy objectives in aged care of ensuring quality of access and a nationally accepted standard of care to all Australians in need, irrespective of their personal circumstances or where they live.

name: Murphy, John, MP
text:
—I raise the issue of migration agency regulation. On the ABC's 7.30 Report  of 25 August 1999, Mr Kerry O'Brien said:
Thousands of hopeful migrants have had their futures cast into doubt following the closure of Australia's biggest immigration law firm. Barlow & Company—which had offices in Sydney and Melbourne has suddenly closed its doors after 20 years; its principal lawyer, Neil Barlow, declaring himself bankrupt. Of the firm's 3,000 clients, many stand to lose thousands of dollars in up-front fees.
Reporter Jacinta Tynan noted:
Just days before, staff at Barlow & Company were telling clients they would be closing for an inventory and back in business this week, in fact the firms's principal, Neil Barlow, had already filed for personal bankruptcy, the day after he deregistered himself as a migration agent.
Clients were told nothing. Dr Charles Sinclair, a former employee, said in the report:
A notice was put up saying that an inventory was being carried out. I don't know how you carry out an inventory in a law office. But the switchboard was also told that no calls were to be put through to us and that they could call back on 20 August, by which time, of course, we had all departed.
The 7.30 Report  notes Dr Sinclair worked as a migration agent at Barlow and Company for the past 15 months. Dr Sinclair became concerned about the firm's business practices. Clients were made to pay up front on the promise of a refund if the case was unsuccessful. Charles Sinclair believes those funds were being withdrawn before the work was complete. The 7.30 Report  interviewed Mr Ray Brown of the Migration Agents Regulation Authority, MARA, who said:
I can't say he was under investigation but there were complaints that were before us and we were looking into those complaints.
MARA has limited powers to investigate agents or audit their books. Since Neil Barlow deregistered himself as an agent, he is no longer accountable to the authority. Dr Sinclair further notes:
I think that the clients have really been short-changed. They have paid monies to have a contract executed. They have paid for a whole lot of work which will never be done and I feel very sorry for these clients because they have no redress at all now.
The immigration department says that because of the `human impact' of the collapse of Barlow and Company it will grant special concessions to the firm's former clients by extending the deadlines for processing visas. But under present law there is little that can be done to prevent this happening again. Just two weeks ago Neil Barlow was advertising in the ethnic press, trading on his expertise as a lawyer, to attract clients.
My electorate of Lowe is one of the most culturally diverse electorates in Australia. The vast majority of my constituency work is immigration work, resulting many times from constituents who have lost confidence in the legal system. I agree with Dr Sinclair's following comments:
I think the Law Society has an utter hide, the way they have carried on in this case. They have a responsibility to clients. They have a responsibility to solicitors. There is no doubt at all in my mind that Mr Barlow was a solicitor.
The Law Society is under a duty to all clients and society as a whole in this matter. I note Mr Bitel's comments:
I'm amazed that . . . the Law Society won't speak to the 7.30 Report . I would have thought that whenever a firm goes under—and they do from time to time—the Law Society's public relations department should at least come on line and assure the community that the Law Society is in control.
I urge the minister for immigration to conduct an inquiry into this matter, especially the conduct of the New South Wales Law Society because the Law Society refuses to intervene in assisting those displaced clients and restore confidence in the legal profession. (Time expired)

name: Williams, Daryl, MP
text:
—I move:
That the bill be now read a second time.
